T: This drinks a lot like an iced black hazelnut coffee with carbonation with a hint of mocha. Its decent but I was hoping a bit sweeter from the nose.

M: Medium bodied with slight sharp carbonation that comes towards the end.

O: This is a solid brown ale, one of the better ones. Its easy to drink though I dont think Id ever buy a 6 pack of it.

Pours a deep golden brown without much of a head. Lacing is nonexistent. The nose is all hazelnut and the mouthfeel is medium and creamy smooth. The taste is rich and pleasing with hazelnut being the strongest sensation Very, very satisfying.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown cloudy liquid with a very thin off-white head. Small amounts of lace on the glass. Smells slighty roasty, with a nuttiness. Big malty flavors, not quite dark roast. Nutty sewwtness. Dry finish. Not much bitterness. Medium body, low carbonation.
Very good brown ale. Definitely has a hazel nut taste through out its body. Good and malty.

Bottle; dark brown with small brown head; aroma-hazelnut, nuts, sweet-reminding me of coffee creamer; taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter, definitely hazelnuts, drymedium body, slick feel, lively. Good beer reminding me of a Black and tan at first.

This beer is delicious.  Pours a dark brown, nose is hazelnut and sweet.  Its almost like a dessert beer.  Finish is hazelnut almost like a coffee creamer, beer drinkers and non beer drinkers alike will enjoy this one.

12 oz Bottle poured pint glass.  Pours a dark brown with a frothy brownish tan head.  Smell is hazelnut and chocolate.  Taste simply knocks you off your feet.  Almost hard to classify it as a beer.  Liquid Nutella is the best way to describe this delicious treat.  Strong hazelnut chocolate flavor simply dominates the taste of this beer. A real winner here but it should very Much be considered a dessert beer!

13/10/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (650ml bottle). Ambrata carica, intensa, riflessi di miele, bella schiuma bianco sporca, non molto persistente. Aroma molto particolare di frutta secca, nocciole, vaniglia. In bocca ha un corpo abbastanza modesto, è dolciastra, sentori di nocciola, vaniglia, miele. Carbonazione corretta. Non è il mio genere di birra, ma tra le brown ale è sicuramente sui generis e si lascia apprezzare per la genuinità della materia prima.

Deep amber in color with hint of off-white head.  Nice hazelnut aroma, like hazelnut coffee.  A nice rich brown ale with ful hazelnut flavor.  A nice twist on the brown ale.

On tap at the Flying Saucer, San Antonio.

Pours hazy brown. Beige head  . Aroma is maple, fig, and malt  . Flavor is nutty, maple, fig, roasty malt and nutela hazelnut.  Thin beer.  Nice and drinkable   nothin to write home about.  Its a good brown though.

Wife picked this out from Total Wine. She seems to have good taste. Poured from a 12 oz bottle. Nose is of Frangelico Liqueur. Taste is sweet and heavenly. Finishes a bit sweet. Heck, this is good stuff.

Beautiful pour, a wonderful clear brown.  The aroma is nice, too, with caramel and light hazel aroma.  Honestly, what killed it for me, was the hazelnut flavor.  It seems like some reviews on here mention the hazelnut as being obscure, as being background, but the hazelnut flavor absolutely dominates the taste of the beer for me.  I dont know if Im particularly sensitive or not, but the hazelnut domination in this beer made it almost undrinkable to me.  If you like hazelnut, this is totally your thing, but if not, Id avoid this.
UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 Wasnt majorly impressed. Found it to be very drinkable. Felt like the hazelnut was a bit obscure. Just wasnt enough there to excite me. So many other better brown ales.

on tap at the Tremont Tap house, poured into a oversized wine glass

a: translicent medium brown color, nice creamy off white head

s: roasted barrly gives off slight coffee aroma, also has a nice nut aroma

t: nice mixture of hazelnut, and roasted/ carmalized malt. hint of coholate and slight fruit. Big on sweetness.

m&d: light mouthfeel, just creamy to the palate. Excellent Beer!
Keg at Brauhaus. Dark mahogany brown, medium off-white head. Big hazelnut, milk chocolate bready nose. Fruity roast palate, some nutty notes, some woodiness also. Sweet nutella finish. Really tasty!

On keg at The Brauhaus. Pours an amber brown colour with a fair light tan head. Aroma of hazelnut and caramel. Similar flavours, just a little sweet, with a lingering Nutella character. Alcohol is well balanced with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. OK.

Dark ruby red with a big head that disipates quickly. Smells of fruit, peach/plum and very seet malty aroma. The taste is complex with a nutty/plum taste mixed in with chocolate undertones. The mouthfeel is thick. This beer is very drinkable
The aroma is very unique with more than just a hint of hazelnut. the flavor is very nutty and roasted, almost like a porter.

From notes.  First reviewed 3/14/2010.  Served on tap in a pint glass.

My pour of Rogue HazlelNut Brown has a deep, slightly cloudy burgundy color, with cherry changing to brown with the thickness of the glass. Soft off-white head lingers casually.

Strong, smooth, nutty aroma dominates the nose; roasted malt and vanilla also present.

There is a persistent, controlling hazelnut taste from start to finish. Caramel sweetness and a roasted malt flavor provide additional introductory stimulation, and some vanilla notes find their way into the flavor.

The very smooth taste is somewhat thrown off by the carbonation. It would be an improved with a creamier feel.

With a good level of complexity and balance, this is a great niche beer in the brown ale category. Definitely worth looking for on a regular basis.

A: A nice dark brown appearance. A thumbs width head first appeared that eventually dwindled down to small lacing on the surface.

S: Nutty, some toffee, some brown sugar.

T: A strong and bold hazelnut taste hits you upfront and stays with you throughout, but milds out as it goes along in a very positive way. The one complaint is that the flavor is definitely not organic, it comes from extract (think hazelnut drinks at Starbucks flavor), but until another beer produces a hazelnut brown ale with hazelnut beans I will always come back to this. The hazelnut definite dominates the flavor but hidden below is a brown sugary kind of undertone with just the slightest touch of some bitterness at the end.

P: A little too much carbonation, medium bodied.

O: One of my favorite beers and now that its offered in 6 packs make me a very happy person. It is a bit of a one dimensional beer, its definitely hazelnut-centric, but that one focus is done well and is of a flavor that I love.

12oz bottle, thanks to Callipalegic. Mostly clear mahogany color, thin tan head. Little lace. Moderate, smooth carbonation. Hazelnut nectary aroma really comes through, its very interesting... But not necessarily delicious. Its the type of flavor that would get old after a bit, unless you really love hazelnut. A single bottle is fun, but getting through a 6-pack of this may be a challenge. Taste is a little sweet, like hazelnut icing or something.

As soon as you crack this one open you smell the abundance of hazelnut, chocolate, and caramel. Pour is with mild to moderate head. Oak brown color. Low on hops heavy on malts. Taste is mild on all aromas but very well balanced. Finally a good craft thats a crowd pleaser that isnt Fat Tire.
Bottled. Brown with amber hues and a short head. Aromatic sugar cereal and hazelnut nose with a palate to match. Medium body, thin-sticky texture, and a chocolate malty, sweet finish. Good beer.
If there is a better Nut Brown Ale out there currently Ive never had it. The Hazelnut flavor really comes through. Sweet but not overly so. Actually very drinkable. Delicious stuff.

pours dark cloudy brown with a white head.aroma is pure hazelnut.flavour is hazelnut chocolate and a sweet malty toasty finish.at first sip i did not like it and kept drinking and have to say it is unique and your palate adjust to the strong flavour of the hazelnut.probably wouldnt try this one again

Pours a very deep brown with a little bit of head.  The aroma is a very strong, overpowering hazelnut.  I dont believe the taste lived up to the scent.  It was still very good, but after the first hint, I guess I might have expected more if that makes any sense.  It might smell as good or better than any beer Ive ever had, it just doesnt translate to the strength of the taste, which of course have made my rating higher.  It is chocolatey and hazelnut in flavor and it is not very hoppy.  I enjoyed this very much.

650ml bottle. Clear brown/amber pour with a tan head that leaves a little lace. Strong hazelnuts on the nose...in the first whiff thats all you get. With a little digging theres a vanilla note in there and a light roasted maltiness. Very nutty on the palate but not nearly as one dimensional as the nose. That vanilla note sticks on the palate and theres a good malty finish with the slightest of sweetness.
Had this for the first time on tap at Yard House.... Its literally all I order now when I go there. Great aroma, clean, nutty flavor. Small head. Do yourself a favor and try it.
Ruby color with a nice white head. Taste is sweet, hazelnuts (well...). Medium body with a heavy carbonation

Pours brown with a thin cream head leaving some lacing. Aroma is hazelnut. Taste is hazelnut, malt, a nice toastiness, mild sweetness, and a good bitter balance. Hazelnut in the aftertaste. Very good.
21/01/2012 Brasserie 4:20 alla spina.  Profumo di nocciola fantastico. Retrogusto amarognolo, con sentori di buccia di nocciola. Non troppo impegnativa, buona bevibilità.

Pours brown with a thin white head.  Right away I pick up on the hazelnut in the nose, and Ive never had a brew that smelled this nutty.  Taste is similar to the aroma but with hints of sweet toasted malts to go along with the extreme nuttiness.  I generally prefer brown ales with more hop character but this is probably the best nut brown ale that Ive had.
This is a beer of which I could consume indefinite quantities. Subtle but substantial hazlenut taste. Great finish.

Bomber. Pours a medium dark brown with reddish highlights. Tannish head. Aroma is clearly nutty, toffee and woody. Taste is roast malt and hazelnut. Better as the beer warmed a bit in the glass. Good for the style with a new twist on a brown ale.....a mouthier feel would have aided this beer.
pours a nice deep copper colour with thin head. WOW Hazelnuts in the aroma and flavour stand out the most with a nice malt base and a bit of bitterness

Loads of hazelnut, some malt, hops and a hint of cream. Sweet hazelnut flavour to start which fades to some malt and hop bitterness. Coffee and chocolate notes in there. Amazing brown ale. Wish I could get my hands on more.

Nutty hazelnut comes off deep in the nose and in the mouth. Slight hoppiness. Thin mouthfeel. Great beer though. 

Carbonation is not harsh at all.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2014 Try it on tap, it has a delicious hazelnut flavor, well balanced with the malts, cant remember any hop aroma, anyway, a beer that want to try it again, with proper carbonation.

Second try in a bottle, medium low carbonation, subtle hazelnut aroma, hazelnut and malty flavor, smooth aftertaste. This beer is balanced.
I really liked the beer. It had subtle notes of hazelnut that was pronounced while eating lunch. Would buy again.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2012 It  was pretty - and that was about it. I love Rogue, but this one was a swing and a miss. A: Nuts. T:Nuts, Nuts, Nuts. P: Bitter Nuts. O: Nuts. Gettin my drift? I was looking for a more traditional brown ale that had a hint of hazelnut. This, not so much....

Tap @ Brasserie 4:20 amber/red color, tan head.
Aroma of hazelnut, walnut, oak, nutella, malt. Taste of nutella, walnut cinnamon. a little bit too watery. slightly bitter. I had this one in bottle some months ago and it liked it much more.

22oz bomber. Pours a burgundy brown with a tan head. Very tasty brown ale with a definite hazelnut flavor to it. Normally I would be a bit wary of a hazelnut beer but these guys know what they are doing and manage to pull it off.
Brown in color and tan head.  Very chocolate with nutty taste.  Its very rich and meaty with a sweet taste.
Bottle. Dark brown/amber wit big tan head. Aroma isd malt, caramel and very nutty. Flavour is malt, caramel, strong nut extract, medium sweet, hops, spices, earthy and wood.
This pours a beautiful dark brown with a creamy tan head. The hazelnut flavor is perfectly balanced. This is hands down my favorite beer.
The beer that got me into darker beers.  The better version is sold with a different logo and is aged in a hazelnut barrel -- seasonal

200ml, on tap at Schouskjelleren Mikrobryggeri. Hazy, dark-reddish body. Fair amount of off-white head. Nutty sweet, earthy malt to the nose. Chocolate and nutty brown malts in flavour. Lightly creamy in the mouth. Likable (Oslo, 05.01.2012).

On tap at Schouskjelleren.
Nutty, round, rather sweet. Cereals. Sweet finish. The nut extracts is a bit too stong.
22 oz bomber pours a light brown  color with a medium off white head.  Aromas of nuts, roast malt, light chocolate.  Medium bodied with a hazelnut finish, really great brown ale.

Semi-clear brownish amber pour with a two-finger light brown head. Aroma is quite nutty, with a lot of earthy toffee notes, caramel, and bready malts. Aroma is on the sweet and malty side of town, but not overwhelmingly so. Lots of toffee and hazelnut flavor. Slight balancing bitterness. Palate is clean and medium bodied. Pretty good, but I wouldnt confuse it for Sam Smiths Nut Brown.
Hazy orangey brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and nutty. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. Smooth. 311211

Pleasant aroma, albeit mild. Hazelnut and chocolatey flavor is present but too week to excite. The only redeeming characteristic of this brew is the aftertaste, which is quite appealing; similar to that of dark chocolate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: dark clear brown, with a short, light tan and creamy head.   Aroma: 	toasted nuts, a bit of pipe smoke, cream, and brown bread.   Taste: notes of caramel, chocolate, and a bit of café late, with solid hazelnut goodness threading throughout.   Finish: clean, light, and a bit creamy.   Notes: Delicious and incredibly drinkable.  Had the whole bomber before I knew it.  Could have been cloying, but the sweetness was restrained and the hazelnuts, while assertive and central to the beer, somehow did not overpower it.

22oz bottle. Pours brown with thin beige head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, roasted malt, and hazelnut of course. Flavor is nutty, roasted malt, and chocolate. Light mouthfeel and carbonation. A fantastic brown ale with delicious hazelnut notes throughout.

Purchased at Binnys in Chicago, IL; enjoyed before my 4 day holiday weekend.  I did also have this recently at a Japanese restaurant with a friend, but this didnt go very well with sushi.  Appearance a slightly clear brownish amber with a rich off-white head that laces to the glass.  Aroma of hazelnut, a dash of cream, but not much else.  Taste is more rich in hazelnut, gives a great crisp finish thats very smooth and has a little bit of crispness to it.  Its not very dessert like but also probably wouldnt go well with a meal, great to just drink on its own without food.  Very good stuff, will drink then eat some sushi as I guess a new tradition is born?

Tap at Yardhouse in downtown LA.  Aroma is tobacco, roasted malts, and a little cream.  Flavor is tobacco, roasted malts, cream, and hazelnuts.   The hazelnuts are very noticeable in the flavor of this beer.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2014 The nose is hazelnut (obviously), sourdough bread, chocolate, and toffee, with an almost Nutella-like feel to it. The taste is quite sweet, with an interesting tartness to it, not awfully bitter.  No alcohol intrusion, either. The mouthfeel is somewhat watery. It needs more balance and substance, though, as the hazelnut sweetness is quite dominant.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2012 Just look at that hipster on the bottle. He looks like he knows about beer. This is a brown ale with a very sweet, nutty flavor. Delicious.

Pours a murky brown with a quickly fading tan head.  The aroma is a magnificent smell of hazelnut with a hint of barley.  The taste nearly matches the aroma with a traditional ale flavor up front followed by a rich hazelnut finish.  Its very smooth & quite sessionable.  Very tasty!  A must try for brown ale lovers.
This is my absolute favourite from rogue! Deep brown pour, well balanced flavour, nutty and slightly sweet.
This may be the best brown ale I have ever had. Pity I only had 2 oz of it.  I will be tracking down more and then updating this rating to something more precise.

This is my favorite brown ale by far!  Rogue did a really good job with this one.  Malty, nutty and sweet but balanced with a little hops.  Its the hops that makes this my favorite brown ale because it just helps balance out the malts; but its still a good malty beer overall.  This is also one of my favorite Rogue beers overall as well.  This would be good with cheese burger or a bbq pulled pork sandwich.

Pours a brown-red with a nice thick head. Plenty of carbonation.  Smells of hops and malt. Slightly grassy as well. Plenty of roasted malt flavor, a moderate amount of sweetness that is like caramel and a touch of something darker like chocolate. Finish is similar but the hazelnut/nutty flavor lingers for a long time. Very balanced and mild. I think this beer would improve if they reduced the hops and let the nutty/toasty flavor ride through the finish.

A great beer.  The aroma is malty with roast and caramel smells.  However the bulk of the aroma character standout as hazelnut.  The beer is deep brown with a fluffy tan head.  The taste is sweet with heavy notes from the hazelnut.  the more subtle malt flavors are there as well to balance the profile.  The body is medium to full and balanced.  Overall a good beer.  Id like to try a version without the hazelnut additions.

Musty, malty, nutty, slightly grassy, and with a touch of scorched/smoke aroma.  Beautiful in the glass, though not totally clear.  Taste is dominated by hazelnut up front but other light toasted notes, mellowed with a balanced bitterness on the back of the palate.  Theres also something like a green hay flavor, perhaps hop derived, which is rather off putting.  Wonderfully weighted mouthfeel, perfect for the style, perfect carbonation.  Overall Ive had better brown ales, and the hazelnut is too dominant for my taste.  However Ill have another, just not for $6 for a 22 oz.
Like a freshly chewed hazelnut, thick head, moderate body, crisp and fresh. Very good. Not sweet.
Nose is broad hazel, cane sugar, malt, weak oak, feel is watery, carb is medium, taste is weak earth, broad sour malt, little hops bite before hazel finish

Sampled on tap pours brown with an off white head. Aroma is strong very nutty and malty.  Flavor screams of hazelnut but a tasty amount backed bubs good malty beer. Body is medium.and finish leaves a sweet hazelnut behind
Low aroma, somewhat thin mouthfeel, and a lack of much that is very interesting. I do taste the hazelnut, but I do not care of it . Not one I would want again.
Bottle. Nutty, chocolate, sweet malt, and alcohol aroma. Clear amber with a thin tan head. Flavor is burnt sugar, nuts, and a long slightly bitter hop finish, Medium body, slightly dry finish,
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 At Shoeless Joes. I didnt expect this to be so nutty flavored. But is smelled and tasted quite hazelnutty.  A little sweet but pretty good. Serving: Bottle

Draught @ Pikkulintu.
Rated on 20110729.
Pours clear red colour with light head. Aroma of dry floury yeast bread, some nuts too. Flavour of roasted malts, some chocolate and nuts. Oddly floury.
4324
Notas de caramelo, con un punto resinoso a la vez suave y muy bebible, una  cerveza original y novedosa.
My favorite beer so far and being a native Oregonian, Im quite proud of my Rogue!

Draft from a hand pump at the J. Clyde.  Pours dark brown with a small light tan head.  Aroma is sweet, rich hazelnut, caramel malt, some spicy hops, and something else.  All that is there in the flavor, including the something else.  My friend and I surmised that there must have been some cask conditioning, given that it was on a hand pump.  Maybe something exotic like a rum or sherry cask.  Silky mouth feel.  Long, rich, slightly bitter finish.  Quite delicious and subtle.

In taster at churchills.  Looks dark ruby very clear.  No head.  Smells like honey and spices.  Tastes clear then thick on the palate after i moved my tongue.  Definite spiced caramel malts.  Overall 7.5 of 10

Pours with a nice frothy head that lasts. Rich malty taste at the start, finishes with a creamy hazelnut flavor. Fairly light, easy drinking beer, with a flavor that feels like you should be drinking a porter. Would buy again

This brew poured up a dark hazelnut colored body with a creamy tan-colored head that held moderate retention and light lacing effects. Aromas full of sweet roasted malts, hazelnuts (duh!), dark fruits, and something akin to powdered cocoa. Medium bodied and loaded with carbonation. Flavors of sweet malts, hazelnuts, dark fruits, chocolate. The addition of the hazelnut extract makes for a nice spritz to a brown ale! This would pair well with a juicy steak or better off as a dessert brew.
cerveza limpia,poca retención aromas a nueces que van ganando con el tiempo,poco lúpulo,pero muy interesante.me ha gustado tanto que he repetido 4 veces!gracias Robert!

Bottle poured into a tulip glass. This is a fantastic brew from Rogue! The hazelnut is very unique, and what a great idea! Pours a dark brown/amber color with a 1" head that melts away to slight lacing. Medium to light carbonation. Mouthfeel is light. The nose on this is fantastic! Obviously big on the hazelnut, bread, vanilla, earthy. Great fall beer! Very smooth and very drinkable.

([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, rated 2011-07-29) Clear, dark reddish brown with a small, partly lasting head. Neutral-caramely, toffeeish and slightly berryish nose with nutty-aromatic hops. Flavor is smooth and caramely, with aged-feeling nuttiness - maybe the hazelnut, then. Medium body, quite soft and creamy palate. Weak.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a New Belgium globe. 

Appearance: Pours a very dark caramel brown with yellow-orange highlights and a 2 finger creamy light tan head which dissipates into fairly large bubbles. Nice lacing.

Smell: Roasted hazelnuts and and caramel with a touch of vanilla and butter layered on top of the mild mustiness I usually get from a brown ale. 

Taste: Vanilla up front followed by hazelnut and sweet malt before ending with mildly bitter hops. Aftertaste is a mix of nuttiness and bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation. Very smooth.

Drinkability: High drinkability. Finishing a bomber by yourself will be no problem.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. The hazelnut really adds a nice character to the brown ale style. Id recommend giving this one a try.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2015 [August 24, 2011] On tap at the Nook. Pours dark brown with very little head. The aroma is hazelnuts, pecans, caramel, toffee, and a little roasted malts. The flavor is very sweet and nutty, with a little bitterness throughout. The palate is medium to heavy, syrupy, and surprisingly lively and bubbly. Overall, this is a flavorful and easy drinking beer.[August 15, 2015] 22 oz. bottle, brought camping by Carlson. Strong nose of peanuts and hazelnuts, with some maple syrup. Cloyingly sweet flavor. Tasty, but lacking balance.

Pours clear brown with ruby tinge. Head is light tan and carries a decent lace and 1/4" cap. Big hazelnuts, some flour, dark malts, caramel and bready grains. Med-light body, med carbonation. Complex malty grainy flavour with a touch chocolate. Heavier finish than initial med-light mouthfeel with caramel and dark malts with a touch of toast and hop flavour lingering. Nice, satisfying, complex.

Absolutely a stunning beer... the nose is pure hazelnut but is significantly lighter in flavor than you would expect from something with such rich profiles. I would drink this again and again. My only negative was the slight bitter aftertaste, which is seriously not enough for me to leave it out of the cart.
Pours a nice caramel brown. The hazelnut flavor is very much prevalent. Aftertaste has a bit of coffee/caramel flavor. Overall a pretty good ale, although it could be a bit thicker.

Pours a dark caramel color.  Smells like brown sugar and malt.  Taste is nice with lots of with hazelnut and chocolate.  Really thin body, and low carbonation.  I didnt get much of an aftertaste besides really light bitterness.  I feel like Rogue could have made this beer awesome, but they made it too thin and watery.

Bottle at home bought from the Great British Beer Festival 2011.  Dark red/brown ale with a nicely formed brown head.  Lovely nutty, rich brown ale.  Lightly roasted nut aroma, very nice.  Bit of a one trick pony though and lacks the complexity of some other beers.  Pretty good.
UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 Whew! This one has a hell of an awesome long aftertaste. I couldnt tell a hazelnut from a pecan before this, but I think now I could!

Tap @ Beer Temple. Brown-red color, off white to beige head (not much of it). Malty & grainy aroma, with a lot of hazelnut and some red fruit. Flavor is only slightly sweet and very nutty. Nuttiness remains in the finish. OK.

On tap at Beer Temple. Clear brown colour, off white head. Aroma of some coffee, nuts, chocolate, toffee. Flavour is sweet, malty, nutty, toffee, light coffee, light hoppy bitter finish. Light to medium bodied. OK.

650 ml bottle from A Tutta Birra. Served into a big wine glass. Poured a wonderful clear amber colour, with a creamy light beige head. Nice lacing on the glass. Lovely aroma of hazelnut, light roasted malts, coffe beans, and I also get a little bit of cinnamon. Very nutty taste, caramel, strong malt presence and some hops. Light bitterness and light carbonation, medium body, oily texture and slightly sweet finish. Nice!

(Draught at Pikkulintu, 20110730) The beer poured brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, fresh malts, chocolate and hops. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, chocolate, fresh malts, sweetness, hops and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. Tasty but a bit too sweet.

Bottle 65 cl, Kris Wines London. Pours clear red amber with a huge creamy beige head leaving lace. Aroma is sweet, nutty, malty and acidy. Flavor as aroma also fruity, miss hoppyness. Finishes acidy fruity and nutty.

Rich almost glowing brown, small yellow white head diminishes quickly. Aroma of burnt caramel (not in a bad way), roasted chestnut, mocha, toffee, cookie dough.  Taste is like eating a bowl of over-roasted nuts, a chocolate bar and chewing toffee. Palate is oily and round with a moist nutty finish. Great beer.

Draught @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu
Yeasty, malty and floury aroma, just like an yeast bread. Some hints of nuts too. Flavour of milk chocolate, some nuts and slightly sweet malt. Might have been placebo, but my hazelnut allergy raised his head a bit. Nice one, the chocolate fits perfectly.

Draught @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours reddish brown with a small head. Aroma has notes of nuts, hops and malts. Taste is slightly malty with notes of hops, nuts and caramel. Smooth, a bit sticky finish. Okay, quite well balanced brown ale.

I love this one.  Wonderful bubby dark brown pour, thin head.  Nose is full on nuttiness. Palate is great, malty, a little dark chocolate, and a touch of hazelnut,  but not too much, a great balance. This is one of the best nut browns Ive ever had.

Malty and nutty in aroma, thankfully not too heavy on the hazelnuts or as artificial as others in the style are.  The flavor is of several different types of nuts, with some almond showing through, while the body is nice and thick.  A very good brown ale, nutty but not too much with the hazelnuts and has a very good maltiness that makes it among the best in the style.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2011 Pours a perfect brown, full of bubbles and a thin head. Aromas are sweet of hazelnut, chocolate and hops with a nutty scent that lingers. The taste is almost perfect, nice and roasty with notes of chocolate and hazelnut all around. Finishes bitter-sweet from the hops with some molasses and spices bouncing around the palate. I am really loving this one :-).

Oh yeahhhh. The aroma is....well.....hazelnut.  Pours deep brown with a red translucent tint. The head is thick and oily, but quickly dissipates (from a 22 ounce bottle). The taste Is not quite as strong as I hoped, but still is full of flavor.....a nutty hazelnutty flavor. Definitely a beer worth trying and retrying....just wish it wasnt six bucks.

Draft at Dexters.  Deep, filtered orange-brown color.  Steady, oily, patchy head.  Nutty, burnt toffee aroma.  I hadnt had this one for years, and found it to be a pleasant beer to rediscover.  Smooth and medium bodied, with a pronounced nuttiness.  Mellowed soapy hops, just enough to balance it out.  Excelllent, fresh, spot on Nut Brown.

22oz bomber pours out nice amber brown color with little to no head at all. aroma of hazelnut very prevelant and very tasty with a touch of caramel. has decent malty flavor but overall brew is light to the feel. very drinkable though and have a couple more stashed away.
Pours A dark caramel brown with an off white head. Nose of toast, caramel and hazelnuts. Sweet malty taste backed up by hazelnut. Very good for the style.

Bomber. Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Light caramel brown/cola with amber tinge.
Head is light tan, 2 fingers, creamy, with medium length retention. 

AROMA: Lightly toasted malts (i.e., zero roast or coffee-like character; rather more like Wheaties cereal), wheat bread, grain. Cereal notes are predominant. Hazelnut notes are fairly light.
Hints of toffee, metallic character. 

TASTE: Wheat bran cereal, dark grains, some metallic character. Hazelnut is even fainter than on nose. 

MOUTH FEEL: Pleasant carbonation. Subtle hop (which appear spicy/earthy) and roast malt bitterness on finish. Thinner side of medium bodied. Nice drinkability. 

OVERALL: Predominant notes include dark cereal grain and some metallic character. Slightly let down. Was hoping for more discernible hazelnut character, as well as perhaps a tiny bit more chocolate malt notes  i.e., more Nutella-like character.

This one is all roasty nutty malts, no hop bitterness to balance it out.
Nice enough, soft, smooth and creamy, caramel and some chocolate,
but the sweetness gets a bit much.
Pours brown with a tan head.  Smells nutty with some chocolatey hints.  Tastes of chocolate, some dark fruity hints, nutty with some sweet molasses hints on the finish.
Tap. Rating #1638. Dark brown with a light tan head. Light toasty nutty aroma. Sweet hazelnut flavor, I almost mistakes it for butter at first, light toast, not too bad. (1725)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle. Poured a nice rich clear medium to dark brown with an average sized light brown head that was mostly diminishing leaving just a little residue hanging around allowing for good lacing. The aroma was of a nutty caramel malt and a doughy yeast with a nice note of hazelnut, brown sugar and a ever so light touch of coffee. It tasted lightly sweet with hints of caramel and coffee in the beginning. Then it matured into a very malty-nutty flavor with the hazelnut being the most pronounced at the finish, although the flavor could of lasted a little longer on the taste buds. Mouthfeel was medium in body and creamy yet slightly watery in texture as alot of brown ales can be with the carbonation being  ever so perfectly soft. Overall a very nice malty nut brown ale, this happens to be my favorite style and this brew fits it very well indeed.

Tap @Cheeky monk, Denver doing the oyster event. Pours deep ebony with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, milk. Taste is caramel, nuts, sweet milk chocolate, sweet fruit, strawberries. Medium body, soft carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. 130411

Had this on 5/3/11 on tap at The Union in Athens, Ohio.  I pours an amber color with a medium head.  I thought this beer smelled a bit like fish.  It was a well rounded beer with a clean finish.  The Union isnt the best place to be rating a beer and Im not 100% sure I can attribute the fish odor to the beer.  I enjoyed this beer and would have it again.
This is a pretty good nut brown. However by the name I was expecting more.   I couldnt taste hazelnut

Light brown with a mahogany tint and a two-finger, off-white head.

Aroma is a standard brown ale.  Sweet malts, caramel and sugar with a bit of yeast.

Taste is very sweet right away.  Interesting.  I get the nectar label.  Its very sweet not in a cloying barley way but almost in a juice or dessert way.  The hazelnut is obvious but subtle and adds a nice accent to a solid brown ale.

Pint pour @ Clark Street Ale House. Dark bronw color with small head and lace. Aroma is hazelnut and malty with vanilla tones. Rich malty flavor with strong tones of hazelnut and lighter tones of traditional nuttieness. Creamy mouthfeel, but perhaps a bit thin. Very light bitterness in the finish.

Dark maroon in color with an off white head. Good lacing. Hazelnut aroma. Caramel and chocolate also in the aroma. Hint of hazelnut in the flavor. Roasted malts. Faint nutty flavor. Oily in the texture with average carbonation. Has a very smooth finish. Overall i liked it and would have again.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2013 75cl bottle shared with 2 friends.
Ok white head. Brown colour.  Nutty flavour.

Very tasty beer. Poured from a 22 oz bottle it has a dark brown color with a nice head. Aroma is sweet with a hint of nuts and chocolate. The beer is very smooth with the hazlenut dominating the taste. There is also some raisins and licorice that come through. Long finish.

The aroma is completely outrageous. lts so good. This pours deep brown and has a perfect head. The taste is really nutty and caramelly. Sweet and dry at the same time. a great brew. You like malts...youll love this.

on tap at the Saucer Little Rock, pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is strong coffee and roasted malts.  Flavor is rich and very malt forward, chocolate, coffee, almond paste.  Very nice beer.

his beer is amazing. Has a very creamy and sweet aroma with the hazelnut hitting right at the end. It is not very sweet though there are a lot of sweet flavors. It is very balanced and it is very smooth. Dark in color.Lightly carbonated and creamy. Flavors of vanilla, honey and hazelnut. But again, it is not too sweet. I hope that some of you will not avoid it because you would think it is too sweet. Not the case, in my opinion at least. You still feel like you are drinking a dark beer.

Poured on draft into a tiny plastic lager mug at Brew Fest in Athens, GA.  Among the many pleasant sips at the event, this was one of the biggest surprises. I have long taken Rogue for granted - who among us has not? - and it has been years since I had this one. It holds up surprisingly well, even among the crazy big boys at a brew fest, with notes of nut skins, meaty hazelnuts, and even a whiff of coffee/chicory accompanying - rather than competing with - the brown ale malts. A sessionable treat.

Poured from a bottle medium/high head.  Smells a hint of chocolate.  very dark  auburn. Tastes a little flat.  Tastes of nuts and malts with slight burnt notes.  Not my favorite style , but it is smooth.
on tap.  pours a see through brown color.  Smell is sweet and crisp.  The taste is a little nutty with a sweet after taste.  Nice tasting beer overall

Original and outstanding!  Generous ivory head, good lacing.  Taste is of malt and cereal, balanced by clean bitterness, finished with a slightly bitter buttery hazelnut.  The finish lingers beautifully.  An exceptional brew.

Rogue Hazelnut Brown Nectar is a clear, red-brown ale with a yellowish white head that vanishes quickly.  It has a nutty aroma thats a touch sweet.  Its light and lively on the tongue.  It leaves the mouth a little chalky and numb.  It has lots of hazelnut flavor, not sweet nor dry.  There is just enough bitterness to make it drinkable.  Theres a huge hazelnut aftertaste.  It really delivers the hazelnut, but its quite a stretch to call it a "nectar".  This is OK, but mildly disappointing by Rogue standards.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2011 Tried this on tap at Thirsty Monk in Asheville.   Drinks exactly like the description says.  Dark but not heavy and they werent lying about the hazelnut.  Smooth, sweet deliciousness.

Bottle. Nutty hazelnut and milk chocolate aromas. Some burnt almonds and light coffee. Really nice aroma albeit a bit weak. Taste is similar to nutella, but in a good way...yes thats possible but only here. More burnt flavors come out in the taste. Some lingering bitterness complements a nice malty backbone. Maybe a bit too carbonated, but still pretty decent.

Amazing in the bottle but the best on tap. Great hazlenut taste with an amazingly long finish. A touch of bitterness adds a little bit of complexity to the oh so tasty brew, but nothing over the top. Overall, the best brown ale I have ever had.

On tap at the Ginger Man Dallas. It pours dark chestnut with a reddish hue and a thin beige head. The nose is nut, wood, caramel and chocolate. The taste is hazelnut, dark chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, wood, quite chewy and ends rather shortly with a light bitter dryness. The balance between sweet and bitter is well executed. Quite enjoyable now and then, but I couldnt drink a lot of this.

Nose is a delicious syrup and almond.  Pours a chestnut with a beige head.  Medium-light on the tongue starting with a slight nip of fruit cake and nettles.  Smooth moving through the body with some copper tones and completing the medley with apricot, hazelnut, walnut and a hint of brown sugar.

22 oz bottle. Dark amber color. Little white head that left solid lacing. Let the glass warm as the aroma isnt as fragrant when its cold. Aroma is of roasted malt and sweet hazelnut. It reminds me of hot hazelnut coffee in the morning. My mouth waters from the aroma.  Taste is much of the same as the aroma, but not as sweet as coffee. There also is a hint of sweet grain. Full mouthfeel and carbonated. It leaves a tingle on your tongue in the finish which leaves your mouth watering for more. I like the sweet flavorable beers and this is good! My first Rouge brew, looking forward to another style. Pick up a bottle if you get a chance, you wont be sorry.

651mL thanks to tastybeer. He brought it to share but we drank it without him. The pour is a hazy light brown/iced tea color with not much of a yellowish head. No retention. Aroma is heavy Frangelico and cranberry. Taste creates the illusion of something very rich within a thin, watery body: heavy hazelnut/Frangelico, cranberry, red velvet cake, but then there is lemon iced tea. Diacetyl actually comes through to create quite the thin yet buttery palate. I can see a lot of people loving this beer because it has a lot of flavor not seen in brown ales that blend nicely. But the base beer is your typical Rogue mediocrity. So interesting flavors? Yes. Brewing basics? No.

Bottle.  Dark amber color with a foamy off white head. Great hazelnut aroma with hints of brown sugar and vanilla.  Malty flavor with sweet hazelnut, and hints of honey.  Creamy texture with perfect carbonation.  All around great brew thats a must try in my book...unless you hate hazelnut.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Amber colour, fluffy off-white head. Aroma is caramel, sweet hazelnut, bit of hops. Flavour is sweet malty, nutty, bit of citrus, caramel, slight roastiness. Medium cabonated with a fairly sweet finish.

Pours a beautiful brown/copper color, nice light tan head that hangs around.  The aroma is amazing.  Caramel, bread, nuts, just amazing.  The flavor is very similar to the aroma, not quite as strong as I was expecting based off how strong the aroma is.  Very malty with caramel overtones, just a hint of bitterness.  A very good beer, i just wish it had a tad more body.  Not enough people makes browns in my opinion.  I will be buying more of this
650 mL bottle in a shaker.  Amber pour with thin tan head.  Sweet aroma.  Bitter sweet hop flavor.  Thin watery mouth feel.  Not as good as I was expecting, but not bad.  Thought it would be heavier.
This rogue is a tasty beer. dark brown in color. It has a good sweetness to it. Some roasted malt flavors some nuttiness also. Finishes with the Hazelnut flavor. A beer you can indulge in.
hazelnut flavor really works here, complements the brown ale malts very well, recommended

Very, very nice amber/brown color with an off white head that was creamy and full.  More than adequate retention with some very nice lacing to follow.  The beer is somewhat hazy with some orange highlights around the bottom and sides of the glass.  Very nice roasted hazelnut smell.  Deep and toasty.  A tremendous fragrance of a woody almond and walnut.  Traces of caramel add a touch of sweetness to the aroma.  This brew smells incredible.  I almost detect a brown sugar and hints of butter.  This is beautifully put together.  Full flavors of the roasted, toasted hazelnut and walnut.  Some suggestions of bitterness, but not intimidating.  Some slight warmth, but no real traces of alcohol.  Some touches of butter and caramel.  Properly balanced.  I even got some very faint chocolate.  Medium mouthfeel.  Smooth, slick and crisp.  Left proper amounts on the palate.  Not an over abundance, but nicely comfortable and mostly dry.  This is a pleasing and proper brown ale.  Wonderful aroma and flavor.  Very easy to drink.  It could be drunk year round.  The fragrance of this beer is the star of the show.  I kept sniffing it because it smelled so, so good.  In my opinion, how a Brown Ale should be and should be compared.  More than adequate in other categories also.  Most definitely one that I will pick up again.

22oz bottle. Pours a see through, bright ruby brown body with a fizzy, light brown, finger-width head that dissipates slowly and remains lightly laced and swirly. Aroma is mainly sweet dark malts. Very nutty and malty. Some roasted and toasty grains, hazelnut, caramel and toffee, and a bit of dried fruit. Flavor is very clean. Sweet malts and a roast backing with lots of nuttiness, sweet hazelnut flavoring, and vanilla. Finishes smooth and creamy with a faint roasty bitterness that lingers with a touch of hazelnut. Soft, full bodied, and again...clean. Overall, I love this beer

650ml bottle.  Beer is a transparent dark amber color with a small off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, of hazelnuts and caramel malts.  To be honest it smelled like capn crunch cereal.  Flavor is a little sweet, a little bitter, has a dry finish.  Not very flavorful.  Medium bodied, oily mouthfeel.  Im not too big a fan of this one.
Pours a nice brown with a pretty thick head.  Nice smooth aroma of malt and cream.  Taste is smooth malt, but not really that exciting.

Pours a light brown with an off white head. Aroma isnt as big as I was expecting which isnt a bad thing. A small nutty aroma with light malts underlying it. A nice simple nose. Taste is much more than the aroma. Big hazelnut burst with an underlying chocolate coating. Fantastic ! The wise words of Nick sum it up perfectly; "tastes like cadbury hazelnut milk chocolate melting in your mouth"

On tap. 
Deep brown color with aromas of hazlenut and malt.  Incredible clean flavor - lots of hazlenut and spicyness. The first time I had this it was 10am at my favorite pub watching a world cup game and enjoying some chicken and waffles. Yeah, it was awesome.

Sampled at Denver Winter Brewfest 2011.  Clearish brown, almost dark reddish amber.  Smell doesnt hit too hard on the hazelnut, which is a small shame, but only hints at the force of flavor to come.  Aroma has lots of chocolate, though; smells "creamy".  Taste hits hard with hazelnut, with some pale milk chocolate around it like a candy coating.  Amazing taste.  Unlike any beer I have ever had, and definitely the best Brown.

(null)
Malt: caramel, bread, nuts
Hops: floral
Other: honey
Color: brown
Liquid: clear
Head: minimal
Initial: light sweetness
Finish: light sweetness
Finish Duration: average
Body: light
Texture: thin
Carbonation: average

Rogue HazelNut Brown Nectar (aka Bald Guy Brown) pours a hazy brown and develops a one finger foamy tan head. Retention was noticeably short and lacing was absent.

The aroma is dominated by hazelnut and general "nutiness". I pick up on a mild chocolate smell and a bit of brown sugar which is likely the sweetness from the malts coming through. It is not a very complex nose but it is well balanced.

The taste echoes the aroma and is also dominated by hazelnut with an understated chocolate flavor. The beer is very sweet (maybe too sweet for some tastes?). The taste is great but the sheer power of the hazelnut is distracting and makes isolating other flavors difficult. I found as the beer warmed slightly that the hazelnut became less overpowering. At this point the beer shined as more of a quality brown ale. 

The mouthfeel is creamy but with high carbonation. When holding the beer in the mouth longer to pick up on the flavors you get a pretty tingly tongue.

This was a fairly one-dimensional beer albeit a very enjoyable one.

I was surprised by the great balance and flavor of this beer. It has turned out to be one of my favorites because its not too sweet nor too dull. I like drinking it alone just because of its great flavor but have also enjoyed with an oatmeal cookie or a bratwurst.
Deep Amber color with white head.  Caramel, nutty, bready aroma.  Medium sweetness, finishes with mild bitterness.  Creamy palate.

Bottled.  A deep chestnut brown coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing.  Chocolate and nut notes throughout, with woody notes to boot.  Pleasant hops at the back.  The chocolate and nuts really work nicely and theres a sweet syrupy feel to it.  Tasty.

Rogue HazelNut Brown Nectar. On tap at Yardhouse Chino. This beer pours out a clear brown with a thick tan head. The aroma stand s out as nutty. Its the initial smell and its the strongest aspect of the drink. You can also smell notes of toffee, malts and chocolate. The hazelnut flavor dominates the beer and is carried well by the creamy body. Theres a sweetness to the beer also brought upon by the malts but never overpowers the brew.
Best Brew ever son. I love this beer. It pours dark brown into a frosty glass and bam hits the taste bud like a hazlenutty beer from the gods.
Poured from 22oz bomber, pours a dark brown with a nice off white head,  aroma is sweet with malt with nice touches of chocolate, flavor is smooth with the malt with a nutty finish, not bad.

Pours dark brown with a rich foamy tan head.  Toasted Malt and Nut Aroma.  Malty with a slightly bitter backbone enough to offset the sweetness.  Ends on a toasted hazelnut note.  It almost tastes like you have eaten a hazelnut.  Very good example of a flavored brown.  Not too overdone.
Orange-light brown in color... Smells frangelico, very prominent hazelnut aroma... Flavor is sweet and malty, notes of hazelnut throughout, very light body, very easy to drink... Great beer

This was a very sweet beer, the first taste was sweet followed by a hazelnut flavor which is also prominent in the beers aroma. Overall this beer was a little too sweet with  little balance of malts or hops
Pours a smooth brown with little foam. Smells sweet. Tastes sweet and smooth with definite hazelnut notes. Finishes sweet.
One of my favourite beers, the hazelnut nectar is a delight to drink. Sweet and caramelly with a real nutty, fruity flavour

Wow. Pours a dark brown, almost completely opaque. Head is surprisingly light in color and density. Aroma is dominated by the chocolate and hazelnut. Also a touch of fruit. Taste is also owned by the hazelnut and chocolate tastes. Theres also just a touch of dry hoppy bitterness and some vanilla. Tasty experience.

Bottle; Pour is a clear amber/brown with a nice beige head - decent retention , and light lacing on this one. Aromas are frankly hazelnut and cocoa - but the hazelnut overpowers. Body is light, typical of rogue - I only say that because I prefer a heavier body in my brews. Flavors are again, big hazelnut, a bit of creaminess from the head, a touch cocoa, a touch of honey, and light bitterness but predominately sweetness overall. The Hazelnut does seem a bit artificial to me, but who am I.

Pours brown with a slight off white head. Smell is nearly completely hazelnut. Taste is a bit sweet and very much of hazelnut. Very tasty, slightly one dimensional, however it is still a very good beer.
Full of flavor and very smooth brown ale.  Not a big fan of the logo on the bottle and I wish I could find it in small bottles.  Love it when I find it.
Pours brown and hints of amber and a small tan head. Nose is cocoa, hazelnut, brown sugar and light bready malts. Full in mouth fell and a very easy drinker.

On tap at Waikikis Yard House.  Pours a burnt reddish color.  No lacing.  Aroma is nutty... with some coconut, which might be because Im in Hawaii. Thin and alittle stick in the mouth.  Taste is...guess...hazelnut -- plus brown sugar.  Great taste!

Bottle. Pours reddish brown. Nose of hazelnut, malts, light chocolate and brown sugar. Taste is full of hazelnuts, some chocolate malt, vanilla and brown sugar. Mouth feel is thin and watery at times.

This is where the founders and Thunder are going to have agree to disagree and by that I mean we will override his every opinion.  The founding Mikes think this is an outstanding beer, loaded with delicious flavor.  A little light on the palate, but otherwise really good.  Thunder was a little less excited.  We have decided to omitt a homoerotic reference to sausage and nuts.   Feel free to insert your own joke here.

~3 of 13

A: Pours a nice, medium slightly-hazed brown with a fairly-nice off-white head.

S: Definite nuttiness comes through along with some sweet malt; not terribly complex, but a really nice balance. A bit of caramel and toffee in the background.

T: Again, loads of nuts coming here. A bit distracting and not quite as clean as the nose was. This is definitely a bit one-dimensional, but not bad by any means.

M: Very nice and creamy. The nut flavors work well with the sweetness.

D: All a bit too much hazelnut, detracting a bit from the ultimate drinkability of this one, along the same lines as their Chocolate Stout.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-05-2010

22 oz. bottle The color is a dark hazy brown with a thin beige head. The aroma is of toffee mixed with coffee. The taste is nutty, malty and added toffee with a hint of honey. Very strong taste, very good and enjoyable.
Bottle pours burnt copper with a tan head. Aroma shows hazelnut, toffee and vanilla. Flavor shows basically the same.  Pretty easy drinking.

Pours brown with a slight red tint and a thin white head. Aroma is extremely heavy on the hazelnut with a slight amount of hops in the background. Taste is hazelnut at first with a nice blend of bitter hops and just a touch of sweetness. Very well balanced brown ale.

Clear and brown, good tan head.  Aroma is a nutty cocoa concoction.   The taste has some pecan shell flavor to it - right along with the malt and a softness that probably comes from not much hops.  A good gentle brew.

Good brown ale. Beautiful apperance! A dark malty brown with a dark tan/brown head. Smooth, light hazelnut flavoring. Hazelnut is a tough flavor for me to put my finger on, if it wasnt in the name I would have trouble pinpointing what the flavor is. This is a personal problem though, not the beer ;)

650 mL bottle at Belgo Brasserie in Calgary, served in a branded shaker glass. Pours clear dark amber with a small tan head. The head fades quickly to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of loose lace. On the nose, there are big aromas of roasted malt and hazelnut, along with caramel, fresh resinous hops and a touch of chocolate. The finish is moderate in length and fairly malty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice nut brown ale. The hazelnut is very prominent, but it is complemented by a nice roasted maltiness. It is a malty brew, but well balanced with a slightly sharp hop accent. Very well done, and one I look forward to trying again. 2010-11-18

On tap.. severed in a snifter. Color is a semi clear/ brown, amber color. No head to speak of. The aroma is smooth, nutty, caramel malt  that is delightful. Almost like a eggnog/ nutmeg smell.  The hazelnut comes through all the way but is not overpowering. The mouth feel is like a normal brown ale, yet very crisp in the finish. It has a lingering hoppy bitterness right at the end. It makes your mouth water a bit. You get a tingle on your your tongue, seconds after your finish it.  Not a bad aspect to say about this brew.
I cant drink any other brown ale with satisfaction because this one casts a big shadow.

Pours a hazy brown-orange with a thing off-white head. Aroma of nuts, toffee and some chocolate. Flavor is sweet toffee, hazelnut, a slight hint of chocolate, and some bitterness from the hops. Smooth all the way through the drink with a pleasant aftertaste. Great brown ale.

Bomber from BevMo purchased more than a year ago ($5.89).  Pours a brewed tea color of brown with one finger of beige head.  Aroma has a distinct hazelnut latte note as well as caramel, nuts, and toast.  Flavor is initially roasty-malty-caramel but the hazelnut picks up in the middle and continues right to the end.  Also has notes of chocolate, vanilla, and even some butterscotch.  There is some nice tangy hazelnut lingering in the finish.  Fortunately this is not overly sweet at all.  I quite like hazelnut, so I think I am predisposed to liking this brew.  Very different and very drinkable.  (1569, 422)

It pours a nice light brown color with a tan fluffy head. It has a medium amount of carbonation.

On the nose there is some nice carmel and some good nuts.

The flavor is just something I can never get sick of. You taste pretty much what you smell. There is good solid carmel notes and nut in there. There is some light chocolate even a little toffee as well. But its defiantly a beer that gets better as it gets warmer.

It finishes with just a slight bitterness. But very smooth and satisfying beer This is hands down one of the best browns I have had to date. I cant say it enough Rogue never fails to disappoint.
Tap at Drakes Tavern. Rich copper color. Aroma and taste are a hearty but smooth malt. Small head. Decent but not outstanding.

22oz bomber from Central Market.  Pours a deep, hazy brown body with some dense, off-white head leaving a bit of lacing on the glass.  Aromas of nutty malts, grassy hops, toffee and just a bit of chocolate showing through.  Flavors are same nutty (hazelnut I suppose), toffee, roasty and light to medium sweetness (carmelized sugars).  Medium, short bitter finish.

22oz bottle. Pours a reddish brown with no head. Smells like sweet, nutty toffee. Taste is sweet toffee-flavored malts, light chocolate and bread. A little watery. Lower than average carbonation. Pretty tasty.

Good head on the pour, large bubbles, but the last of it lingers.  Brown, but not really dark, Light aroma, a bit of nuttiness on it.  The hazelnut flavor blends well with the malt (I love hazelnut too), and the flavor lingers a long time after swallowing.  There is a lot of flavor too, though some of that is filled by the hazelnut.  This has been my favorite beer for a while.

Pours a hazy reddish brown.  Thin beige head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is caramel, hazelnut and vanilla.  Flavor is very sweet and nutty, with lots of crystal malt and hazelnut.  Its like a beer mixed with a couple shots of that hazelnut flavored syrup you can add to your coffee.  Medium mouthfeel and a lingering sweetness in the finish.  I admit that hazelnut isnt my favorite flavor and this was a little sweet for my taste.  But overall, very solid.

Bottle consumed during Online Birthday Party, October 16th, 2010. This was the final and best beer of the night. Brown with a beige head. At first the aroma seemed vegetal, but it resolved itself into a wonderful, comforting treacle sponge and custard dessert. The delicious malty, nutty flavour was, despite the beers name, oddly surprising. Something worried me about the mention of hazelnut extract.  If this were Belgium, surely the hazelnuts would have been freshly gathered and macerated for months. But the taste is, to be frank, absolutely marvellous: smooth, satisfying and full of malt as well as the nuts. Some bitterness. 22 oz of sheer beery pleasure.

Pours brown with ruby highlights and a thick, quickly fading light tan head.
Nose shows rich toasty and nutty malt with unmistakeable sweet hazelnut also quite prominent.
Similar flavours, very soft and easy-going with little bitterness in the finish.
Carbonation is a little high.

Flight sample at Morimoto. Pours a clear amber brown with a thin offwhite head and some slight lace. Aroma of Nutella, fresh roasted hazelnut, toasty malts, coffee and cream, and some barley. Medium bodied with a light, sweet, nutty palate. Finishes with some earthy soil notes and a great creamy nutiness. Excellent brown ale.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2013 Tasted in a bomber purchased in Denver, Colorado.  Pours a medium brown body with a brown-creamy head.  Strong hazelnut flavor and very smooth.  Not too creamy but very tasty!  One of my favorite brown ales.

Murky brownish red with a tan head that lasts a couple of minutes.  A very pleasant bouquet is nutty, fruity hops, and just a bit of coffee.  The nuts really shine in the flavor and they mix beautifully with cocoa, coffee, and some very gentle fruit.  Rogue outdid themselves here.

Tap.  Nice light brown pour with mocha head.  Nuts, coffee, chocolate.  Has the typical Rogue powder like touch in the mouth that adds finess and balance.  A very nice beer that could be matched with anything or could be enjoyed alone.  Highly recommended.

Beautiful, opaque dark brown with a tan head. Smells strongly of hazelnuts. Tastes of malts and hazelnuts. Nice medium body with low carbonation. Good, the hazelnut is a bit strong at first, but it finishes nicely.

malt and nut aroma.  tastes of caramel, coffee and nuts.  This is easily the best brown I have ever had.  The hazelnut flavour is quite strong and this pairs very well with this style of beer.  definitely on my "to try again" list.
Tap at brew battle, small tasting glass, dark mahogany pour with moderate head. Really picked up on the hazelnut which added character without overwhelming the beer.

I was recommended this beer by a guy at World Market and he said it was a warm and rich brown ale. To say that if i described this beer as an average HONEY brown would be a disgrace to JW Dundees. NOT good at all and i have no flavor description because it lacks that much flavor
This brown ale, served on draft, came off as no more than "average" - maybe just an off day for the taster.
Pours dark brown with tan head and some lacing.  Notes of chocolate and raisins.  Taste is well balanced and smooth.  Sessionable.

Aroma is very nutty.  And not just hazelnut.  Some brazil nut and macadamia with a touch of citrus.  Head didnt stick around long and the beer is more carbonated than I expected.  The taste is toasty, hazelnut and chocolate with a bit of a bitter finish.  I would have rated this beer higher if it had been a touch creamier and less carbonated, even though it is not as "in the style" of the beer.
I really liked this beer...malt had a taste of hazelnut with a hint of citrus...nice finish

Bottle. One of my favorite Rogue brews.. Apparently I resemble to dude on the front..  Pours a dark red/brown color with a very nutty and sweet nose.  The hazelnut is very prevalent, but not overwhelming.. definite caramel and slight chocolate in the nose.  Rich and chewy mouth which goes down super smooth. Light roasted coffee with a tinge of hop bitters. I find this to be a supremely drinkable brew.

22 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Murky brown pour with a big fluffy tan head.  Sweet hazelnut aroma, very nice.  Sweet nutty flavor, the hazelnut isnt as prominent but its there.  Finish is kind of weak but overall a pretty solid  beer.

Dark color with a rich nutty aroma. Stayed bubbly but lost its head about halfway through. Hazelnut comes through very stong in the beginning and finishes off nice and malty just like the description says.

CHOCOLATE MILK!!!!! Poured from a 22 ounce bottle into a large snifter. Color is a very dark brown color with a tan head that leaves a fair amount of lacing. Aroma is very much like chocolate milk and hazelnut. Taste is just like the smell with chocolate milk being the predominant taste but the finish is somewhat like that of the hazelnut flavoring. I love this beer! I love it even more when I find out how much it costs. For the money, this is possibly my favorite beer ever.

650ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy dark brown, with a good sized off-white head.  Aromas of cocoa, hazelnut, smoke, wood.  While it smells pretty good, theres something about it Im not really liking.  I think my nose is preparing me for a buttery taste.  Thankfully, there is no butter anywhere taste wise.  Cocoa, hazelnut, a strange faint taste of green beans, toasted bread.  Lots of toasty malt in the medium bitter finish.  Ive had this in the past, and I recall it having more flavour, but what Im drinking now is nothing to complain about.  I have been sitting on this bottle for a while though, so it could be its age coming through.  Decent stuff, and a fine effort.  (Let it breath/warm up.  It makes a huge difference.)

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Consumed with Jeff. Smooth, cloudy medium brown pour with head that sticks to the glass. Nice aroma - milk chocolate with fruity spice. First impression is bold hazelnut with a slightly burnt aftertaste. Nice.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2014 22oz bottle - Really liked this number.  High marks for aroma and taste.  Quite malty and--as advertised--hazelnut flavor does come through.  **Re-rate** Have been enjoying this for years.  Usually have something to add, especially after years since my last rating, but my initial impression is pretty much on.  Still one of my favorite treats from Rogue I pick up semi-frequently.

Poured a slightly hazy brown with a thin light-tan head.  Huge nutty aroma with roasted notes.  Taste is also very nutty with good roasted flavors.  Slightly sweet at first, but transitions into a bitter roasted finish.  Brown ale is a style that is usually overlooked, and this is a great example of a good brown ale.

large frothy light brown head. fair lacing. mostly diminishing. clear thin light brown body. moderate malt, dark chocolate, mild coffee, honey and yes: HAZELNUT! if: moderate sweet and light bitter. ff: light sweet and bitter. short duration. palate: light body, watery texture, soft carbonation and metallic finish. 
GOSTO MALTE, CAFÉ (AMARGOR), CHOCOLATE, 

Nota: 60 skol

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2010 perfect brown ale. blows the rest away. the hazelnut really comes through in the smell and the tastes is very nutty, toasty, and very drinkable.

UPDATE: on tap@ slows bbq.. WOW what a horrible disappointment! my inital bottle rating was a 4.1, but this experience was a disaster. flat, no head, and none of that taste nutty smell. not sure if this was the bars fault or what... im going to give the beer the benefit of the doubt, but still had to knock it down a couple points..

22 oz bottle: Pours a dark caramel color with a thin head and little carbonation or lacing. The aroma is malty with a nice nutty smell associated with the Hazelnut. The taste was good - very smooth with a strong hazelnut taste that lingers on your palate. Not very complex, but very balanced. Overall I did not truly enjoy this beer as the hazelnut flavor seemed forced and not natural. It is labeled as a natural hazelnut extract, but it did not leave me wanting another anytime soon.
This is a wonderful brown ale.  Pours a lovely deep brown.  Taste is rich malty goodness.  Good mouthfeel.  Not watery. Just the right consistency.  Cant wait to try other Rogue brews.
UPDATED: AUG 18, 2010 I have been drinking craft beers since they first appeared and this is my personal favorite.
10.08.05 Reddish brown med carb lasting beige head. A:Nutty, chocolaty, caramel. F:Nutty finish beer is med to full in body. It has an excellent mouth feel. Unique, glad I had it.

Flaske: Mindst holdbar til marts 2007. Har lagret fantastisk flot. Dejlig duft af portvin og karamelmalt. Der er også en anelse kaffe og chokolade. Udseendet er klassisk brown ale med en fin karbonation alderen taget i betragtning. Smagen er først kaffe og chokolade men bevæger sig over i en fin oxidation med gode portvinsnoter. Har lagret overraskende godt.
sweet brown ale with a rich hazelnut flavor. very sweet nutty rich caramel flavor. not for an every day drinker but a nice desert beer.

Bottle- pours deep amber brown with a short but well held head. Thick mouthfeel without being too heavy, which was great. Better with a slight rise in temperature, increasing in complexity. Aroma was less prevalent to me than expected, but did not take away from the body of the beer. A tasty brown ale that finishes very smooth.

At SBWF 2009. Short light brown head. Brown-amber color. The aroma is dominated by the hazelnut aroma but there is also something that reminds me of chinese cusine, some spice or flavor enhancer. Nutty taste with a small bitterness and chocolats. Strange flavour combinations in a beer, might do for a desert beer.

This beer had a strong, bitter hops aftertaste to it that seemed to mellow a little bit as I worked my way through the beer.  I didnt pick up on the hazelnut either in taste or smell.  The color was a nice deep brown and it had a creamy head.

Pours a rich brown colour with a ruby tint and medium tan head, fairly clear. Aroma is quite malty with grains, bread and of course hazelnut most pronounced. Taste is fairly malty too, nutty and bready with a long dry finish of grain and cereal. Medium body, smooth on the palate and soft carbonation. Excellent brown ale and an outstanding beer.
Poured deep red/brown with half-finger, foamy head.  Aroma is faint hazelnuts and bread.  Taste mimics the aroma.  A good brown ale.
Nice hazy dark brown pour.  Aroma is of light malt and hazelnut.  Taste is a smooth creamy hazelnut with a deep, smooth finish.  A great sipping and relaxing beer.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2010 22oz bottle, unknown date, although a recent delivery.  Pours red-copper with a one finger tan head, holds a foamy cap, short-term lacing.  Strong hazelnut aroma, very nutty, buttery, heavy toast, somewhat sweet smelling, some caramel.  A pretty unique and nice aroma.  Hazelnut also strong in the taste, maple syrup, dark bread, caramel, chocolate, some earthy hop bitterness for balance.  On the thin side, but still a bit syrupy, prickly carbonation.  The aroma is definitely my favorite aspect, solid Brown Ale overall.
Draft at Taco Mac.  Pours brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and hazelnut.  Taste is pure hazelnuts.  Taste gets better and better as it warms.  Thick mouthfeel.  Great beer.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2010 Had this one at the Bier Markt in Toronto after a great meal. Poured a brown-red colour with an off-white head, with decent retention, average lacing and not much carbonation. The nose was sweet (maple syrup, caramel) and had the regular brown ale scent with fresh dark malts. Hazelnut was light in the aromas though. Refreshing mouthfeel with a little stickiness. Oh wow ! Hazelnut is definitely present in the taste. Nutty, with a smooth aftertaste. A very nice brown ale with the touch of hazelnut extracts. Worth trying for nut brown ale lovers.

Bomber thanks to.. someone
Appearance : Deep brown, small head.

Aroma : Burnt caramel, spices, sweet. Lots of overcooked/burnt caramel.

Taste : Burnt caramel, roasty, spices with some hops. A bit bitter on the finish. Rather dry.

Overall : Taste quite bland. Interesting roasty caramel thing. Interesting beer. Probably a nice beer to match with some particular deserts.

Never have I been happier not to have a nut allergy.  Pours a luxurious deep maroon/brown with a thin, but lingering head.  Big chocolate and hazelnut aromas.  Sweet without being cloying.  Subtle but undeniable hops in there too.  This would be a very good brown ale, but the hazelnut brings it to another level.  Yum.
Draught at the new Draft House with Big Al and Lisa. Very sweet brown ale but also a touch of bitterness from some coffee and baking chocolate. Pleasant and easy drinking.
Rogue does excellent flavored beers.  This one has a nice base of maltiness that plays well with a nice and substantial hit of hazelnut.  Absolutely great as part of a beer float.

(draught at Common Table) pours deep brown with hints of rusty orange. Excellent lacing and a creamy head that lasts the duration. Nose of roasted nuts, nutella, and brown sugar. Taste of hazelnut, toastiness, dark brown sugar and cream. Very creamy mouthfeel and tons of nutty flavors hang around on the palate.
Rich brown pour with a medium head.  Sweet nutty nose.  Taste is sweet like molasses with a very subtle hop spice.  Candy sweet finish.

Verrry solid; copper pour; tase is a sweet malty; almost syrupy but not quite that sweet.  maybe a little nutty; slight bitter hop.  well rounded beer!!

will have again

Subtle hazelnut nose coming from the nice hazelnutty brown orange amber colored brew.  Foams quickly up but then goes away.  Very foamy mouthfeel.  Nothing noteworthy here for me.  I dont taste any hazelnut flavor...just a soft amber brew to me.

22oz bottle from Harris Teeter. Pours a super dark copper/reddish brown color. Little off white head that dissipates quickly. Nutty, woody, earthy aroma and a bit of sweet mixed in. More of the same in the flavor. Has a thin (watery) consistency to it. Has a nice sweet, nutty/earthy flavor to it. I typically like more of a fuller body/palate in my brews, by this has a nice flavor to it. Definitly a nice ride of flavors. Starting with the earthyiness and ending in the sweet malty range. Solid brew.
So different and so good. First time I had this was at Thanksgiving doing a blind brown ale tasting. This was the hands down winner...

22 oz. botlel. The color is a dark hazy brown with a thin beige head. The aroma is of toffe mixed with coffee. The taste is nutty, malty and added toffee with a hint of honey. Very strong taste, very good as well but not your drink every day beer.
Nutty, malty, yet dry. Was definitely expecting more of the hazelnut sweetness to come through, but the beer was quite satisfying.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a dark, woody brown with a thick tan head and a hearty, nutty, caramel aroma.  Delicious smooth, crisp but strong chocolate and hazelnut flavor up front before transitioning into a heavier, chocolate, woody, smoked finish.

Sunset Grill, Allston, pint ($5): Pours a reddish brown color with a beige head that leaves no lacing. Aroma of hazelnut, vanilla, and sugary malts. Taste is a little bit too sweet for my tastes. Lots of vanilla, lots of hazelnut. Reminds me why I never get hazelnut or vanilla or any other flavor shot in my coffee. Lingering dessert taste. Full-bodied, but not too heavy. I admit I dont like this beer very much, but that doesnt mean it is bad... the other ratings are a testament to that... but I think that the sweetness and hazelnut were overdone.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown color with a tannish head. Left plenty of lacing as it went. Aroma was nutty with caramel and molasses. Flavor was sweet. It also had a rich caramel nut taste. Longer finish. A very good beer

Dark brown pour with a foamy, 2-finger, off-white head.  Lots of toast and nuttiness in the aroma.  There is definitely a distinct note of hazelnuts and some floral clover and honey sweetness along with a bit of caramel and hay.  The hops add just a touch of spice and pepper to the nose.  The flavor again has lots of hazelnut character with hints of toast, cocoa, straw, clover honey, wild flowers, and caramel.  The body is a bit thinnish with a little too much carbonation but drinks very nicely.

On tap at Yardhouse. Opaque dark brown with a generous head and nice lacing. Strong coffee and toffee aromas with a nuttiness in the background. Sweetness of toasted malts was strong up front, with hints of hazelnut, charred wood and chocolates. Slight offsetting hops bitterness. Medium body and carbonation, and a wonderful lingering nuttiness.

Dark color with a rich nutty aroma.  Stayed bubbly but lost its head about halfway through.  Hazelnut comes through very stong in the beginning and finishes off nice and malty just like the description says.

Bomber. Transparent but hazy lighter brown with nice off white head. Aroma of caramelized almonds/pecans, maple syrup and brown sugar with notes of newspaper and specialty grain. Taste is not as sweet as smell, and has nutty malt caramel backbone going into mildly bitter finish, maltiness lingers. Crisp and bubbly on tongue.

Dark brown, caramel colored beer.  Creamy tan head that sticks around.  Nutty hop aroma, odd but not unpleasant.  Nutty flavor as well, mostly malts, bready with caramel.  Toffee and vanilla in there as well, definitely some hazelnut.  Smooth with some carbonation.  Clean finish.  Coats the mouth nicely.  Nearly full bodied.
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 Bottle from Beers of Europe. Nutty malt aroma. Deep cloudy brown with big brown frothy head. Strong flavour of coffee, nuts and chocolate. Fantastic bottle.

Bottle tasting at DLD. Youll have to forgive me for my less than thourough tasting notes... a drunk taster with a destroyed palate does not, a proficient rater, make!
  Not very impressed.  Aroma was pleasent, but the taste was far from enjoyable.  The sweet hazelnut flavor coated the throught and did not have much bitterness to balance.  Nice palate despite the taste and the head was frothy and left some lacing.  IDK, maybe Im just not a hazelnut fan.
Bottle. Brown with a honey like texture. Plenty of body with low carbonation.Left some lacing.Complex flavours which take time to fully appreciate. Nice.

A- Pretty much what a brown ale should look like. Slightly translucent medium brown colored body that pours with 1/2 finger creamy tan head. Head retention is near perfect and plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Hazelnut overpowers the smell. Mild hints of caramel and chocolate malt hide in the background.

T- Flavor is much milder than the scent. Hazelnut is still upfront but smooth chocolate and caramel malts balance in the background. Finish is consistent with the initial flavor with everything becoming more subtle for the swallow.

P- Medium-low carbonation and medium weight body. Goes down like a nice English brown.

O- This is a nice offering from Rogue. A great twist on an English Brown Ale-the hazelnut character matches the mildness of the style to take it one step farther. One I will definitely have again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-08-2007 00:51:36

Really tasty stuff.  Pours a nice brown color with a tiny white head.  Aroma is nutty sweetness, the hazelnut really comes through here.  Taste is slightly sweet with very little bitterness.  Super solid.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 Rogues Hazelnut Brown Nectar pours a deep auburn with a thick tan head. The aroma contains roasty chocolate and the bold scent of hazelnuts.  The flavor is made up of a light sweetness, medium bitterness, and a rich nuttiness.  The palate is medium bodied and slick with a fairly lively carbonation.  Overall, Rogue Hazelnut Brown Nectar is a unique and mouth watering twist on the American Brown Ale.

Pours a clear dark brown almost ruby red with a light tan head.The aroma is of brown sugar and a hint of nuts.The flavor was a nutty and sweet malt taste.The finnish was nice and smooth like a good brown ale should be.Another fine brew from Rogue ales.
Bottle. Clear red/brown colour with small creamy white modtly diminishing head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel and chocolate. Sweet flavor. Creamy palate.

650ml/22 US fl. oz bomber poured into a tulip pint glass...

Slightly hazy ruby red, brownish colour to the body. The caramel head is quite rich and frothy, leaving some pleasant lacing on the glass.

Hazelnuts is what I smelled right from the start. Some caramel, brown sugar, a faint hint of dark fruit, and some floral notes in the background. Quite a mild aroma, even for a brown ale, but its pretty good still.

This beer has got a VERY pronounced hazelnut flavour, which is excellent and makes it stand out. Not very sweet, with some bitter-sweet chocolate and toffee notes. Very subtle dark fruit notes, and a touch of oatmeal (not sure why, but I could definitely taste it). Some bitter notes in the finish.

Medium-bodied. The carbonation was kind of crisp at first, but then it mellows down. Quite smooth, even creamy. No trace of alcohol (not surprisingly).

This is a good American Brown ale. Certainly not the greatest, but the "hazelnut" component definitely did not disappoint and met all of my expectations.
On tap at the Gingerman Fort Worth.  Dark red pour with a small tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, nuts, and roasted malts.  Taste is dry, roasty, bubblegum, almost fruity, and a little nutty.

Tap at Ginger Man. Clear dark ruby pour with a small amount of head. Smells of homebrew sludge, light hops and brown malts. Sweet tea aromas also with a leafy quality. Taste is dry leaves with a teabag type characteristic. Slightly Medicinal with a large essence of vanilla? Odd but Ill go with it. Nuts on the finish. Not sure how I feel about this one.

65 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Medium brown colour, quite clear. Chocolate and caramel aroma, medium body with a very sweet flavor. Chocolate comes through more on the finish with vanilla and faint raisin.

On tap.  Pour is a deep clear brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is lots of malt, light nuttiness, and a faintly chocolate component.  Flavor is roasted caramel malt and hazelnut up front with notes of cocoa.  The finish was not great, a little yeasty/ bready likely due to an old keg or poor storage.  Overall I like it and see the potential.
