650ml bottle - LCBO. Appearance: Ruby red with a yellowing - off white head, quite frothy. Aroma: Yes - Hazelnuts, yeast, chocolate. Flavour: Malty - nutty, some slight vanilla too. Interesting. Somewhat dry finish. As it warms up I can taste the hazelnut more and more. Delicious.

650 ml bottle - pours a dark mahogany with a slightly beige head.  Aroma of nutella, some toasted malt, chocolate.  Beautiful, not cloying.  Flavour full and silky smooth - wonderful malts, milk chocolate with some dry nuttiness.  A slight oiliness as well.  Slightly bitter finish.  A beautiful, beautiful beer.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2008 650mL bomber from the LCBO. Poured a nice brownish amber with a large light mocha head. This beer smells absolutely AWESOME. One of the best smelling beers Ive ever come across. Perfect malted barley profile, bready, worty, a touch roasty, with definite nuttiness, the promised hazelnut is a main character. I could sniff this all night and be content. Flavour is really big on the nutty aspects, with a touch of vanilla being a strong tag along to the whole party. Less barley flavour than I was hoping for after the aroma, but still some decent malts in there. Minor milk chocolate, as well as maybe some rye bread. Really not much hops to speak of, and usually Im very perceptive of Saaz. The malt profile of this nectar is a pretty all-star line up, and they all blend together so seamlessly, with only the Crystals perhaps standing out a bit more than the rest. This stuff is just absolutely delicious!

Dark brown with a nice tan head that dissapates quickly. Big nutty aroma/flavour, with some nice malts and a touch of hops, bread, brown sugar and chocolate. Pretty well balanced, not overly carbonated, and leaves a nice nut and malt aftertaste. Good stuff!

Pours with a dark brown hue, with a nice light brown head that is pretty large when poured, but surely dissipates after sitting for a minute to a minute and a half. Hue is murky as well.
Aroma is of nuts, lots of nuts - it is the most dominant smell in the aroma. I can also smell hints of very light dark fruits, and some sweet malt. 
Flavor is rich and tastes of nuts - almonds and hazel nuts, wheat bread (maybe 12 grain), carmel, and maybe some coffee. 
Flavor is pretty consistent throughout - a tiny bit bitter on the finish, but to the slightest possible degree. 
Lively carbonation, with a light - light syrupy feel to the palate. 
Wow what a great beer! This is definitely worth buying again!

bomber from the LCBO. pours brown with a nice tan head that lingers and laces beautifully. aromas of nut, chocolate, sweet malts. solid flavour profile with the nut aspects working into the malt structure of a very nice brown ale. ill be back for more of this one.
Nutty malt aroma with little to no head and a solid brown color.  Rich nutty flavor of hazelnut, rye bread, and brown sugar.  Good carbonation with a mild even palate.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee (hazelnut I suppose), slight nuts.  Flavor is quite nutty (hazelnuts and walnuts) with a slight sweet malt backbone.  Good beer, interesting flavor!

650 ml bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Clear, fairly deep copper with a tan head that fades fairly quickly.
  
Aroma:  Roasted almonds and other roasted nuts, a bit chocolaty, seems quite dry.
  
Palate:  Medium-ish body with moderate-soft carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Still plenty of roasted nuts with light caramel and a hint of tang, still a touch of milk chocolate and just a hint of grassy (?) hops.

A bit heavy-handed on the nuts, kinda like my previous girlfriend...

22 oz. bottle from Sam’s Wine (South Loop, chicago, IL). Pours a deep dark tobacco-y brown with nice tan head. Aromas are lighter than expected, some chocolate that provides a touch of a bittersweet element and light nutty sweetness that balances well with the bitterness. Medium bodied, lighter than expected on the palate. Finishes with some nice chocolate and nut notes with hoppy bitterness. Pretty good. Cheers!
From bottle.  Part of a Dayton Beer Tasting July event.  Pours a cloudy brown with a small mocha head. Aroma sweet caramel and smoke.  Thinner than I expected.  The finish had a slightly bitter bite.

Pours a cloudy brown with a reddish tint when light passes through it. The head fades rather quick  but the aroma is nice and nutty with a sweet caramel sugar finish. The texture is bitter with a mild bitterness. You can really taste the hazelnut and some toasted almond. The finish has some bitter notes that stick to the sides of your mouth with a sweet caramel malt. Overall it is nice refreshing brew.

Pours auburn tending dark brown with a cream/tan coloured head. Nose has huge dry nutty characters. Peanut, hazelnut, wood its all there! Palate is more subdued than nose. Caramel malt dominates with mild nuttiness. Finishes with a touch of dry hop bitterness that adds complexity. Interesting...
Weirdo beer. Amazing nose of chocolate and nuts, hazelnuts (!) and a touch of wood. Completely seductive. Nuts front up again in the palate before some fizz and malt drive the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2009 On tap at McGloughlins in Kyoto. Deep brown and frothy. Like a chocolate hazelnut  malted milkshake. Rich, thick, creamy, and full of the flavors of nuts, caramel, chocolate, and lightly roasted dark malts. A real treat, though definitely cloying, and more than two starts to make me dizzy.

Bottle. Rogue Hazelnut Brown Nectar has a suprisingly mild nut taste. Very smooth accross the palate The best part in my opinion was the nutty aroma. Great beer but i wouldn’t go to any great lengths to get my hands on it.

Bottle. Brown with pale brown head quickly disappearing. Matly aroma, bread and nutts. Taste very malty maybe some nuts.
Another anonymus brown ale. I don´t quite understand the high ratings. I prefer Jackie Brown.

On tap at Yard House Brea; remember having this a couple years ago and not liking it; that has definitely changed.  Aroma of nuts, chocolate, caramel and butter.  Flavor was the same; sweet with buttery nuts.  Good on the palate.  Nice color.  Very good for the style.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Pours a real nice brown color with an atractive thick and tan pillowy head.  Smells of rich roasted malts, some nuts and nice chocolate.   The taste is much of the same.  The roasted malts are very prevalent, coupled with chocolate malts and a real nice nutty flavor.  The body is just a little too light., but not bad.  The finish is hoppy, yet smooth.  Its not quite as good as I remember it, yet Im surprised I still like it as much as I do.

Draught at The Flying Saucer in Nashville.  Poured a dark mahogany color with three fingers of off white head.  Aroma is of sweet malt with a faint nut aroma.  Flavor is very sweet with a strong hazelnut tone and some bitter chocolate.  Too sweet to drink more than one, but overall a solid beer.
dark brown with a medium/small head.malty aromastrong hazelnut tones in the flavorsmooth body

22oz bottle thanks to NoworkNJ. Pours clearish brown/red with a fizzy offwhite head, no lace. Smells malty and sweet with a sort of wet dog, nut flavor. Tastes sweet nutty and chocolatey. Very tasty but not sickly sweet or nutty. Medium body, semi-dry, good carbonation.

not usually a brown ale drinker or a fan of nut flavors in beer, i chose rogue’s hazelnut brown nectar on the high recommendation of my friend seth haines. immediately i notice that the ale pours very brown, cut through with deep-purplish shards of light rather than the redder, cherry cola appearance i usually notice in "brown ales." the aroma screams hazelnuts and dry, dry piecrust filling. am i drinking this or slicing into it? should i drink this alone or over vanilla bean ice cream or paired with a rich cup of coffee? before tasting this beer, it looks and smells too big to stand alone - it may need something else to help carry the burden. the first sip is all hazelnuts - huge and chattering between my teeth like squirrels swirling tree trunks in sport. second sip, and on, reveals deeper levels of sweetened chocolaty malts, coupled up and peppered with lightly spiced hops. this is an extremely large, but well balanced ale. too rich for occasional drinking, but perfect for a special occasion or celebratory evening with friends: which is exactly how i prefer most of rogue’s beers.

While I am allergic to hazelnuts, it didn’t stop me from enjoying sips of this on a couple occasions. Brown bodied with thinnish head. Hazlenut aroma reminiscent of candied popcorn, a quality that characterizes the flavor as well. Distinct nuttiness, smooth and easy malting, rather thin mouthfeel. Enjoyable in low doses though the hazlenut tastes could overstay their welcome past a glass or 2.
Ruby copper color with dense tan head.  Rich malty aroma.  Hazlenut is prominent along with the malty sweetness.  This became less enjoyable as I finished.  Too much hazelnut
The upfront hazelnut flavor is well blended with chocolate malts and light bitterness.   It’s a nut brown ale running on all cylinders.   A great beer to share with friends.

Over-carbonated hazelnut flavored soda water.  Very thin and watery for a beer of this color.  Too lively and bubbly on the tongue.  Not at al drinkable or enjoyable, this one went down the drain pretty fast.

Everything about this beer is marvelous - nutty aroma, lush, rich, smooth mouthfeel, and complex, nuanced flavors.  We love Rogue’s bigger stuff, and this is right up there with the Chocolate Stout in my book.  Just plain yummy stuff.
(Bottle).  Very sweet mocha aroma.  Dark reddish brown with a light tan head.   Flavor is sweet malty nuts.  Delicious at first, but after a few sips I found myself having had enough.

22 oz bottle.  Clear purple brown with a latte head.  Nose like a coffee ice cream shake with distinct toasted hazelnuts.  Creamy with a bubbly tang, this time reminding me of egg cream.  Taste is hazelnut and sour raisin with touches of mocha.  The nuttiness is a perfect fit for this brew.
bottle, medium amber pour, sweet nose, decent head, caramel and some fruit flavors, nice body and medium finish

For the Rogue in all of us.

Sounds like the story of my life, past, present, and future. Rogue always delivers an excellent brew, and the Hazelnut Brown Nectar is no exception. Available in a 22oz bomber, she quickly fills my glass to her very tip-top, but without overflowing.

Rich, dark brown with hints of amber showing through along the sides of the glass. A thick soft creamy head at least 2 fingers thick quickly forms, and then fades into a lush layer of creamy foam resting on top of the beer. Rich hazelnuts practically overflow from the glass and throughout the nose. Sweet malty caramel notes act as an accent to the intensely sweet roasted hazelnut aroma and palate. For such a succulently aromatic brew, the body and mouthfeel are very balanced. Neither too heavy nor too cloying. An excellent brown ale. The hazelnuts practically dance across my taste buds, sweet and nutty on the first number, then settling into a more mellow malty profile with a hint of hop bitterness in the finish. As she warms, along with the sweet roasted hazelnuts I detect a hint of oats/grain in the nose and the palate, mingling with the hazelnuts to bring an almost "breakfast" taste and aroma to the brew. I would attribute this to the oats aroma I detect. Even so, Hazelnut still goes down smooth and easy, leaving even less of a hop nip at the finish the further along in my glass I go. Fabulous.

Probably one of my favorite American brown ales, Rogue pulls off a stellar traditional and yet revolutionary interpretation of the English Brown Ale style. Easy to quaff, Ive had Rogue Hazelnut Brown Nectar both on draft and in the bottle and I can say that both stand proud.

Tasted 26/07/2008. 750ml bottle, in Invercargill, with Sam and Steve.  Bloody nutty. Almost over-the-top, like the Chocolate stout, but it is so nicely drinkable behind that nut character that it gets away with it.  Again, a perfectly conditioned Rogue ale with a kinky twist.  Sweet, a nice desert beer - hold the ice cream.

Bottle with yalnikim (in NZ), pours brown with a yellowish head. A very nutty aroma, but slightly cardboard. Man this is nutty! Drinks like liquid nutella - nutty and chocolately. Difficult to know how much I actually like this beer - but much respect to the brewer for putting this much nut flavour into a beer.
Sooooo nutty. How could not love this beer? Uses the best part of a brown with a true hazelnutness to good effect.
Thick and creamy head sits on a red/brown colored beer.  Malty sweetness with a little nuttiness.  Nutty sweetness also in the aroma.
Bomber. Aroma is hazelnuts brown sugger. Flavor was on sweet side with hazelnuts, brown sugger with malt and a touch of hops. Found it to be weak and watery. Was expecting much better.
Had this on tap. Not my type of beer. Pours a dark brown color with a nice tan head. A nutty and malty scent. A decent tasting beer, but pretty good for a brown ale.
Bottle, Pours a dark brown.  Aroma is sweet of hazelnut and nuts.  Flavor is sweet hazelnut and creamy.  Full body beer, this is a great beer.
Bottled: Pours a dark ruby brown color with a tan froathy head. Smells tastefull hazelnuts and roast, that blasts into your mouth with a full chocolaty hazelnut flavor. Good and very drinkable beer!
pours dark brown.  scent is weak, but consists of nuts and roast.  taste is very nutty and takes over the taste.  finishes quick.  I might purchase this again.

Pour is dark brown with not much aroma at all.  What little aroma there is is of light fruit and malt.  The flavor was quite the opposite with a very strong up front flavor of hazelnut.  also noticed some slight chocolate notes in the middle finishing with a dry nutty finish as well as a slight hop character.  Good brew.  May buy again.
ambrato carico nocciola al naso tostato leggero caramello nocciola schiuma media persistenza buona non molto amara sentori di nocciale corpo medio sfumature dolci un po di tostatura
Pours a dark hazelnut brown .  The nose has notes of coffee and hazelnuts. Comes across the palate with hints of hazelnut and coffee, with subtle chocolate finish. Great semi sweet winter ale.

On tap at Brigid’s Cross, nice pour of dark brown, not quite black with a thin dark tan head.  Smelled of coffee, nutty (mostly hazelnut).  Flavor of coffee and hazelnut and a finish of chocolate and malt.  Good beer, great sipper.

Pours a delectable dark hazelnut brown with a frothy light brown/tan head. Has a nice aroma of hazelnuts, hops, chocolate, and caramel. The flavor is very nut driven of hazelnuts and sort of hard to notice much else except a little caramel and perhaps a hint of chocolate. The feel is very creamy and rich. Its like a desert in a bottle. Very good balence and not to much complexity. Semi sweet. Wow I’ve never had a beer this nutty before. Well done.
Bottle.  Color is brown with hints of red.  Mostly diminishing off white head.  Good lacing.  Smells sweet and nutty.  Taste was creamy, with hints of chocolate and nuts.  Very good beer.

Bomber, no date. Is this really a winter seasonal? Pours unsurprising dark brown in which you can see red when held to the light. Aroma hints at hops, but on the tongue, its the roastiness that distinguishes. Sort of chocolatey (Nutella?). Balanced so as not to be too sweet. Body is somewhat light. Still, very tasty.

Pours ruby brown with tan head.  Hazelnut aroma with notes of maple, wood, and some slight dark fruit.  Flavor is subtle with notes of hazelnut, maple, wood, and slight roasted malt.  Palate is rich and creamy with light carbonation.

bottle thanks to Metzlers, Denton TX.  poured a clear amber/copper with tan head.  aroma was that of malt, wood, and slight nuttyness.  flavor was equally as impressive with the malt, nutty flavor and thought i picked up some dark fruit notes.  this one is good!!!

Bottle, thanks to ericandersnavy.
Pours a clear ruby brown with beige head. Aroma of maple, wood, with faint nutty notes. Flavor is semi-sweet with maple, wood, and nice hazelnut. Has medium body with medium carbonation. Very good!

Bomber.  Nutty aroma with roast malt, wood, and grain husk, a little bit of a cereal quality.  Theyre not lying, theres a lot of hazelnut here.  Ruby-brown body, dark but still translucent, with a soapy tan head.  Malty, butty, lightly sweet and only slightly bitter taste, a woody, slightly sour faint roast drying out a bit around the teeth toward the end.  Medium body, maybe even thinner with that, and a bit unbalanced - where are the hops?  The sweet nuttiness is nice here, and shes a good session, but this beer is massively overrated.

1/7/08 notes:  on tap, Yard House. Amazingly smooth, nutty and mellow brown ale. Features nutty flavors, roasted hazelnut and a bit of brown sugar.  In addition, the hops keep the flavor clean and balance the sweet.  A little light on the overall flavor, but couldve just been the tap. Still tops my list for browns.  IN BOTTLE: 4/1/08 notes:  pours a light brown with one finger head.  Soft carbonation that matches a gently nutty, malty, semi-sweet flavor.  Really enjoyed the subtlety, along with the comforting hazelnut finish.  Great beer.
pours a dark brownish color color with a head that disappears quickly. aroma is of hazelnots and caramel. has a strong hazelnut flavor

Pours opaque dark amber with a fast dissipating tan head. Aroma is intoxicating blend of the hazelnut and maple syrup. The flavor is nearly as great, nice and nutty, with a bready, toasted malt backbone. The palate is creamy and sticky. This is what a brown ale should taste like.
Dark brownish colour with disappearing head.Aroma of hazelnuts and toffee caramel.Flavor is light tosted and sweet with full body.really tasty brown ale.

1pt 6oz single from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...pours hazy brown...aroma gives a definite whiff of hazelnut with hints of chocolate and malts...flavor was nutty, chocolatey...definitely could have been a little less carbonated.

On tap at the Yardhouse in downtown San Diego.  This one was a treat.  Poured darkish brown with a fair bit of tan head.  Smelled nutty with malts and caramel in there as well.  The taste is much of the same, the caramel, hazelnuts and malts definitely shine but there is some hop character present, although very subtle.  The flavor is very complex, but not overtly so, a delight to enjoy!  I was very pleased with this beer and it is now one of my favorite brown ales.

Pours out a lovely dark brown. Nutty aromas assault my nose. Apparently I dont like hazelnuts. Tastes like a more robust version of Hales Irish Nut Brown Ale. I think I would like it better without the nuts.

Pours to a rusty brown mahogany body with a tall foamy light tan head.  The aroma is caramelized brown and crystal malts with a hazelnut thing going on in the background.  There are lots of complexities and nuances in this aroma.  Some chocolate brownies at times.  The flavor is strongly hazelnut with a bready caramel and crystal malt backbone.  Light amounts of chocolate.  Subtle hops.  One of the better brown ales Ive ever had.  The palate is only lightly astringent with a medium and drying body.  A definite delight.

Pours a shiny nut brown colour with a full tan head. Roasted nuts, butterscotch and pancakes on the nose. Full, heavy and creamy nutty flavors on the palate. Sweet chocolate cake like taste with a long toffee finish.
Pours brown with light tan head.  Tastes like a standard stout, I was expecting more hazelnut flavor though.
great brown with a nice chocolate caramel flavor, sweet aroma - hints of nuttiness, malt - full-bodied with a slightly higher alcohol than expected

Bomber. Smelled very sweet with maple, cane sugar and burnt wood in the nose. Dark, dark brown...I could see a red hue when held up to light. Very nutty, malty brew with some hops. Finishes relatively clean with just a hint of alcohol burn. Could have been just a bit thicker. Overall very good beer.

22oz bottle in an English pint.  Pours a very nice, dark brown with red hints.  Has a decent tan head, than leaves quickly.  No lacing.  Aroma of burnt wood and chocolate.  This one has a complex flavor that starts sweet with semi-sweet chocolate and roasted nuts.  The hops are noticable, but certainly play second fiddle to the malts.  Palate is creamy, but a bit thin and watery.  Overall, this is a VERY complex, and very tasty brown ale, wish I could find it in 12 oz bottles.

Thin on the tongue, but very nutty, slightly creamy. Pours a dark brown, small head. Slightly roasty, more on the malt side, no discernible hop. Pretty complex on the nose. Fizzy carbonation, but not overly fizzy, and smooth on the front of the tongue. A little peaty when you wash it around in your mouth. (Bottle Pour 5/8/2008)

Pours clear brown with off white head. Sweet hazelnut aroma. Sweet flavor with hazelnut, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, toasted m alts. Medium bodywith average carbonation and a slightly creamy mouthfeel. A solid brown ale.
Pured a clear brown color with a small off white head. Aroma is of nuts chocolate, cream and roasted malts. I cant describe the flavor anymore than by saying liquid butterfingers. Delicious

22 oz bomber pours a hazy chestnut body with a medium ecru head. Aroma of hazelnuts, milk chocolate, and mild dark roasty malts. Lively carbonation and a medium body. Taste is nutty with chocolate notes and an essence of honeyed brown bread. One of my alltime favorite Rogues and a very solid brown ale.

Aroma: One word: yum. Maple syrup, brown sugar, toasted marshmallows - and you can really smell the hazelnuts. Just a hint of mocha. Really something, this one.

Appearance: Gorgeous, shiny kalamata-olive coffee black. Pale yellow-tan head.

Flavor: A sophisticated flavor. Roasted malts that turn chocolatey at the end and a subtle hazelnut character. Estery hops lend a clean finish. The bottle says to serve with beef or pork, but personally I think it would match much better with dessert, especially something with a coffee flavor. Tiramisu comes to mind.

Palate: Good; full-bodied and thick.

Overall: I could sip this all night. I chose it as my post-finals celebration beer, and what a good choice! I just wish I had more.

22 oz bottle.  Light, sweet nutty aroma.  Mahogany color with off-white head.  Rich nutty taste with some sweetness, with a slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Moderate carbination, noit much hops.  Slight hints of dark chocolate.   Well balanced, this could really end up too sweet, or otherwise, the tastes could go badly out of whack but they make it work well.   Slightly bitter aftertaste as it gets warmer.   Impressive brew!

Bottle. Pours orange/brown with a thin beige head. Aroma is strong hazelnut, lightly roasted, and a light note of vanilla. Body is full and smooth. Flavor comes first with hazelnut/chestnut/almond and is accompanied by a nice sweetness with notes of caramel, vanilla and cherry. Roasted malt and coffee show up in the finish. Very nice.
kinda a hazelnut color, brownish.  Not a very strong aroma.  Tastes like chocolate and nuts.  Very nice beer.

At Tux place 280408.
Aroma and flavor of roasted barley. Honey sweetness and nut notes. A characteristic milky profile

Bomber, into Sam Adams lager glass. Pours Pours a hazy dark brown, with a small tan head that doesnt last long. Aroma is roasted hazelnut, chocolate. Taste starts off with hazelnut, very roasty, nutty, finishing bitter with deeply roasted hazelnut and flavors of dark bread crust, slightly bitter. Mouthfeel is highly carbonated, moderate body, not quite watery but not full either.

On-tap at the Flying Saucer, Raleigh, NC.

Our table was fairly evenly divided over this one -- either loved it or hated it. I gave it a robust "Good Lord!" upon first sip. It definitely drinks stronger than the 6.22% ABV that it is. Flirts with the possibility of being too sweet, but the folks at Rogue yet again pull off something that otherwise shouldnt really work.
Not usually a flavored beer fan, but this is quality stuff. Dee-licious! Even better when used to make the bread at Rogues restaurants.

Pours a deep brown with hints of caramel coloring. There is very little fizzy head that dissipates quickly. Smell is very sweet with a nutty and toffee edge. The taste is different than the smell lets on. Sweet, as was expected, but there is a strong nutty taste that hits from the second the brew touches your lips. It finishes very smooth and slightly bitter leaving hints of hazelnut taste on the pallet. It is carbonated fairly highly and I personally think this takes away from the mouthfeel. I would have enjoyed this style more with less carbonation but regardless, it was thick and smooth. This is a great beer to enjoy as a desert or to taste but I couldnt see myself drinking more than a glass or two in a sitting. Regardless it was a delicious brew that i thoroughly enjoyed.
Rich dark brown, enormous head.  Scents of wood, sugar, caramel, nut and significant malt.  Very smooth and refreshing.

Pours dark red-brown with a yellow head. Aroma is nuts, honey, and toast. Nice initial sugary sweetness with a strong nutty flavor on the finish. Not a huge fan of the nutty flavor, but its an ok beer overall.

Pours a medium rust colored brown with an inch of tan head. Very nutty aroma, almost a glazed sweetness with some lightly roasted notes. Initial taste is a very satisfying sweet nutty flavor. Flavor almost subsides in the middle to a few dry hops but then picks up with some hints of honey to a lingering tangy sweetness that is really nice. Body is smooth and refreshing for a brown.

Draft in a smoky bar: It had a dreadful smell of toejam and ass. Clear ruby colored with no head.Tastes of dirt, mold, moss, bark, and pretzels. Bready with a black cherry tang that doesnt fit well with the earthly qualities. Fascinating melon rind finish. Interesting novelty beer and skillfully crafted, but I doubt I drink it again.
dark in color. sweet scent. rosated malt flavor with sweetness. overall a good brown.

Bottle at Chaucers Pub- Dark deep brown letting in some light. Head is a frothy beige foam. Nose of toasty malts, and as you would expect, hazelnuts, like nutella, some chocolate, with a fair amount of fresh hops blasting up. Nice toffee and hazelnut flavours with sweet cocoa and a good dose of bittering hops to balance the act out. Finishes much like the flavour, just a bit thinner than I expected. Good stuff.
On Tap.  Incredible Ale.  My new favorite brown ale.  Light head, great aroma, not a strong hazelnut scent.  Sweet finish.  very smooth taste.

Pours dark copper brown with a lingering 2 finger beige foamy head.  Nose is all sweet hazlenut.  First sip is all hazelnit then roasted cocoa and just a slight dry hop finish.  Very good brown ale.  Would like to see a little more complexity.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 This is one of my favorite brown ales. Aroma is excelent hazelnut and leads to nuts and malt flavor with a clean finish.  Beautiful brown color and perfect carbonation.  22oz. bottle

Pours a clear dark amber with a thin light tan head and very little lacing.  Aroma is sweet caramel and nuts.  Flavor is sweet, not overpoweringly, not very complex.  Clean, not very heavy, more nut flavors appear as it warms.  Easy to drink, not much complexity of character.

Pours a cloudy tan with a dense head - aromas of honey and maple (maybe thats the hazelnut??) A bit under carbonated relative to a lot of ales, but it worked for this brew - allowing the malty flavor to shine through without blasting you with bubbles.  The malt presence reminds me of unprocessed malt extract you lick off the cans when making home-brew - heavier sweetness than a lot of beer, but not overdone.  Good brew

Poured dark cloudy amber.  Off white head dissipates quickly.  Aroma of lightly roasted malts, sweetness and some nuttiness.  Flavor is nutty and some chocolate.  Overall, not a bad ale, but not my favorite either.  Brown ales in general are not my favorite style.
65 cl bottle, at my «Hopheads» tasting. Reddish brown color, beige head. Aroma is very caramellish. Flavor is chocolate malt and nuts. Nice, but not ass good as i expected.

on tap @ papago. dark chestnut brown pour with orange at the edges. its got a small off white head that disappears to a ring rather quickly. aromas of toasted hazelnut syrup, caramel/toffee and some grassy hops. the flavor is definitely fake hazelnut but not really in a terrible way. notes of toffee, chocolate and grassy hops as well. light bodied but it has lively carbonation which makes it insanely drinkable. its not as bad as my rating would indicate, im just not down with flavorings...

Draught.  Poured deep rich brown with a thin quickly dissipating head.  Nutty and malty aroma.  Malty body, with a strong hazelnut present.  Sweetish finish, with more hazelnut.  Satisfying, but ones enough at a session.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: 22oz bottle, pours dark brown with a tan head, mostly dissipates and leaves no lacing.  Nutty and coffee aroma.  Taste is coffee, hazelnut, slight hops, and chocolate.  A good refreshing brown ale!

The color speaks brown and red, the head is full and steady. The flavor is in tune, with the hazelnut strong, but not overpowering. This is one of Rogues best brews putting in the running weith the worlds best.

On draft at Newport Pizza O.B. Poured a deep brown with a very nice roasted malt/nutty nose.  The flavor is very much that of rich toasted nuts and semi sweet coffee/toffee notes with a great balance of hops.  The finish was very smooth as Ive come to expect from all of Rogues ales!
Bomber.  Pours a dark brown. Great sweet light aroma, and its sweet on the tip of the tongue as well.  Really very enjoyable, probably the best brown ale Ive ever had.

I had Rogue HazelNut Brown Nectar on tap at Scottys in Bloomington, IN. The ale is deep brown in color with a nice but quickly disappearing head. The aroma is light, but hints of hazelnut cannot be missed. The flavor is full of great hazelnut flavor and the finish is very smooth. This is a great brown ale!

Pours meium brown like cola, cloudy enough not to see through.  Liquid looks a little syrupy at first, then turns runnier. Tons of foam on the pour that is densly packed and laces well and lasts a while. Great balanced hop and malt aroma and character. Aroma is mild and sweet, has hints of brown sugar, caramel, and hazelnut. The beer is not very carbonated on the palate and a little flat and runny. Its flavor is dominated by malt that is a little bitter. The finish has a little fizz, which is nice.
Now this is a great brown ale.  Great aroma, full of roasted nut flavors.  An aftertaste that keeps you thirsting for more.
Sweet aroma, roasted, nutty malt tones.  One of the best brown ales Ive ever had the pleasure of tasting.

This bomber (called Morimoto Hazelnut) caught my eye and promised an unusual beer-drinking experience.  The label spells out the ingredients in detail - I guess Rogue is proud of them.  The aroma is superb - floral hops with a touch of hazelnut cappucino.  The taste is mellow and smooth.  I could taste coffee and caramel, and the hazelnut comes thru clearly.  I kept  thinking that I might have spilled some latte into my beer.  But this unique brew works out pretty well and is worth a try.

One of, if not my favorite out of all the rogues. It has a good amount of flavor, but a little more carbonation than Id like. It has a hint of hazelnut(as expected) and a pinch of chocolate. Its a decent brown ale, with a thin head. Its good if you cant afford a lot, but still need to enjoy a decent tasting beer.

22oz bottle. Pours a opaque dark brown with a thin tan head that doesnt last long. Nose of some malt and hazlenut. Not very smooth, which is what I was expecting for some reason. Tastes like your basic brown ale with hazlenut flavoring added. A bit of a let-down.

Brown with a hint of red with a medium head.  Not the best brown and expected more from Rogue.  Toasted earth tones but a strange bitter tasted challenged the sweetness a proper brown ale should have.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 clear brown reddish in appearence with small head that disappated quickly. very sweet with taste of hazelnuts and thats about it .i dont know why this beer is rated so near the top for this style the flossmore station pullman brown is so much more complex and balenced if you get a chance check one out i think you’ll agree
Bottle. Pours see through brown with a small head. Aroma is a sweet nutty flavor. Has a definite hazelnut flavor with a hint of brown sugar. A slight malty finish. Good beer if you like hazelnut.

draft- liquified toffee and caramel, with some boozyness in the background. Little in the way of head retention, and a little thickness in the mouthfell detracted, but overall, this was a very nice treat.

Bottle. Pours brown wih a small lightbrown head. Aroma is nutty and malty. Flavour is full of sweet malts and could maybe use some more hops to balance it out. The sample Ive tasted at Potten in Skive was close to the exp. date, so this might be the reason for the lack of hops.
One of my favorites from Rogue. Wonderful nutty aroma. Flavor is hazel nut and vanilla. Very nice hoppy finish. Incredibly smooth.
This was the first Rogue beer I ever had and it hooked me on the Rogue brewery immediately.  Sweet hazelnut flavor with some great maltiness and a hint of hops balances this brew perfectly.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2008 On tap at Plan B, W Hartford CT. Absolutely zero head on this one by the time it got to me, but I’m not much of a stickler for the appearance category unless it looks like piss. Aroma started off sort of juicy, grape-ish. A little later it reminded distinctly of strawberry-rhubarb pie, fruits and delectable, buttery crust included. This doughy, buttery pie-crustiness continued throughout the flavor with the fruits/general malty sweetness sort of switching off from time to time. I honestly don’t think I would be able to identify hazelnut if given a blind sampling of it, so maybe that turned into this pie crust I keep talking about. In any event, I thought this was very unique, and very nice if you’re in the mood for some smooth sweetness.8-4-8-4-16/4.0Rerate 9/16/08. Interesting. Was I served the wrong beer the first time? Was it just way too cold as all tap beers from that location are? Was I just an idiot? Hard to say, but my goodness, there are hazelnuts here, fresh, nature-filled, fleshy hazelnuts comprise the majority of the aroma. I could make arguments for some earth and a touch of spice, but really it’s all from the nuts. Flavor not quite as nutty, but a general nuttiness still plays a prominent role with some chocolatey notes and semi-roasted sweet malt coming through more. Finish actually goes back to that huge hazelnut though, right back where you started. Very tasty and uniquely nutty in my experience.
3/8/08 - On tap at Ginger Man in Dallas.  Pours brown with amber hues.  Nose is hazelnut and caramel and some some nut.  Hazelnut and chocolate.  Little bit of hops.  Tasty, but a bit overpowering.
Great brown ale. Deep brown color with a lasting head. Smooth on the palate, with a nice nutty, malt flavor.  Another tasty beer by Rogue in a fun bottle!

Poured from a 22oz bomber and served in a Bells dimpled mug.  This beer poured a dark mahogany brown with a thick head of tan foam that lasted awhile.  The aroma of the beer was made up of roasted malt, nuts, and caramelized sugar.  The flavor consisted of sweet, roasted malts, cereal, mild chocolate, and some sweet hazelnut notes.  The mouthfeel was light to medium-bodied and a bit thin and watery.  A bit too sweet for the style by my tastes.  A pretty average beer.

Pours a very dark brown colour with a light tan head that dissipates faster than I can write this scentence. Smells nutty.  I like that.  Tastes a lot like Hazelnut which is not a good thing but a great thing!  Ha ha.  Probably the best brown ale Ive ever had.  Rogue never fails to impress. Such a great brewer. I drank this out of a Tumbler.
22oz bottle pours smooth with a dark brown color adn tan head.  Wonderful aroma of chocolate and hazelnut coffe.  Fantastic malty nut taste.  This is one of the best brown ales ever.

Review from notes.  Poured into my Rogue pint glass.  Dark brown body with a beige head.  The aroma has an obvious hazelnut note drifting above sweet and roasty malt.  Flavor is much the same, with roasted barley and chocolate setting the foundation for a rich nuttiness that is thankfully not overpowering.  Dry finish, smooth on the palate.  Really easy to drink.

Pours dark brown with a consistent one finger head.  Aroma of toffee, chocolate, brown sugar, and hazelnuts. Smooth tatse of sweet malts through hazelnuts to a light bittersweet finish.  Very solid beer.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a thin head. Strong, pleasant, hazelnut aroma. Nice strong nutty flavour, pleasing slightly sweet aftertaste.

Pours dark brown with a finger head.  The aroma is overwhelmingly sweet almost to the point that it smells milky.  The flavor is really sweet with this nuttiness, but it has a sharp dry finish.  The body is kind of nice and creamy.  It definitely got better as it warmed.

great aroma of hazelnut and roasted malt. Pours dark ruby with a thin head. Great brown ale flavor with a nice amount of hazlenut flavor. Ive homebtewed with hazlenut extract. This suffers from the same slightly artificial flavor. Very good though
Really great brown ale. Dont really taste any hazelnut but great falvoe all the same. Can see why it is in the top of this category.
amazing brown ale, best brown ale ive had, an interesting aftertaste of hazelnut and chocolate, but not overpowering at all!

22 oz. bottle - Poured mohogany color with medium beige head. A definite nutty scent, very earthy. Taste is creamy smooth with a hazlenut flavor on palate. Reminds me of a dunkel I had, has that musty earthy feel. Another fine brew from Rogue Ales but not my favorite.

Rogue Hazelnut Brown Nectar pours a dark copper-ruby color with a medium tan head.  The flavors of hazelnut and roasted malt are really nice, and so is the finish--sweet and nutty.  Theres something metallic and artificial though, which restricts me from giving it a higher rating.
pours a nice dark brown, nutty aroma, had a strong nutty taste that lingered but didnt distract from the overall taste. A nice change of pace
Fantastic beer, one of my favorites. The hazelnut flavor is just delicious without being overpowering. Could be the best of the Rogues.

Bottle, nice dark brown color. Big head, three fingers. It slowly disappeared but it was a creamy color. I can smell the hazleut a little bit. Flavor of malt and hazlenut, some other spices are thrown in as well. Taste like some chocolate also (cocco powder). This beer was good but nothing extraordinary.

750ml bottle.  Dark brown with a hint of red hue resembling a deep stained wood.  Nose if chocolate and malts.  Although pleasant i didnt pick up on much hazel in the nose. Taste is very nice, a bit smoky with earthy malts, cocoa powder,  and chestnuts.  Smooth with a bit dry finish.  Very well done brown ale,  highly drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Nutty brown amber color with very thin brown head. Aroma of roasted nuts and alcohol. Thin bodied with hazle-nutty and wood  taste. Thin and easy to drink a lot of! A tiny dry and bitter finish.
The aroma is sweet and milky with hints of dried fruit. The taste is sweet and nutty. The finish is smoky and woody. Its what a brown ale should be. Very drinkable and tasty.

22oz bottle. This was fairly decent. Better than expected for sure. Aroma of milk chocolate, hazelnut, vanilla, banana bread and grassy/slightly spicy hops. Pours a nice looking dark amber with a thin brown head leaving light spotty lacing. The Saaz are much more pronounced on the tongue and offer a nice bitter and earthy compliment to the sweeter hazelnut and chocolate notes. Some toasted malt in there as well. Creamy, medium bodied with a nice bitter and slightly sweet finish.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2008 Aroma of hazelnut, hops, chocolate and cereal malts with a bit of leathery yeast. Flavor is nutty and malty with a lot of toasted hazel nut on the back end. Appearance shows a dark amber body with a frothy light brown head that goes away. Okay lacing. Mouthfeel is creamy with soft carbonation. Pretty good!

Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  It was a smooth beer and well balanced.  There were some flavors of hazelnut and maybe a little bit of vanilla.  I thought it was a solid brown ale.  Rogue always seems to make very solid beers, but nothing extraordinary.

at the public house in san fran.
Not a bad little beer toasty sweet molasis and nutty aroma hints of vanilla in the flavor.  Pours to a dark brown color w/ a small tan head.

Very solid, drinkable beer with nice walnut bown color and 3/4 inch khaki head.  Both in the aroma and in the taste...hazelnut is definitely evident.  Mouthfeel isnt overly heavy and the flavor doesnt stick to the palate.  Extremely flavorful and undoubtedly something Ill drink again.  For those trying to convert the masses from the "World of the Macro" to something more refined, this would be a transitional beer they might be receptive to.  Cheers!!!

Tap..Poured a medium brown w/ slight head. Some coffee notes, but mainly dominated by the hazelnut and vanilla on both aroma and flavor. Descent palate / very smooth, but the more I drank the sweeter the beer tasted.

Very tasty beer. A great alternative to NewCraple when you can get it. Thick, but not overly so, nice even brown color with a tan frothy head. Very nice taste. I wouldnt say "complex" but certainly not "simple". Taste is smooth, creamy, with a nice nut and malt flavor. My favorite Rogue thus far.

Pours a light bworn color with a samll light tan head. Aromas of malt and hazelnut. Flavor is of hazelnut, caramel malt, vanilla and anf hint of hop. Nice smooth mouthfeel. Im not a huge hazelnut fan, but I really like this brew!
Damn i love the nutty flavor. There is some sort of frutiness to this beer also. Great thick mouthfeel. I liked this beer.

2 ounce sample.  Tasting at 99 BOTTLES.  The color was a brilliant orange-brown.  The nose was berries, sugar, nuts.  The flavor moved from cream to chocolate to nut, with a spicy edge and flashes of raspberry.  The mouthfeel was thick and creamy.  It was beautiful, it smelled good, it tasted even better, and it engaged the entire mouth.  Very good.
drought. smelled  great. very smooth with a tad bit of a burnt after taste but not over powering.
draught. smooth and sweet. finishes with some espresso, mocha, and hazelnut. everything I wish Starbucks was.
Bottle. Pours dark, dark reddish brown. Aroma is hoppy and nutty (duh). Big nutty taste, coffee and chocolate as well. Finish is bitter. Average.

Big nutty aroma, with a great flavor.  Not too carbonated.  A flavor packed with nutty chocolate and coffee.  Very sweet, but had some spicy hops in there too.  Kind of bitter finish, but relatively clean for as dense as this is.  Great beer.

Aroma of...hazelnuts, which is not necessarily a bad thing.  Taste:  Frangelico or hazelnut extract - sweet, hazelnuts, more hazelnuts.  I wondered if this was artificially flavored at one point: overpowering

Bottle.  Dark brown with similarly colored head.  Aroma is dominated by the hazelnuts.  Flavor is the same, with some roastiness and faint hop presence making an appearance.  Too much hazelnut for me.

22 oz. bomber.  Aroma of brown sugar and nuts.  Brown cloudy pour with almond head.  Sweet, brown sugar creamy taste with some spices evident.  Even finish.  Not a huge fan of the style but I really enjoyed it.

From bottle.Nutty aroma. Hazelnut brown in colour with an off white head. Rich, smooth, nutty flavour. Nutty finish. I found the beer a little soapy and too sweet. Got sickly  towards the end. Sounded like a promising ale but I didnt enjoy the beer as much as I had hoped for.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown, no head, a lot of lacing.  The aroma is sweet, creamy, nutty, and malt.  This is a very good brown ale - it is sweet but not too sweet, and the hazelnut, malt, and nutty flavors complement each other really well.  It adds up to a complex but relaxed and understated brew.
22oz bomber(10/07)-A medium brown body with a small head and an aroma of hazelnut, malt, and caramel. Taste of big time nuts followed by more nuts and a great malt finish. A nice tasting brew.

Tasted 1/5/08.  22oz bomber.  Amber brown hue and apparently clear.  Layer of off-white head.  Tasted at almost room temperature.  Total nutty nose!  Toasty and spicy nose.  Medium bodied with tight effervescence.  Spicy nutty flavors.  Touch toffee.  Dry finish with a lingering subtle cocoa sweet note.  Toffee and fudge.  Nutty brownies.  Roasted nuts.  Malt dominant.  Hops are bitter yet short lived.  Tasty!

Pours a deep brown with a moderately thick light tan head.  Aroma is very sweet and is pretty apparent about the hazelnut.  Smells like a barista poured some syrup in my brew.  Taste follows suit - very sweet syrupy hazelnut backed a basic brown ale malt base.  Decent, but not really my thing.

Bottled. A hazy deep brown beer with a big and quite persistent creamy beige head. The aroma is roasty and nutty, enough malty, with some hoppy notes. I feel some toasted bread too. Interesting flavour, lots of hazelnut, some chocolate. Smooth, creamy, with medium body, lively carbonation, and a light bitterness in an enough long finish. Less hoppy than expected. After all I find it enough well balanced and tasty.

I was pissed at this beer because it was nutty enough to get me expecting, but not nutty enough to finish the job!  Man, now I really want a super-nutty beer.  Rather sweet, almost brown sugary in its smoothness.  Light roasiness, and a smooth hazelnut flavor.  I just wish there was more!

On tap at Flying Saucer. Has a dark ruby color with a medium light tan head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is roasted malts and sweet caramel. Some lacing on the glass. The taste is malty with a sweet dry finish. Really enjoyed this one.

[778-20071020] Bottle. Mildly wet dog and nutty sweet roasted malt aroma. Clear, dark ruby brown body with a quick foamy light tan head. Roasted nutty vanilla malt flavour. Medium body. Very nice and nutty.

Pours a medium-dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is sweet, mostly nuts and coffee.  First taste is all hazelnut, but that seems to mellow and be balanced by chocolate and coffee.  I really enjoyed this beer.
Whoa, Nelly! Thats a lotta Hazelnut! Tasty, but strrrrrong on the sweet, nutty flavor! Beautiful complex palate, but Im not so sure about that zowee-patowee zing-zang nuttiness!

Dark brown with a red hue to it, has a almost tan colored head that leaves no lacing. Smell, as expected is very nutty, hazelnut and I thought maybe even a cocoa smell to it. Taste is definately full of hazelnut and I notice the cocoa more in the taste than the smell, with a hint of coffee in the finish. Light in body and highly carbonated, this is a good beer that I can see myself having again.

Appearance is a little lacking, but it still holds a little lacing and a crisp brown color.

The smell is very sweet and reminds me of a coffee, an irish cream splashed with a little mocha cocoa.

The taste is sweet with slight bitter cocoa with traces of irish cream in the nose.

Mouthfeel is fine: not silky smooth, but not hard and watery.

Drinkability is, for me, not enough to go out and buy more, but enough to wait until I feel the need or craving again and the opportunity arrises.

Solstice party in Canyon, CA.  Bottle. Pours dark brown with lovely, thick head into pint glass.  Lacing throughout drink.  Smells like malts, plums, applesauce. Taste is rich, malty, and ends with the hazelnut essence.  No hops.  Creamy as a thick Latte.  Ate this with some salty aged Gruyere and after each bite, the flavor of the beer intensified.  Awesome & sublime & cant wait to try with other foods. No alcohol flavor whatsoever.

Bottle.  Poured a very dark brown with a two finger tan head.  Very rich hazelnut nose, almost as if its more a coffee creamer than a beer.  Very interesting beer, although I think the hazelnut flavor overpowers much of the finer qualities of beer.  Surprised that theres almost no hint of alcohol in this beer.

On tap at the Bocktown, nice place. Some barely detectable roasty hints inthe aroma. Has the look of a darker cream soda. Some mild chocolate hints in the flavor and you cannot tell this is a 6.2% beer. Well hidden. Fairly enjoyable with little bitterness. Other Hazelnut brews Ive had were way to hazelly for me but this comes across rather gentleman like. Very mild creamy carbonation and it is barely present. Overall, not bad and fairly friendly. Easy to drink with no medicinal finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Thick and creamy head sits on a red/brown colored beer.  Malty sweetness with a little nutiness.  Nutty sweetness also in the aroma.

22oz Bottle: Cloudy brownish amber w/ a very small light brown head. Very sweet aroma. Malty, nutty & almost buttery. Aroma is amazing...I know I have to taste, but the aroma. Ah yes. Flavor. Roasted malts followed by a nutty, buttery goodness, then the roasted malts again. Not unlike the aroma. Slightly dry finish. Smooth, very smooth. A little creamy, nice carbonation & that aroma, my god...the aroma is friggin amazing. Great job by Rogue here...great beer!

Wine-King, Manasquan.. nice dark Amber color with a decent pale brown head. had a smooth dark hoppy taste that wasnt over powering. I dont know were the Hazelnut comes in because I didnt taste any.

Bottle. Pours a medium brown with decent beige head. Aroma is malty and nutty. Flavor is clean malt leaning towards sweetness with vanilla, butter, and hazelnut accents. Leaning towards thinness but overall mouthfeel is nice and this one drinks fast. Finish is dryer and has some toastiness to it along with more nuttiness. Good stuff and an easy drinker.
The aroma was fantastic, very nutty.  The flavor was a bit behind the aroma.  Still enjoyable though.  I enjoyed it!
750mL bottle split with wcampbell and Belushi. The aroma is fantasticly nutty. Hazel nuts galore...Taste is same. Great beer, no trace of any sort of alcohol., very smooth.

Great nutty aroma, I couldnt stop smelling it. There wasnt enough flavor to match the strong aroma though. Lighlty sweet, nut flavor, no hops or bitterness. A bit one sided, but decent. Breif watery finish. No alcohol presence.

This beer pours a deep brown with a medium tan head that dissipates very quickly leaving no lacing down the sides.  Aromas very faint but slightly nutty and some musty wood.  Falvors are very nice and subtle but totally emulate the smells.You definitely taste the and smell the hazelnut!  This is a very odd tasting beer with the hazelnut, but I like it somewhat.  Cheers!
22 oz bottle.  Decent pour with a nice aroma.  Flavor was a bit dissapointing due to high expectations from other Rogue beers.  Middle of the road for me.

Pours rich dark brown with a tan head.  Nutty aroma with sweet notes is very inviting. Warm, not overly heavy palate has just the right carbonation. Nutty flavor throughout, very satisfying.  Soothing, like a liquid friend.
cloudy brown, head quickly dissipated.  sweet aroma, almost like a friuty pipe tabacco.   a nice balance between nut and fruit.  hints of toffee and caramel.
From a tap poured brown with very little head.  Flavor of hazel nuts, with not much aftertaste or finish.

Bottle One of my favorite brown ales (or is brown nectar its own category?). It is as sweet as nectar, with an amazing hazelnut flavor. In fact, it tastes a bit like Nutella in a bottle, which is a very good thing. Nice malty flavor to complement the sweet hazelnut, lest you forget this is a beer, and a very good one at that!
Bottle at Toms Ultimate Glasgow Tasting : Poured a brownish with tan head. The aroma is nutty as well as the taste is hazel nut.
pours an amber dark brown with white head.  light subtle aroma, real smooth palate, low carbonation.  very sweet and nutty finish, very good.
Bottle at ultimate glasgow tasting, bbf jan 04. Aroma is a nutty brown ale. Taste is similar but chocolat hints, well balanced and tasty enough, but relitivly unexciting.

Bottle at Toms Ultimate Glasgow Tasting ... Yeasty malty with load and loads of Hazelnuts (i was told it was nut brown , so clearly identifable hazelnuts without knowing) little bit bitter in linger for my liking but still wonderfully rounded.

Served cold from tap. Pours a nice medium brown with a slighter-darker-than-tan head. The aroma is dominated by nuts but there are also hints of malts present. Ive always found this to be one of the easiest beers to drink, and considering the high-quality of the beer, that makes the Hazlenut Brown Nectar one of my favorite Rogue brews.

Pours a nice chestnut brown with an almond colored head.  Aroma is dominated by the hazelnut but also has a nice amount of maltiness and other nuts.  This is one of the smoothest drinking beers that ive ever had.  The sweetness of the hazelnut made me want to guzzle this beer down but I took my time as best as I could.  There is a nice amount of maltiness and a slight hoppiness added to th wonderfull sweet hazelnut flavor.  A slight watering down makes this beer not quite perfect. Otherwise, absoluelty delicious.

Man, I was disappointed with this beer.  Im wondering if I got a bad bottle or something.  It poured just like everyone else said, nice brown color with a tan head.  

After smelling the aroma, I just knew I was in for a treat here.  Very nutty and warm smelling.  

Im thinking this was an old bottle or something.  It tasted like a Bud Light or something.  I was expecting nuances of the hazelnut flavor, maybe some malt.  I didnt get any of that.  Tasted rather watery and thin.  Big letdown here.  I will probably try this again in the future to make sure Im giving this a fair shake but after seeing all of the high marks this was getting, I picked this over the Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout and Im pissed that I did now.  First Rogue beer Ive ever had and I didnt get started on the right foot here.  Big disappointment here.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2008 Had this on draft at My Fathers Office in Santa Monica, CA, a great beer bar. Despite standing in a crowd with no elbow room, this beer was a religious experience, especially for a real lover of brown ales. Flavor was definitely nutty, but also strong caramel and chocolate as well that just exploded in your mouth. Easily the best tasting beer I have ever sampled.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a dark chocolate brown with a nutty colored head.  You can really smell the hazlenut aroma mixed with a bit of chocolate.  The flavor is huge.  The nuttiness is balanced with a touch of tang from the hops but is accented beautifully by the malty sweetness.  Awesome.
One of the best beers Ive had. It pours a brown color and smell of nuts. Smooth and creamy from beginnning to end. Excellent nutty taste. This one will be bought again.
Poured a dark brown with medium head.  Smelled and tasted of hazelnuts and malt.  It was a very smooth brew on the front and backend.  Overall, one of the best beers Ive had.

(Draught at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, 24 Nov 2007) Dark reddish brown colour with brief head. Malty, nutty nose with notes of toffee, chocolate, wild berries and hazelnuts. Malty, nutty taste with dark fruit, prunes, hazelnuts and hints of chocolate. Low bitterness, hints of sweetness. Nice beer, but lacking some punch.

Wow! That lives up to its name.  Deep brown pour, very fine bubbles and head, gorgeous.  Wonderful hazelnut aroma with some malt, and maple syrup.  The flavor mactches... very sweet and smooth, malty, nutty, and some chocolate?   Unfortunately the palate just lets this beer down... the carbonaton is spot on but the body is sooo weak.
Chocolate and hazelnut.  malty.  Just an overall delicious beer.  A standout from a solid brewer.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2013 Freshly poured while the thick brown foamy head slowly dissipates  believe it or not I smell MANGOS! Im drunk and I have a damn mango tree about 20ft from my window but I smell mangos directly from this brew. Now after the head is gone and time to settle I definitely smell the hazel nut. Its so NUTTY! So smooth and drinkable matter of fact I honestly can drink this by the gallon. At 6.22% alcohol there is no trace of it. Get lost in this beverage and enjoy. Absolutely beautiful in appearance, aroma, and most importantly TASTE! My #1! Sorry Franziskaner Hefewiesse but youve been replaced but I still love you! However you know what there is no such thing as perfect so...
Pours a dark brown with a small head. Sweet malt aroma. Sweet with hints caramel and hazelnut. Rather full body. Nice beer.
Waitress surprised me with this one.  I could tell by the appearance it was going to be a winner.  Hazelnut very evident and aftertaste is spectacular.

Pours a dark, dark brown. Very dark for a "brown" ale, with a sandy tan head. Aroma was sweet and slightly nutty. Flavor is rich and nutty, slightly bitter,  and good malt flavor with a thick, rich, almost creamy consistency. Goes down smooth.

Draught. Poured a ruby amber colour with no head. Nose of roastiness and nuts. Iinitial taste has a very fizzy mouthfeel. Roasted malts, light coffee, and clearly artificial hazlenut flavor that tastes more like cherry. Finishing with bitter hops on the palate. Medium Body. The mouthfeel really draws away from the beer.

Had this beer on 9/10/2003.  Aroma is a light sweet scent, but it dose not give any hazelnut.  Color is a deep clear amber with light carbonation and thin head.  Taste is sweet and fizzy.  Starting with medium body it goes down with a sweetness and a slightly sharp feel.  Finish is a sweet fake hazelnut flavor with no hop flavor and just a hint of malt.  This thing is a big disappointment for a brew from Rogue.  The hazelnut flavor comes across fake and its very unbalanced.  Overall you can drink it but not with a smile.

Not much aroma; tastes like milk chocolate and coffee, nice sting but goes down really smooth, kind of creamy. The hazelnut extract is very evident.
[tasted next to a Big Sky Moose Drool Brown Ale]

Pours a nice brown.  A light head with not much lacing.  Real nutty aroma.  Slightly sweet caramel/toffee.  Drinkable and smooth.  I wouldve liked a more hop flavor.  Rogue has done a good job as usual though.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text:
22oz dust-covered  bottle, courtesy of 4 Seasons in Hadley, MA

Smell: Very nutty, nice hazelnut aroma with a little bit of caramel and chocolate.

Taste: Not sweet, not bitter.  What I got was a very mellow, creamy, nutty flavor, not strong at all. It reminds me of a hazelnut coffee with way too much cream so that a lot of the intense flavor is gone. Minuscule hop presence. Aftertaste is nutty then roasted coffee.
Flavor is good but if it packed the appeal of the smell it would be great.

Other: Carbonation was a lot higher in this one. It messed with my taste buds. Viscosity was rather thin but left a creamy coating in your mouth.
Really good. Smooth, hazelnutty, malty. Dark brown with a thin tan head. Some coffee/chocolate aroma with the hazelnut.. Smooth aftertaste. One of my new favorite beers, wish it werent so expensive.

Nutty goodness! The hazelnut is very evident in the aroma and taste, especially after it warms a bit, but most of all in the finish, pleasant nutty aftertaste. nice malty beverage with subtle hops. I could drink this very regularly.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2008 Awesome. Good hazelnut flavoring, I reaally enjoyed it. Smooth tasting with good roasted notes. Overall a really good brown ale. The hazelnut taste is so enjoyable it almost makes you feel like you are chewing on some... Delicious, and without a doubt my favorite Brown thus far.
From bottle : Pours a drak brown color with minimal head.  A hazelnut and roasted aroma.  Nice smooth mouthful.  Taste is good, nice aftertaste, roasted.  Quite a nice brown ale.

Enjoyable bomber, a very nice take on the style. Murky medium brown pour with a filmy tan head and splotchy lacing. A wonderful scent of creamy hazelnut and milk chocolate with some faint caramel and spicy star anise. Velvety smooth mouth feel, large malt body. The hazelnut flavor is very prominent, reminds me of one of my favorite morning coffee creamers. Butterscotch and tame chocolate along with some expected floral hop flavors. Taste is rounded out be a strong nutty malt flavor and some light coffee. Great variation on a classic style, I really enjoyed the strong hazelnut presence.

Initial aroma and appearance were impressive.  Whatever you do, do not drink this beer ice cold.  True taste was pleasant when drank at around 65+ degrees.  Finished flat and watery without much of an obvious Hazelnut  hint  Use of Crystal Malts is misleading, not as caramely as one would wish.  Deffenatley room for improvement.  Nice attempt, one can see what the intent was on this one.

On draft at Cambridge Common.

Great beer for one of the first cold Saturdays in New England.  Wonderful nutty aroma and very rich coffee/toffee flavors.  Served at Cambridge Common with very little head, though it may have overflowed on the glass.  I dont actively seek out nutty/brown beers, but this was a wonderful find.  Rogue never disappoints!
This beer poured out to a brown color witha tall tan head.Aromas of brown sugar,malt,toffee.Taste was pretty dominated by the hazenut which was ok,I guess,especially after it warmed up a bit.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2008 Bottle, Solvang, CA. Brown. What a strange brew, very nutty. After a few sips I read the ingredients and noticed there is actual hazelnut extract and thats what it tastes like. Its like those flavored coffee drinks you get from Starbucks. Really difficult to consider this as a real beer. Some coffee, chocolate.

5 words: Pecan Waffles With Maple Syrup. Thats what this beer smells and tastes like - especially as it warms up. Had a tall bottle at The Ginger Man in Austin, TX. Nice nutty appeal, sweeter than most nut brown type beers. Very enjoyable. Packed a nice little buzz before The Avett Brothers concert - nice combo.

10-7-07 bottle.  Brown color (shocking, huh?) with short lived head.  Subtle malty aroma with strange bready overtones.  A bit on the watery bland side for me.  Not great but not bad by any means.  I just think there are better Browns out there.

Pours a hazy rich brown color with cramy tan head.  Aroma of hazelnut, toffee and light chocolate.  Taste is of hazelnut, liht vanilla, toffe, caramel and light chocolate.  Very creamy, smooth and well balance  Excellent.

Dark brown, reddish amber color. Full off white head. Fairly sweet aroma. Definitely sense the hazelnuts. Also some hints of toffee and slighty toasted malt. Light to medium in body and nicely carbonated. Normally not the biggest fan of the browns, but this one was pretty good.

Bottle. Aroma starts with a heavy dose of malt. Hazelnut, milk chocolate and roasted stand right out, with light grass for the hops and light dough for the yeast, and toffee in th background. Head is fizzy and off white and gone way too quick with no lacing. Color is brown (maybe thats where they got the name brown ale). Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic then finishes lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is light to medium watery and a carbonation thats between lively and fizzy. Though a little lacking in taste, aroma is what really makes this beer.

Well here is a sweet brown, I love it. I can definetly taste the Hazelnut extract, its like someone poured some Frangelico in there.  Possibily my #1 choice for a dessert beer.   Normally I am an IPA man, but sometimes you gotta switch it up.
Hazy amber with tiny head. Sweet aroma with sweet malt, chocolate and nuts. Sweet flavor with chocolate and nutty notes.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 Bottle conditioned and enjoyed at Volo. Poured a deep ruby with minimal head. Aroma is dry, and somewhat spicy. Flavour has a nice nutty bite, with a pleasant alcoholic oakiness. Dry nutty finish. Would repeat again at a lesser price.
Deep brown of color with a brown head. An aroma of chocolate, caramel and dry notes of nuts. A flavor of caramel, chocolate, weak coffe notes and a dry finish with nuts.

This ale poured a deep brown colour with a nice big foamy head. Scents included puffed wheat, cocoa, caramel, corn flakes and of coarse hazelnuts. First taste was quite hazelnutty with a quick bite from the carbonation, maybe a little too fizzy. The finish though is smooth and creamy with a little hop after the nut flavor. Palate ends with a light bitter taste while the hazelnut continues...

For me this is the nut brown ale of all nut brown ales.  Im not a fan of hazelnut coffee, so Im a bit surprised at how much I enjoyed this.  The smooth texture, and flavorful outburst of a delicious array of malts, topped off with a not too sweet yet not too bitter aftertaste will have you wishing you bought a case.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 RERATE:  22oz.  Pours hazy brown, slight amber twinge.  Thin brown head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is a bit lacking and hard to find.  Flavor delivers exactly what I hoped!  Great carbonation and smooth mouthfeel, good sweet malt and hop that reminds me of Christmas in Germany... (It seems hazelnut is in everything christmas and not too much sweetness).  Really hits the nuttiness on the head.  Has a certain buttery creaminess that is very reminiscent of eating nuts and how the fat from the nuts coats ones palate.  Will probably go back to this one, a brown ale with character.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 650 ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a dark, translucent red-brown color with an off-white head that  faded at a reasonable pace and showed plenty of lacing. Aroma was moderate in strength with rich spices of cloves, cinnamon and anise. The flavor featured black licorice, roasted oats, malts and burnt toast. The mouthfeel starts a bit thin but builds to a nice creamy climax--very full and satisfying. Overall this is a great beer. Recommended.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 Pours a dark ruby-brown into the glass wiht a small bubbly head.  A quick chocolate taste at first, definitely has a malty and nutty character as well, can taste the alcohol a little bit, too.  Also, there was a little bit of a coffee aftertaste.  This beer went down smoother that I expected... it looked heavier than it felt in the mouth.

1 pt. 6 oz. bottle, on tap.
On tap at Rogue, Union st. Interesting beer....not sure if i liked it but interesting all the same. Had a huge butterscotch nose and flavour, possibly to much and thats what put me off.
good the first few times and every once in a while but not strong enough and too expensive

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2007 Excellent. I was expecting an overwhelming or artificial hazelnut aroma and taste and was pleasantly surprised by the subtlety of the flavors. The hazelnut lends itself readily to the brown ale. Sublime--be very afraid, Nutella! Love this beer and ranks among my favorite Rogues for the time being.

Bouteille 650ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur brune-rouge et légèrement voilée. Nez de noisettes, de malt rôti doux, léger de caramel et de chocolat avec des notes de houblon herbeux, de pain et de levures fruitées (traces de raisins). Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse et aux petites notes huileuses et aqueuses. Goût de noisettes rôties (présent toute la gorgée) accompagné de notes de levures fruitées (raisins) et des traces boisées lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût légèrement amer de malt rôti doux avec un léger goût de chocolat et de pain ainsi que des notes de caramel toffee puis en finale lon retrouve un goût léger-moyen amer de houblon herbeux ainsi quun léger regain de goût de noix plus asséchant et également des traces de café. Post-goût moyen-long et un peu sec, moyen-léger amer de rôti, de chocolat, de noix, léger de houblon herbeux avec des notes de café.

Maroon brown pour with a light tan head.  Slightly transluscent but hazy.  Smell is definitely big on hazlenuts with a lot of sweetness, and milkiness coming in as well.  Smells like the hazlenut coffee creamers.  Nice slightly thick body on the beer, smooth, and sweet nuttiness.  Perhaps a bit overly sweet, but the big nutty flavor was welcomed.  Nice for a brown, and pretty easy drinking.
Brown with a nice head to it.  I thought it had a nice malty taste.  I wish I could get more Rogue brews where I live.

Brown, with a diminishing head. The flavor and aroma really comes out when the beer is warmed up a bit.  Aroma of hazelnuts, sweet caramel malt. Flavor is the same with some chocolate malt in there. Finish has a light amount of bitterness to balance the sweetness. Pretty good body for a brown and nice moderate carbonation. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2007 Pours a beautiful brown color with a generous off-white head that lasted a while.  Smell is both nutty and chocolatey.   Taste is fabulous.  Nutty and tastes of chocolate.  Very well balanced.  Mouthfeel is great.  Drinkabilty is good.  This is one fine beer.
draft. off white head. dark mahogany color. not a hwole lot of aroma, but im on a porch. taste is smooth and nutty and very little hops. clean finish.
Tasted like cream soda with addition of slight hazelnut flavor.  Easy to drink but unremarkable.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 bomber, poured a plumb brown in color with a thick frothy two finger head and good carbination that stayed through the whole bottle. smell has hazelnut as advertised, slight cider sweetness, caramel, malts, and is a little funky. the hazelnut flavor is nice, slightly sweet, and has a creamy chocolate thing from the malts. only complaint is the finish just does not quite have enough punch, but it is an easy to drink beer. one of the better browns and with some hazelnut thrown in, real good!
Strong hazelnut aroma, which I didnt like. Head declined quickly. Thin body. Clear, weak brown color. Lightly hopped.

On draft at the Flying Saucer.  Has a deep mahogany body with a tan head.  Wonderful sweet aroma with hazelnut liquor.  Tastes predictably sweet with little hop presence.  Light chocolate, truffle, molasses and caramel notes.  Very nice.  A desert beer.
Pours out a brown color with a nice tan head.  Aroma is very nutty and malty.  Flavor is the same.  This might be the best brown that i have ever drank.  this is a solid beer!
A damn good nut brown.  Very nutty and malty.  Tasty, Tasty, and ...Tasty.  One of my favorite brown ales.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Poured dark brown with creamy caramel head. Lots of nuts in the nose (dont take that out of context), but I dont get a hazelnut experience as much as just pure roasted nuts, like almonds and cashews. Taste is chocolate, roasted nuts, cream. Bitter finish. Drinkable, and recommended.

"Its a bit nutty" This beer is wildly popular around Boise with a float of Chocolate stout. I must say that I prefer that particular version to the straight nectar. No offense to the all mighty Rogue, but at least Im topping it with one of THEIR other beers.
this is a very nice, mellow brew that goes down very easy and is refreshing to the palate

Pours dark brown with a nice creamy head. Roasted hazelnut and dark chocolate in the nose. this is going to be great!
Well....
Tastes like dark roasted nuts and sweet malt. Leaves an aftertaste that hints of wood. Rogue has done better.

bottle - Pours dark brown with a very thin head and a caramel malt aroma.  The flavor is sweet, nutty, caramel malt with a good balance of hops.  Its medium bodied though even as it warmed it still seemed a touch watery.
22oz Morimoto.  Simply look at the name.  Hazelnut, brown, and nectar.  Solid and creamy, with a great malt flavor.  Delicious.

On draught at the Issaquah brewhouse Aroma is sweet malt with nuts, roast and caramel.  Appearance is a clear light brown with a moderately retained tan head.  Flavor is very light, nutty sweet malt forward with medium bittering and some citrus.  Mouthfeel is medium bittering with a solid medium carb bite and slight creaminess.  Overall, not bad, with decent complexity, but could be sweeter.

A Sim rate (on tap at the Flyng Saucer Memphis): Nutty, slightly sweet aroma thats a bit too alcoholic. Nice dark amber colour but no head or lacing. SO divinely hazelnut in the flavour. Sweet chocolate and caramel with an amazing finish.
Bottle. Pours a very dark amber with a nice head. The taste is hazelnut, a smooth sweet malt, and a strong coffee aftertaste. Good for breakfast.

Yet again, Rogue delivers. The hazelnut comes with a dark brown/red color with a one finger head. Nose is light hazelnuts. The taste at first is lighter on the nut, but I found as time went on that the flavor was more pronounced as it stayed with you. This wont be my all-time favorite by Rogue, but it still is very very good.

Bottle.  Color is a nice brown that glows amber in the light.    A nice tan head that subsides.  Aroma is hazelnut, with a hint of malt.  Taste is a nice smooth hazelnut, with a bit of nut.  Finishes very smooth, with a little hops at the end.  Wonderful beer.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 
Name: Hazelnut Brown Nectar
Date: June 23, 1996
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewpub
Appearance: dark
Aroma: sweet nut like aroma, lots of smoked peat aroma
Flavor: good smokey nut flavor and nut aftertaste 

Name: Hazelnut Brown Nectar
Date: September 02, 1997
Mode: tap
Source: newport
strong fresh hazelnut aroma and flavor, no bitterness, and certanally no peat!

Name: Hazelnut Brown Nectar
Date: September 02, 2008
Mode: draft
Source: summits woodstock
Appearance: clear dark brown, fine beige head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma with a strong but not over the top nutty character
Flavor: rich sweet chocolate flavor, lots of hazelnut, vanilla sweetness really brings out both the chocolate and hazelnut, very light balancing bitterness

Name: Hazelnut Brown Nectar
Date: August 28, 2011
Mode: draft
Source: tmac kennesaw
as good as it ever was but the hazelnut have a very artificial flavor additive character,  

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.8/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

22 oz..Morimoto Hazlenut...dark brown with a big bubbly head...head dissapears after a minute...malt aroma..light sweet and nutty aroma...roasted malt taste...definately pick up the hazlenuts in the finish...great brown ale

Poured a dark and earthy brown and forms a two finger beige cap. The nose was bourbon-esque laced hazelnut and rich dark chocolate. The taste was of roasted toffee malts with sweet cocoa and a nuttiness that slips to a piney finish. This is a great brown ale perfect around the hollidays.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2007 bottle, bomber. poors heticly bubbly then leaves no head, looks like a matt finish unfiltered bourbon in the glass. Aroma as advertised; overpowering hazelnut, with vanilla. quite quaffable. no nasty overtaste. Im certain this tasted loads better at the  2007 anderson valley brewfest from a tap (but I was very, very drunk).

Draft at Brixx. Nothing smells quite as good to me as a fresh-brewed pot of hazelnut coffee, and thats what overwhelms the nose of this one. Delightful. Actually not as dark as Id expected and pretty thin on the head, but still a nice rich dark brown. Yeah, it tastes like hazelnut coffee, too. Its very sweet, and quite unusual with those coffee notes so present, which did wear on me by the end of the pint, but not as much as Id feared they would. Truly an interesting beer, not one Id drink tons of, but itd be a great change of pace beer and good for converting non-beer-drinking girls to the joy of "real beer".

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Poured from a bomber.Poured a deep amber brown with a tan head.  Aroma was dominated by hazelnuts, and smells quite nice.  Taste is much the same, with initial malt hit leading into a nice hazelnut flavor.  A bit sweet, but very nice.  Smooth mouthfeel helps with the drinkability.  Top notch brown ale.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown with huge light brown head. Nutty, malty and chocolaty aroma. Great, silky mouthfeel. Distinct, but balanced, flavour with lovely hazelnut character (and hey! I dont even like nuts!). A slightly bitter finish prevents it from becoming cloying.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 Aroma: Chocolate,malt,hazel nut&caramel.  Appearance: Deep-red- brown. Inch thick tan head slowly disappears into a ring around the glass. Flavor: Malty-nuts with little alcohol presence. Palate l: Liquid and oily. Finish: The end is the same as the beginning. Mild hop. Nice Brownie.

Served on Tap at the Yard House, In Phoenix.  Poured very dark, almost black(poor lighting) with little head.  This beer is great! You really can taste a hint of nuttiness...just right, not ovepowering.  Nice find!

Draft
This was a deep brown color with a thin head.  The aroma was that of dark malts and Hazelnut.  Loved the aroma the beer also had some great flavors this was truly a fun beer to drink.  Never thought it would be this good.  The beer drank easy and the hazelnut flavor was throughout but not hugely overpowering.   A Great Great Beer.

Roasted malt and nut aroma.  Very strong hazlenut smell, excellent.  Deep brown color,  light head.  Doesnt lace well.  Taste of nut and brown sugar.  Good bitterness in the finish.  Clean mouthfeel, thin.  Great beer.
Dark amber with foamy head / Fresh bread nose / Medium body, subdued carbonation, with steady finish / Flavors of toasted nuts, caramel, and vanilla / A fine, tasty, balanced brown ale.

650mL bottle.  Pours a beautiful deep brilliant, reddish brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is soy sauce, malt, hazelnut, some vanilla.  Flavor is rich malt, soy sauce, hazelnut, chocolate some vanilla, and a touch of hops.  You can really taste all that Crystal malt as well as the Pale Chocolate.  A very fine brown ale.
22 oz bottle. This isnt one of my favorite styles, but it was pretty good. Lots of nutty flavors and a hint of some sour too.

When you look at the Rogue Hazelnut bottle, there appears a bald intellectual looking fellow with a pretty satisfied almost smug look about him; he is almost saying to you,"Yeah, I got this great mug of hazelnut brown, come on and have some with me." I suggest you do.
A fabulous beer! This is a great example of the brown ale style with distinctive characteristics that make it a Rogue product. You can taste, and to their credit, very subtle notes of hazelnut and dryness; thoroughly enjoyable; this is a prime example, like the Chocolate Stout, Shakespeare Stout, and Dead Guy Ale, of why Rogue just might be the worlds best brewery!!!
Poured  a light brown color with a strong two-finger frothy beige head. Awesome nutty nose with hints of sweet vanilla extract.
On tap at Issaquah brewhouse.  Strong nutty impact, dry finish with plenty of initial sweetness.
650 ml bottle,pours dark brown with ruby highlights,tan head,carmelnuttynose.carmelchocotalynutty tastenot to sweet whith a nice restrained bitterness.very nice.
Nice dark brown color. Nice nutty aroma, with hints of malt and coffee.The taste is an interesting hazelnut, caramel, and a bit of hops.
