With an unimpressive watery and slightly bitter aftertaste, this brew seems to progresses to an increasingly unfinished state. Not far from a winner, but this Brown Ale requires just a bit more work for my taste.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 on tap-pours a rich tan head with dark brown color.  Aroma is malt, roasty.  Taste follows, nutty, sweet. 3.0
Rerate120218-thanks Ben
Bottle shared with Mette, Henniing ad Karen in the garden, as a before-dimmer-beer. A big tastel of Hazenut. Lovely malty smell. Almost no hop smell and  taste. Very nice pleasant beer.
Tasty treat with a nice pour and a quality aftertaste on the palate.  Id offer it to a friend.
A very nice pour rich brown in colour, with a pleasant hazelnut aroma.  Has a nice creamy tan head that dissipates rather quickly.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2006 A darned nice nut ale. The hazlenut approach was unique and pleasant, just phenomenal. Appearance was crystal clear ruby brown with a small head and minimal lacing. The aroma was strong hazelnuts with some chocolate behind it. Flavor was dry hazelnuts, with a sweet dark malt base (chocolate?). Mouthfeel light to moderate for the style. After two tastings of this, man, Im impressed. One of the best nut browns around.

Cant figure out why, having had this so many times, that I neglected to rate it.  Deep garnet body with a small brown head.  Nice roasted nut aroma, vanilla notes, malted Whoppers.  Full bodied and creamy in the mouth.  Same notes in the flavor as in the aroma.  Had this once with a shot of Frangelica in it.  Awesome.

Bottle, Københavnske Øldage 2006. Dark brown with an average head. Rich malty and nutty aromas. Mellow brown and nutty caramelly flavours. Some artificial caramel. Finishes with nougat and more caramel. Soft and without any influence of hops.

From a 22oz. distinctive Rogue bomber bottle with info and a blurb on the right side of bottle along with a good beef and pork symbols.

Made a good appearance, poured a cloudy chocolate brown with a foamy tan head that settled into a thin lacing, moderate carbonation.

Had a hazelnut and caramelized malts nose with a little roasted sweetness.

A crisp, malty textured and creamy smooth medium bodied mouth feel, very good drinkability.

Hazelnuts and caramelized malts, toasted and roasted with a nice sugary sweetness, a spicy hoppiness that is quick and fleeting in its bitterness, a chocolate maltiness shows up in the middle and a nutty and sweet malty finish.

Another winner from Rogue, one of my favorite brewers, tasty, nutty and quite quaffable.

This beer has it all- not weak in any category.  In appearance, its a nice dark brown, almost reddish color with a small to medium sized tan head.  The aroma is chocolatey, sweet, almost milky- chocolate milkshake is coming to mind..., a touch of vanilla and brown sugar.  It also tastes chocolatey and malty, but very nutty as well.  Smooth and creamy, low carbonation- the palate is very appropriate for the flavours.

Pours a clear rich redbrown with a decent light tan head, dwindling over time to a thin film.  The nose is delicate (my allergy ridden sinuses couldnt pick anything up at first, though after blowing my nose...).  Milk chocolate, almost Nutella, given that distinct sweet hazelnut overtone.  Just a touch of flowers at the end, though given the big malt, I suppose some more hops wouldve been nice for balance... though I dont think that would be appropriate for a beer that smells like desert.  Though this is a great tasting beer, I was immediately wowed by the palate--silky smooth with the tiniest bubbles Ive ever encountered.  Just enough viscosity to remain a session ale.  This really nails the right mouthfeel for a brown, in my humble opinion.  This brew really continues to shine in the flavor department.  Huge malt, chocolatey and creamy sweet with just a hint of spicey hops at the end.  The finish is a bit toasty for a brown, but I cant say Im complaining!  The hazelnut isnt as obvious in the flavor, but it sneaks out in the lactic aftertaste.  This is one of the nicest session beers Ive consumed.

Tap  @ Frisco Grille (Rogue Wave Weekend) - Deep clear brown, thin tan creamy head.  Nose held soft notes of rich hazelnut, brown sugar, with even softer caramel and raisin notes.  Flavor was nutty all up in the house with light sweet chocolate and more brown sugar dominating.  A light hop bitterness offers up a version of balance, but this take is all about the hazelnut.  Light to medium bodied, light carbonation, soft nutty, semi-sweet finish.  Decent stuff, but couldnt drink more then one in a sitting...
Robe brune foncée très claire surmontée dune mousse brune mince qui sestompe. Arômes noisette, de sucre et de malt. Saveurs de malt, dérable et de noisette.

Looks almost as dark as some stouts.  Rogues stuff is a bit more carbonated than I generally care for, but the aroma and taste were both amazing.  Definitely tastes of hazelnut.  A great choice if you can find it (or afford it).

Bottle (found in Atlantic City!!) An above average beer that delivers what is on the label. Deep brown in the glass with a tan head. Aroma is malt and hazelnut. Much the same in flavor with a powerful sweetness to it. 
Very good beer and highly enjoyed.
As the description says rich nutty flavor nice brown semi opaque color, excellent maly aroma, nice thick palate. Down the hatch smooth. Great beer. Cool label

Bottle.
Hint of sweet hazlenut.
Appearance: keeps a thin head, dark body.
Flavor is decent. Alittle too sweet at times. Goes down smooth/ very drinkable.
A decent brown ale but one where I would get another.
Cheers!
bottle. amber brown color lots of caramel in smell and taste. a litte thin but otherwise a great brown ale.
Bottle. Pours dark brown in colour with a large light brown head. Malty and sweet. Too sweet. Caramel and kinda suggary.

Tap, Yardhouse. Poured a dark brownish/amber color. Smells of roasted maltiness and some dark fruits are predominant. Dark roasted malty flavor. Some dark fruit. A little bit of chocolate. Somewhat creamy mouthfeel.
This beer was very flat, with no head and little carbonation. A thick dark ale, I didnt detect and Hazlenut flavor, and very little flavor at all. Not a favorite

deep garnet/chestnut brown color, mostly clear.  light tan foamy head thats cramy at the top.  aroma is nutty chocolate malt, like raw filberts.  body and mouthfeel is thin, medium to high carbonation.  flavor is raw hazelnuts with their skins, and a little grassy sourness.  faint chocolate malt (this isnt nutella but I wish it was) but this is more one the nutty side.  finish is, bitter and vegetal - rutabagas?
Very big head on a dark copper drink. Very carbonated. Where did the head go so quickly? Nice bitterness. I quite like the nutty flavour. A little thin but very drinkable.
Bottle. Brown lasting head. Clear dark body. Nutty cocoa aroma.Roasted malt  hazelnut choccolate flavor with proper bitterness. Do not remember having tasted something like this before. Thanks.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2007 Small head that disappeared quickly. Caramel and nut aroma. Chocolate and nutty flavor that lingers. A little bit of toffee flavor on the end. Slightly creamy with no carbonation.

A zinger.  22 oz bottle.  Pours a very clear saddle leather brown in your glass with an off-white, fizzy head diminishing fairly quickly.  When held to the sun the brew becomes beet reddish - kind of purple even.  This brown has an awesome, beautiful nose with the most immediately recognizeable aromas of cinnamon, hazelnut, and maple syrup.  Theres also definately some deep orange in there; maybe some clove too.  More beer huffing reveals a malty, doughy bread aroma.  Im excited to taste this.  My first gulp is bliss, so I forget to take notes and finish half the bottle.  Predominant flavors of dark chocolate, maple, and honey and a perfect balance of the sweet and tart.  Nice, full, creamy body with soft carbonation and a long, lightly bitter finish that left me smiling without realizing it.  Not a trace of alcohol in the smell or taste.  I gulped down the second half of the bottle and made a note to buy a couple more cases.  Caressingly smooth and infinitely satisfying - this is the best beer Ive had all morning.

Dark brown in colour with medium carbonation, but poor head retention. Malty aromas, along with the typical  Rogue pacman yeasty touch. Initial flavors of munich malts and a bit of soft fruit give way to the more drying chocolate malt and nut flavors. I think its more sesame than hazelnut. Theres a bit of a sour twang on the finish that I didnt really like.

Hazy, rather than cloudy, dark reddish brown.  Principal note in the nose is indeed hazelnuts.  Taste is sour brown, and with so many kinds of malts I think muddied Mahler rather than symphonic Beethoven.  Not so much complex as unfocused.  Thin and dry in the mouth.  Better than the sub-elements makes it sound, but not my favorite from Rogue.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2007 Clear nut-brown, modest tan head. Sweet and toasty, nutty caramel and shortbread cookie aromas. Big nutty character up front, a little milk chocolate, lots and lots of caramel malt flavour. Thoroughly enjoyable with a high density of flavour makes this one of the best brown ales Ive ever tried (can Rogue do no wrong?).
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: UPDATED: AUG 10, 2006 Not as creamy as I expected, a little bit more bite, but the hazelnut flavor is phenomenal.  It comes through strong but it doesn’t overpower, and it’s just as sweet and tasty as the name suggests.  I wish it were creamier, but it’s still delicious.
nice almost creamy brown ale with a strong bite of hazelnut?  I dont know some sort of spice.  kinda tasted like licorice to me.  Any way pretty good for the style.

Pint on tap. Ill need to rerate this at a later time but I was quite disappointed with this higly rated beer. The initial sips were very medicinal - It was like the beer wench had dosed it with Robitussin. After I made it through about a third of the glass the cough syrup taste was gone and I was left with a too sweet, strangely hopped brown that to me didnt resemble a brown in any way but the color. It was OK.

Dark red with a light head.  The Yeasty fruity/apple aroma reminds me of belgian beers.  A slight hint of hazelnut in the aroma.  Intense sweetness as if some kind of juice was added (apple juice?)  Juicy fruit and spicy finish with some nuttiness.  Full bodied and a bit sticky but  still pleasant.  Different but good.
In the bottle, nutty aroma. Pours a thin creamy head. Sweet, nutty flavor. simply one of the best brown ales out there.

An aroma of hazelnut, caramel, and  toasted malt. A dark brown beer with a hint of red when held to the light. It has a flavor of sweet hazelnut coffee. A good finishing bitter that eases on you and lasts. A smoothly carbonated beer that the palate doesnt weaken much as it warms.

Brown Ales are pretty much the same from brewer to brewer, but this one set itself apart from the rest by being bold, thick, and nutty.  Another awesome beer from Rogue!  If you like Newcastle, give this a whirl and see if you still think your precious import is the bomb.

Bottled.  Pours dark brown with a thin creamy head.  The aroma is a really sweet syrupy malt aroma and the taste pretty much matches.  This is a  medium body ale, with a slight malty syrupy quality to it that makes it a very hard to forget beer.  It has a very sweet finish.  Great beer!

Ive enjoyed this one both on draught, and in 220z bombers. This beer has its fans and its share of critics as well. I enjoy this beer, and find the addition of hazelnut to be a nice one. Pours to a beautiful, bright, deep brown color, with a creamy, tan head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is excellent with lots of fragrant hazelnut aroma, paired with nutty and sweet malt aroma. The palate is firm, with good sweet malt, and nutty malt flavors. This beer finishes, with more good sweet and nutty malt flavor up front, then ends sligjhtly cloying, with a very pleasing hazelnut flavor that lingers. If you enjoy hazelnut, then you will enjoy this beer. While hazelnut is indeed the star of this show, I really enjoyed the aroma and flavors of sweet and nutty malt. The hazelnut character is too much for some tastes, but this beer makes for a wonderful desert beer, and a great beer to enjoy after a nice meal.
Outstanding brown ale, with notes of maple syrup and almonds along with a gorgeous ruby brown color.  Meduim bodied and mildly sweet.
Bottle: Gorgeous ruby brown in color, with very little head. Sweet and Nutty with toasted malts abounding. Not as complex as I wanted but a very good ale none the less.

22 oz bottle.  Drank after I defended my dissertation, 4/11/06.  Poured a dark brown color with a small head.  Basically, this is Nutella beer (for those of you who have had Nutella, a chocolate hazelnut spread).  The sweet, nutty aroma almost scared me away from this one, but the more a tasted, the more I liked it.  All in all, I say this one is pretty excellent.  Rogue rocks!
Surprisingly little body to this beer in the mouth.  The sensation somehow seemed completely limited to the nose.  Nothing unpleasant about it though.

The 22 oz bottle poured a slightly hazy, dark mahogany brown colored beverage with a small off-white head that was mostly lasting and left good lacing on the glass. The aroma had a decided aroma of hazelnut, grassy hops and roasted malts. This one had a medium body with lively carbonation and a slightly thin texture although there was an alcohol warmth in the finish. The flavor started off with a sweet and nutty presence that lasted through the medium-long finish.

The commercial description is perfect. I would include sweet coffee aromas. You think its gonna be sweet from the aroma and front end flavors but to my amazement it stays totally dry. This is a very interesting brew. The color is a rich brown with a splash of red creating a slightly tawnied blood hue. Pours a chocolate milk colored froth that hangs around for a while. Overall; a very rich and aromatic brew that is ballanced. The finish is smooth and lingers.

OK, first "full" description Im gonna try.  I dont dislike it as much as the total score suggests, let me start with that.  Its AWFULLY flat, first of all, with a bit of coffee scent.  Texture is thin, almost watery.  Just an odd flavor to me, probably just not my cup of tea, but I guess my expectation was something a bit thicker than what I got.

Nice mahogany colored brown ale  from a 22 oz bottle. Rich complex aroma included hazelnut, coffee and a blend of other aromas that I can only desribe as "sweet". Sweet malty taste with a definite hazelnut quality. Very subtle hops influence. A little flat and watery, but pleasant overall.

Pours a deep, opaque brown from the 22 oz. bottle.  Antique white colored head and lacing are awfully thin.  Hazelnut aroma is present, but not overwhelming.  Hazelnut flavor is pronounced with nice malty finish.  Almost no hoppiness to it.  For me, thats a plus.  On the weak side palate-wise, but somewhat crisp.

a favorite, pours with a thin ephemberal head, with a subtle aroma that reveals little of its sweet, enchanting taste.  With elements of hazlenut, mocha, honey.  Has an amber appearance, and is thin and delicate within the mouth.
Ebony brown with a thin tan head. Aroma has a little malt, a little hazelnut, and a hint of mocha. Flavor is malty with a background of hazelnut, and a hoppy bitter finish.

A dark red color with no head.  The aroma is crisp and reminds me of a fresh (not skunked) Newcastle, but there isnt a lot there.  The flavor on the otherhand is very strong with the hazlenut.  A pleasant suprise.  Very smooth and not very heavy.  Wonderful with my pizza.

22oz bottle. Poured dark brown, almost still, into a British pint glass with a large, mostly-diminishing foamy tan head. Very nice, dense lacing. Could use a few bubbles to liven up the appearance but otherwise beautiful. Aroma is absolutely gorgeous: honey, hazelnut, toast, some coffee, butter note, background of raisins. Sweet. A feast for the nose! The flavor is comparatively indistinct.. I get coffee and a lot of toast with some assertive hop bitterness and muddled other flavors. Light alcohol (not unpleasant). Im not tasting any hazelnut. Doesnt feel like much in the mouth, thin and watery with no carbonation to speak of.. could definitely use more body, but quite drinkable at least. Id get this again just for the nose, though!

Moderately malty with definate toasty/nutty notes as well as coffee in the aroma. Body poured a deep brown with a strong, lasting head that had medium longevity. Very good flavor for the style . Medium light mouth feel.

A fizzy yet fluffy ecru head forms and dissipates over a rich, ruby/mahogany body. Nuttiness abounds in the aroma with butterscotch and soapy florals. Prominent, flavorful nuttiness and roasted flavor with praline/pecan dominating. Hop bitterness is present yet gentle, not coming off as "rancid" as I have detected in other nut browns. Mildly syrupy body with an efferevescent tingle to enliven the flavors. Although on the lighter side, this is a nice "dessert" beer.

<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462<font size=-1>

Bomber. Clear, medium brown with a small ring of a tan head. Nose is sweet malt, some light mocha notes, and, of couse nuts. I actually cracked 2 hazelnuts just to verify the flavors (not something I remembered well.) Flavor is also sweetly malty, more nuts and brown sugar flavors. Light mocha and milk chocolate notes. Mouth is slightly creamy. Lightly bitter finish. Excellent body! Insanely drinkable, and has been added to my "regular drinker" stable.

Tap.  Dark amber-mahogany in color with some cherry accents when put to candlelight.  A dime-sized bubbling grey sheaf is all the head that weve got.  Whole wheat bread and maple brown sugar sweetly waft up the nose, along with almond butter, sweet caramel ribbons and Honey Bunches of Oats with excessive maple syrup.  Sweet, nutty concoction that thrives on maple syrup out of oak vats begins the flavor regime.  Gentle, sweet slide that (rather than falling apart in the aftermath) thickens to impart a woodsy, tree bark and sweet honey roasted pecan characteristic.  Controlled carbonation breaks way for cocoa nut butter - Nutella style - likely a byproduct of the principle hazelnut contention.  Cookie crisp cereal and chocolate Honey Maid graham crackers reiterate a sweet, smooth spurge, and maple nut fudge prevails in its afterlife.  Possibly the best nut brown Ive ever had.

(Bottle) Dark brown body with a hint of red.  Medium tan head.  Very aromatic - nutty, slight alcohol, hazelnut, chocolate, vanilla, and honey.  Sweet malt flavor with hazelnut. Only slight bitterness. Best nut brown ale Ive had.

I had this as a Build" your own sample at the Flying Saucer with other brown ales. This was the best one of the bunch, but they did not have Samuel Smith to compare to head to head. Still a great beer with a smooth malty finish.

This beer offers a nice hazelnut aroma with hints of oatmeal and caramel in the background.  It is a brown solution with a cashew colored head and good lacing.  This beer offers a sweet creamy taste of hazelnuts and oatmeal.  This beer has a smooth rich characteristic that stays with it form introduction to finish.

Hops and added flavour. If I am going to have this, it might as well be on-tap. Colour-brown. I can see it appealing to some people and transitioning from coolers. A bit too much on the sweet side for my palate.

Bottle.  Bought for my father as a sub for New Castle.  (He did not enjoy it!) Pours a deep opaque brown color with a thin off white flim across the top of the beer.  Aroma is very nutty and lightly roasted.  There are notes of chocolate in the finish.  Flavor is very nice and soothing.  Notes of nut, chocolate, very light fruit notes on the tail end.  Finish is crisp and clean.  Very nice brown ale.

A hazy amber beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of alcohol and nuts. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of wood, leading to a dry end. I find the flavor quite boring.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2012 Re-rate - Bottle:  Dark brown pour with a nice, thick tan head.  Smells of maple sugar, tastes of malt, maple, caramel, and nuts.  Milder in flavor than I remeber from the first go-round, but still a decent brown ale.

Very dark brown in color, almost black, with a head that stays abruptly, until almost completely disappearing. A roasty, nutty flavor. Very smooth and malty. This beer is great cold, and not so good as it warms. It has an, almost, stout characteristic about it, especially in the aroma, with its coffee like scent. Low on the hops, and the alcohol comes through just a tad bit to strong, but lets not be to picky. A good brown ale, and another good brew from the boys and girls at Rogue.
i really liked this beer. it reminded me of nocello and nutella.  it couldve been a little thicker. but this hazelnut flavor is dead on.
very delishious brown ale they should sell it at starbucks eat a biscotti with it and chill taste of coffee just great

22oz. Bottle. Not a style I tend to seek out but it came highly recommended. Disappointment ensued. It pours a reasonably attractive brown with a swiftly vanishing head. The nose is artificial nuts, maple syrup, and sickly sweet caramel candy. The flavour is not far removed though painfully one dimensional with a mouthfeel somewhat flat and syrupy. Id have a hard time finishing a 12oz bottle of this, much less 22ozs.
Rich in flavor and complexity, well balanced and crafted, this is certainly the best of this style that I have come across.

Had a keg in my frige.  It went faster than a keg of Guinness.  Truly a fantastic beer.  Was my first nut ale here at the house.  Definately my all time favorite nut brown.  Well worth the $147 I paid for the keg

Bottle (650ml).  Been saving this one for a while ...  Poured bubbly hazy reddish-brown with a small light brown fizzy diminishing head.  Bready aroma of roast malt, roasted nuts and chocolate - a wisp of hops, and a rich, oily malt aroma that builds as it warms.  Taste is sweet roast nutty malt, chocolate, toffee, a hint of grape, and just enough bitterness backing it to keep it from being runaway sweet - very doughy and rich.  Mouthfeel is fizzy, average body, very sticky - okay, its a little watery, but still ... a damn fine and unique brown ale.  And I have a whole bomber to drink!  Prosit!

Pours a dark amber color, with a copper colored head that dissapates quickly.  Smells like chocolate and nuts, the odor just floods the nose.  It has a very distinct hazelnut taste, with strong hints of chocolate and carmel.  Great mouthfeel, through and through.  Very complex, and very enjoyable.

bottle, pours dark brown, with a medium head. aroma is of sweet caramel, brown sugar and nuts. taste is very unique. the hazelnut flavor is dominant. flavor is vary good, but seems slightly simple. you have to wait a minute between sips or you lreally loose the flavor and it starts to taste alot more watery. but if you have patients and take it slow, this beer will not dissapoint.

Pours a reddish brown with a small head.  Smells like sweet maple syrup and nuts.  It has a rich hazelnut flavor complimented by maple and caramel.  It was a little too sweet but I enjoyed it nonetheless.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2006 to be fair, the aroma was somewhat muted by a very cold storing temperature and glass.  unimpressive head, large sized bubbles.  relatively effervescent beer, with good coloring.  the real highlight is the flavor.  not particularly a brown ale fan, the first words out of my mouth to my friends were "how could anybody not like this beer?"  its delicious, and the nut flavour (not sure about the hazelnut, particularly), is substantial but not overpronounced.  great mouth feel.  rerate: wonderful aroma and a slightly sweet taste, but ultimately a brilliantly crafted beer.

Bottle: Dark brown colour, pours a beige heavy head but quickly fades. Aroma is spectacular, nutty, chocolate, sweet. Taste is silky, creamy and smooth, strong notes of hazelnut; truly a World Champion.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark reddish-brown with a small diminishing white head. Nice aroma of caramel malt, nuts and maybe even some chocolate. Delicious flavour of hazelnuts, caramel malt, roasted malt and a nice bitterness in the finish. Bodys a little thin but the mouthfeel is nice and creamy. If only all Nut Browns were this good, this is definitely the best one Ive ever had. Great stuff.
Deep brown color with a thin brown head. Nutty aroma mixed with malt. Sweet flavor of caramel mixed with malt. Some hazelnut tones in the flavor.

Beautiful deep brown color, light brown head.  An extremely nice nutty aroma with heavy malts.  Brown sugar is highly evident, light carbonation after the initial pour.  Tastes almost like maple syrup.

This is probably one of the better brown ales Ive had...the Nautical Nut is better...but I only had a small taste of that at the brewery.
Color is a dark brown with a medium mocha head.  Aroma is very subtle...a bit of roasted malts.  You can actually taste hazelnut in this beer...its pretty damn good.  Mouthfeel is smooth and dry.
Clear dark brown colour with a tan head. Malty and nutty aroma. Malty flavor with hints of caramel and nuts. Dry finish.
Deep reddish colour with a tan head. Malty, dark fruit sweet aroma with notes of nuts and bread. Malty flavor with a caramel sweetness and hints of nuts and dark fruit. Dry finish.

Tan head that disappears quickly, but hugs the side of the glass for quite some time.  Nice dark brown color with some red highlights when held up to a light.  Aroma of roasted malts, hazelnut, and some chocolate.  Taste is malts, chocolate and a nice hazelnut aftertaste, which is more pronouced as the beer gets warmer.  A Wonderful Beer!

Hazy carmel colored with a dry sweet aroma. Slighty nutty flavor, with honey and small hoppy notes on the back. Smooth, a tad sweet(but in a good way mind you), and malty...very drinkable. Nice offering.

Bottle.
Clear orange brown coloured with an off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel and dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel and dried fruits with light roasted notes..
Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Light roasted malty, nutty, chocolate aroma and taste. Medium body with a dry finish.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 This beer smelled delicious! I thoroughly enjoyed it and Im not usually a fan of "nut browns". Poured a nice deep brown into the glass with a slight whitish head that dissipated into a sporadic foam. Malt and hazlenut to the nose with some slight roasted coffee notes. Taste reflects aromas. Smooth character with a very slight bitter finish. Very good beer!

Tap @ North star bar (ok selection, but Ive only had suspect servings there).  96%ile = extremely overrated, sorry.  Pretty plain and really lacking any brown ale characteristics.  Tasted like hoppy pale ale with hints of roast malt (really bare hints).  Not a browny, and no nuts to speak of either.  I think this bar has dirty or even mixed up lines, so maybe I got misled.  Would give it another shot if someone had a bottle but thats about it, it wasnt worth my time if what I got on tap was the real stuff, way below usual rogue standards.

thanks to alobar for bringing the bottle over.  looks great, a deep brown color, like a coke or a root beer, with a nice white head about a 1/8 inch thick.  aroma has the hazelnuts as well as some chocolate and loads of malts.  flavor is almost a porter, but the hazelnuts are a very nice addition to the chocolates and malts and are in just the right amount to add to the taste without overwhelming anything.  a little bit of grittiness to the mouthfeel, but overall, an excellent ale.

Labeled Rogue Morimoto HazelNut Ale. Pours a clear brown with a beige head. Sweet and malty. Some port-likeness. Has a hint of sweet liquirish. Creamy fullness. Roasted, coffeeish finish. Nice one, though it has a not-so-good hint of sourness.

(Bottle 65 cl) Comes as "Rogue Morimoto Hazelnut Ale". Beautiful, clear dark brown with a creamy, beige head. Nutty, malty aroma. Very nutty, roasted accents - lovely flavours indeed. Almost no bitterness. 270106

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2006 Poured a translucent brown with hint of red with a  medium light tan head. Aroma is sweet malty, with a hint of something nutty--hazelnuts?...maybe, but theres definitely something there.  Flavor is full-bodied and quite malty with distinct vanilla notes.  Finshes nice and smooth, mostly sweet with only the slightest hint of bitterness.  Not incredible, but quite tasty.

From a bottle into a snifter. Beer pours a clear, dark, amber-brown color with a small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma is quite tasty: The hazelnut aroma is in the spot light, backed with heavily malty notes of roasted grain, chocolate, chocolate syrup, coffee and a light note of caramel; lightly hoppy with a note of herbs and pine with faint yeasty notes of cobwebs. Smells like a Rogueneat.  :) The flavor is heavily sweet, moderately bitter with an average-length, moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter finish. Dessert-like retronasals of Hershys syrup. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is water-to-velvety with lively carbonation.

Poured dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of hazelnut, vanilla and  caramel.  Flavor is nutty with caramel, vanilla, some coffe and chocolate along with some slight maltyness. It doesnt linger very long in your mouth which for the sweetness of the brew is probably a good thing. A very interesting and enjoyable brown ale.
One of my faves.  However, its tough to have more than one or two at a sitting.
Draft: Clear brown thin head, nice coffee more like cappuccino flavor with the hazelnut flavor but more in the aftertaste, really good and different beer.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2006 22oz Bottle GREAT, GREAT, GREAT. This is one Rogue for me. GREAT tast, Great appearance and Tast even better.

Small sample at beer tasting at From The Vine in Lewis Center, Ohio.  Dark, slightly murky brown.  Aroma nutty with vanilla and toffee.  Flavor lightly malty; nutty; prominently hazelnut; vanilla; caramel.  I would describe the mouthfeel as cool and wispy; unfortunately quite thin and watery.  Easy to drink.  Like drinking a chocolate cookie.  Unique and pleasant.

Tough to imagine a better brown ale.  Bomber.  Pours with a decent head that quickly dissipates.  Dark brown but not black in the glass.  When you take a sip, the first thing you notice is the nuttiness,  then a coffee sensation takes over.  Carbonation is adequate, not overbearing.  I just want to keep drinking and drinking it.  And maybe I will.

The aroma has hazelnuts with malt and some chocolate. The appearance is dark brown with a small head. The flavor is not bad. It has hazelnuts and malt with a light spicing. The palate is too thin. This was a great idea that could stand to be just a bit better but not bad.

pours amber brown in color with a tan head, aroma is chocolate malts, hazlenuts and coffee-like, the flavor is sweet and resembles the aroma, chocolate & hazlenut coffee flavor, with a small amount of bitterness from hops, not a bad brew.

Bomber - Sold as Morimoto Hazelnut Brown  - Pours a very dark reddish-brown in color with a medium tan head that quickly disappeared to a quite small rim around the glass.  Aroma is malty and sweet with hints of coffee, chocoilate and very faint of hazelnuts. Flavor is thick with caramel, coffee chocolate and (of course) hazelnut.  Some underlying hopiness (excellent!) Body is quite thick for a brown.  Thoroughly enjoyable... well worth repeating... my favorite Rougue Ale so far....

This beer pours a deep brown color with a deep tanned head which absolutely overflowed out of the bottle and all over my countertop...thanks Rogue...small amounts of lacing on the sides of my glass. The aroma is obviously coffee and hazelnut with a hint of chocolate and hops. The flavor is as full bodied as you can possibly expect from a brown ale with coffee and chocolate flavors extremely abundant but having caramel and hoppy undernotes as well. It leads into a caramel/nutty finish with a medium degree of carbonation and dryness. I need to face the fact that Im not a big fan of brown ales, but this isnt all too bad. The thickness of the chocolate flavor increases dramatically with the warming process.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2006 Very coffee-like.  Gobs of hazelnut which i found very enjoyable. Distinctive flavors of Rogue beers.  Very deep colored.  Will drink this again, definately.  ADD-On: My second bottle had a distinct soapy taste to it, so I poured the remainder in a second glass...same taste.. Dissapointing, though Im eager to have a third go at it.

Draft.  Pours dark, dark brown with no head.  Aroma of coffee and hazelnuts.  Taste is smooth and sweet, with the obvious hazelnuts.  Backed with coffee and roasted malts flavors.  Decent enough to have again.
One of my favorite Rogues.  Rich, dark, sweet beer.  Very enjoyable stong beer.

Bomber poured a clear reddish brown with a small amber head. Aromas of sweet malt, some nuttiness and a hint of molasses. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of hazelnuts, sweet malt,and a hint of coffee with a smooth, lingering nutty finish.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2006 Deep burgandy color when held up to bright light. Small fading tan head. Lightly sweet nutty aroma. Flavor is sweet, nutty, caramel and butterscotch with a light spicy bite on the tongue at the finish.  Kinda peanut brittle sweet. maybe too sweet and candy like. Smooth, but thin texture with lively carbonation.

dark brown body with medium brown head...aroma is of nuts and has a huge roasted malt backbone, with little else....enjoyable strong flavor of nuts, chocolate, and coffee....great palate; another good one from rogue, and a wonderful brown ale

Pours dark brown with very thin head, Nutty aroma with coffee hints. Of course lots of hazelnut in flavor which finishs with a roasty coffee like taste. Only thing that annoyed me was that it felt thin. Aftertase is awesome though. Pretty good but just too thin for me, needs alittle more body.

Morimoto bomber. Dark brown with some tannish creamy head, somewhat translucent. Nose is all nuts, hazelnuts, peanuts, maybe some almond. Taste is, you guessed it, hazelnutty delicious. Nice chocolate, toffee, and vanilla notes. Very creamy texture, albeit thin.

22oz morimoto bottle. Pours a dark rich brown color with a light off white head. Nose is tons of chocolate and hazlenuts, almost has like a peanutbrittle or peanutbutter feel to it. Taste is more of the same, lots of chocolate, toffee, and tons of nuts. very creamy mouthfeel that makes your mouth very happy.

Poors a rich dark brown.  Aroma is sweet coffee and nuts.  Coffee is strong in the flavor as well, but not too much so.  Tastes delicious and creamy.  Smooth overall and just a touch bitter at the end.  This ones definitely a keeper.

Bottle. Pours dark dark brown (definitely not black) with an ok tan head, which dissipates quickly. Aroma is... well coffee with cream and sugar, but with out the coffee. So...I guess that leaves cream and sugar. But this is different than that; there is a certain luxuriousness that great coffee brings to any coffee based concoction. The aroma has that, but no overt coffee aroma. Flavor is mysteriously devoid of chocolate, but the coffee comes back, again not in the bitter form Im used to it from most stouts and porters. Hazelnut is right, along with some cream, nutmeg, natural sugar...somehow not-too-sweet caramel and toffee malts. The feel is only rivaled by the best made oatmeal porters and stouts. Im surprised that there is no oatmeal in this, considering how smooth it is, walking that line between thick and medium bodied. Finishes like a warm hug from Juan Valdez.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 this beer is ggreat - Im becoming a big fan of but Rogue and brown ales.  THis beer is a sipping beer.  the flavor should be savored.  I will hunt for this beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Poured a dark cola brown with a sizeable creamy tan head.  Aroma was strong roasted malt with some hazelnut hints.  Initial flavor was mosted toasted malt with some nutty chocolate, coffee and caramel bursting forth and finishing with a bitter hops taste.  It was creamy and smooth on the palate, and just a tad lighter than I normally like, but as full bodied a brown ale as Ive had.  Definitely tough to go back to Newcastle after this one.
An excellent beer with a light tan head. Hazelnut and roasted malt in the aroma. Not to thick, but not watery. Nicely carbonated. Sweetish finish, made for a very delicious and drinkable beer.

Hazy mahogany, fleeting light tan head. Definitely has the hazelnut in the aroma, along with some roasted malt and maybe some floral hops. Nice feel, just right for the style, not sticky or overly thick, and just the lightest carbonation. Sweet malty flavor with roasted nuts, a little brown sugar, and jsut enough hop character to prevent it from becoming cloying. Nicely balanced and very drinkable.

I have enjoyed this beer as both the HazelNut Brown Nectar and as Rogue Morimoto HazelNut Ale.  Pours a nice dark brown color.  Aromas of nuts/chocolate/caramel.  Flavor is nutty with a nice sweet honey chocolate taste and a little coffee bitterness.  This is a great beer, no matter what the name is.

Bottle. Pours a dark ruby brown with a thin white head that quickly became a ring around the glass. Nose is sweet with lots of malts and caramel. Tastes like liquid coffee candies (especially the finish!!), with definate hints of honey and hazelnuts. Medium body, leaves a tingly feeling in my mouth even though it doesnt appear to have much carbonation. Its like a way better version of Newcastle with a ton more flavor!

Not what I expected at all, though I dont know much about brown ales yet.  I was expecting a more british malt taste with mild hopping and a bit of nuttiness.
Mine smelled not too great, a bit sour, perhaps it was old.  Flavour on the other hand was wonderful!  Nutty, chocolatey without straying too far from tasting ike beer, or becoming one or two dimensional.  And, just to be silly I dipped a brownie in it, and it was delicious!

(22 oz bottle: $4.29 at Hi-Time Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA) Brown ales arent the most exciting of beers, but if youre gonna brew one, and youre the brewer for Rogue, you throw down the gauntlet and brew a kick ass brown.  This is an absolutely delicious nut brown ale with a very potent and sweet caramel flavor that tastes just like candy caramels.  And damn, it smells like caramel candies too!  Plenty of hazelnut , chocolate and honey in the flavor, and bitterness is very mild from start to finish.  Medium bodied, moderately carbonated, but it becomes a bit cloying now that Im polishing off the second half of this bomber.  Dark ruddy brown in color, clear in appearance, but too dark to see through.  Unfortunately, the dark tan head is bubbly and fizzy, so though it starts off at nearly an inch, it dissipates fairly rapidly down to a ring.  Yeah sure, it might be too sweet for some people, and it does seem pretty sugary sweet to me, but its just so damn tasty!  Easily my favorite brown ale.
This beer had an excellent appearance.  It tasted a bit like coffee or carmel.  A nice smooth beer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2005 Had during a beer tasting party.  Poured dark brown with smells of caramel, hazelnut coffee.   Would have enjoyed more if the tastes was dialed down to just a hint, not something strong enough to drink all day at work and not have anyone know because it looked, smelled, and tasted so much like coffee.
Pours deep mahogany brown with thin lacing white head.  Honey, nut, brown sugar aroma.  Solid nutty, sweet sugar, light coffee flavor.  Creamy smooth palate.

Pours reddish brown with a thin tan head.  Short retention.  Smell had caramel, hazelnut, honey and caramel.  Taste is like hazelnut coffee plus caramel and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is nice but a little thin for my personal taste.  This was good.  Im glad I got this.

Thanks to Fatty.  Pours a reddish brown with a small tan spotty lacing head.  Aroma of nuts, honey, caramel and brown sugar.  Flavor of nuts (hazelnut), creamy, caramel and a general sweetness.  If you like hazelnut coffee give this a try.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2006 Bottle rated November 19th, 2005 - Pours reddish brown with a fully receding.  Aroma is toasted malts, plums, slightly vinous, with a nice toffee balance.  Taste has lots of sweet toasted maltiness with a bit of the raisin/plum character.  Faint notes of chocolate and vague hop bitterness linger barely under perception. One of the few beers deserving of the "Nut Brown Ale" title. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied but has a slight stickiness.  Quite enjoyable. 
Ar 8 Ap 4 Fl 7 Mf 5 Ov 16 = 4.0

Bottle Rated August 18th, 2006 - Pours dark amber with a thin foamy mocha head. Aroma of hazelnut and toffee. Taste is sweet and nutty, with an artificial tasting hazelnut extract flavor. Mouthfeel is medium/full bodied and slightly sticky. Ratings averaged. 
Ap 4 Ar 6 Ta 6 Mf 4 Ov 12 = 3.2

Dark brown ale with a golden tan head that dissolves quickly.  Taste of dark chocolate, almond, and obviously hazelnut.  This beer definitely reminds me of an iced hazelnut coffee, maybe even a little mocha.  I like the uniqueness of the taste, but cant decide if Im a fan or if it is just something different

nice take on the "nut brown ales" pours nice and reddish brown with a nice head that stays all the way till the last drop. nice smell. like iced hazelnut coffee. the taste is nutty with hints of chocolate covered cherries. quite pleasent. nice till the end. had another one as I type this right now!!!!

Brown/auburn in color with a light tan dissipating head.  Strong nutty aroma.  Mouth fills with the hazlenut taste, and leaves a nice impression on the palate.  Very malty.   I wish there was a little bit more spice, that is the only thing I see keeping this fro mbeing exceptional.
Nothing too fancy here, but a nice alternative to the crazy hoppy beers so popular right now.

From Bottle

Poured brown that when held up to the light amberish color shined through. Light brown head that didnt last to long. Aroma was of faint chocolate and fruits. Taste to me was just like the Rogue Chocolate Stout with less chocolate. Some floral and nutty notes near the middle and in the finish. A little bitter toward the end when the beer warmed, also I could faintly taste the alcohol in it as it warmed.

Dark brown with a nutty flavor and smooth finish.  This is the beer that got me hooked on Rogue Ales.  Found it in a pizza place on Hilton Head Island and have been buying Rogue Ales ever since at Discount Liquor in Waukesha.  Truly a nectar of the gods!

Bottle. Pours hazy, oaky chestnut brown with creamy beige head. Rich aroma of cappuccino, vanilla/Irish creme, chocolate, and hazelnut. Mostly sweet, creamy flavors of hazelnut and malts - like Whoppers candy. Low carbonation and velvety mouthfeel. Could use a bit more hops for balance, but creamy sweetness has its place, too. A tasty, complex beer.

Rogue attracts me with their great bottle art.  Poured very nicely, with a brown tight head lacing quickly and evenly. Smell was amazing, beery, but with a hazelnut ice cream smell. The taste is odd. Im not sure hazelnut matches the taste of hops very well. Definite caramel maltiness, not too sweet, and full mouthfeel with a hint of pleasant graininess. A bit of chocolate taste complements the filbert flavour, but the dessert taste wars with the spicy saaz hops, IMO. I think Id really like this beer without the adjuncts, and the adjuncts without the beer.
Hazelnut dominates the aroma and its awesome. Very smooth, buttery, lots of hazelnut in the flavor, well rounded and robust with a touch of hops. A very nice brown, and very different and distinct.
Almost black color with minimal tan head.  Malty and sweet.  Hints of cherries.  Lively beer that sits on the tongue.  Roasty, bitter finish.
Not bad, although the tatse of hazelnut faded with each sip. Good in a pinch though.
Ive never had a beer quite like this.  This brown ale seems more like a stout to me.  If you are a stout lover and you enjoy hazelnut coffee, this is a must try for you.
A bit too nutty characteristics for me. Kind of earthy, not that appealing to me. A quality-made beer, but it just doesnt do it for me.

One of the best rogue beers.  This beer was extremely creamy, with a tasty chocolate, hazelnut and caramel flavor. And if you dont like a good amount of bitterness in your beers (I do to a degree), this beer will do it for you.  Very smooth going down.  I will definitely try again.

Great aroma and appearance.  A good feel in the mouth and great tastes of coffee with a hint of hazelnut.  This is one that I tried to clone and I found that I prefer just a little more hazelnut flavor, but an excellent beer in the rogue line up.
Super creamy, nutty, almost "cream soda" taste to it. Buttery but not a great deal of flavor in this one: fairly one dimensional.

Nice reddish color with a coffee, nutty aroma.  This is one beer that is as good on tap as it is in the bottle.  One of the best beers in the Rogue lineup and is a must try.  Finishes very smooth and clean with very little bitterness that makes you want to continue to drink this to make sure its true as you think.  Wonderful beer.

(Knoxville Brewers Jam). Pours reddish brown with a beige head. The aroma is caramel and a bit of butterscotch. The flavor is just a bit on the buttery side, but boasts brown sugar, hazelnut coffee, and just a touch of salinity. Smooth.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2006 Pours a reddish brown with a one finger head that quickly recedes to a thin ring, with mild lacing.

Smells sweet, nutty, mild chocolate, and roasted malts.

Taste was some chococalte, hazelnut, caramel, with a sweet malty finish. Color me crazy, but this reminds me somewhat of a dopplebock when it gets a litte warmer. This one goes down very smooth, with only a touch of bitterness.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text:
tastes like Postum-flavored soda, burnt root beer, earthy, charcoal and dirt, cant find the hazelnuts unless they toasted the shells . . .

light bubbly mouth feel, not frothy, but weak and insubstantial, incandescent and tinny

aftertaste of smoke and fish, weird tingly head rush

.

Rich, creamy, almost tastes like im sipping on a root beer or something. Browny and a little stinky, kinda like my underpants looked the morning after this. Dont be afraid, however, its one of the best that I have had yet. Thin palate, needs a little more meat to it. Nutty aroma, and a smooth "Don Steele" type of aftertaste. Cheers!
Honestly one of the best Ive ever had. Sweet bubbly flavor, with a good aftertaste. Great stuff.

This dark brown ale poured with a short tan head, eliciting a malty aroma. There is  a slightly carbonated mouthfeel and a chocolate malty flavor with a slightly bitter hoppy finish. A very nice brown ale.

Aroma of roasted barley and nuts with a sugary sweetness toward the end. Dark brown with hints of amber and a medium sized tan head. Huge hazlenut flavor overwhelms the palte from fore to finish. Tastes like Coffee Mate Hazlenut Creamer in a weak cofee. It does however taste good just overpoweringly one dimensional and not very beer like.

Had a sweet roasty hazelnt nectar aroma. Brown body and decent head. A decent creamy rich nut flavor appeared in the middle. Otherwise I would of thought this beer is just a medium bodyied nut somewhat watery beer. .
black w/ brown head.  hazelnut aroma indeed, w/ a note of chocolate.  full bodied, creamy texture w/ chocolate flavor. nutty.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Had this again on tap after some time apart. Its a pretty pour with a deep brown color and a tan head. The nose packs plenty of sweet, though roasty, hazelnut scents. Hazelnut is right up front in the flavor, but its adequately smoky to keep things from being annoyingly fake. Soy sauce, chocolate, and nuts make up the flavor basically. Its a shade too sweet to be completely exquisite, but when Im in the mood for a sweet beer, this does the trick. Again, plenty of smoky, semi-meaty flavors are present to keep this from being one dimensional or cloying. Its a nice beer.


[June 9, 2008]

Bomber at Pisa Pizza. Its been a while since Ive had this one. The nutty quality is more out of hand than I remember. Pure flavors of nuts are all over the place on this one. Its not bad, it actually imparts a nice roasty, chewy quality to the entire brew. Sometimes this walks the line of being too sweet, but its not bad. I often think of brown ales as having a nutty quality, this one takes it to the next level.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Bottle. Dark colored, large head. Sweet, chocolaty and nutty aroma. Sweet, Rich, full bodied, nutty, chocolate notes, roast and bready hints. Unique beer, very tasty and very smooth.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2006 [bottle] This is definitely one of the best brown ales Ive ever had the pleasure of trying. Pours a dark caramel brown with a full head. Enormous malts balanced with excellent nutty sweetness- dark, smooth caramel ending with a excellent finish. This is excellent.
UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Pours dark with a tan head.  This beer has big taste. Rich. Full. Dark. Smooth. Malty with strong notes of chocolate and hazelnut.

Head goes quick.  Choclate Smell.  Dark Brown color. First taste is very toffee hazelnut 
coffee.  Nothing too bitter pretty smooth sweet finish.  If it had more alcohol it would be much better.

This is the number one rated brown ale, ya right...Pours a dark brown colour, good head at first, laces well..some coffee in back, bitters r OK nice subtle after taste..could be sweeter and the content was present..
One of my favs.  Nice brown color and decent head.  Caramel and nut aroma with a very smooth malty caramel flavor.  I could drink this all day.  Very sweet finish.

Bomber bottle. Dark brown color with medium light brown head that diminished slowly. Full hazelnutand roasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with smooth texture. Good flavor of hazelnut, malt and caramel with medium sweet finish.

Bottle sweet aroma caramel, slight roasty, with a hint of maltyness.  Small light tan head that dissaprears quickly.  Very thin light mouth feel.  Slight bitter foretaste with a sweet hazelnut finish.  Would drink again but dont belive should be rated so high.
very very very femine tasting. has a kinda caramel sweet taste. good beer to give your girlfriend.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2006 Awesome beer... very sweet start with a perfect roasted coffee finish.  very smooth.  Awesome on tap, great from a bottle.  Smooth frothy head with a slight carmel taste throughout
Got a bottle of this while on vacation in Ocean City MD. Pours with a small brown head and a medium body. Aroma was malty and the mouth was nutty with tones of chocolate.

Bottle: Ruby brown, large foamy light beige head, very nice lacing, very light carbonation. &nbsp Grainy/nutty nose, moreso on the side of nutty, with a huge honey and even moreso Honeycomb cereal aroma. &nbsp Totally Honeycomb cereal like... DAMN! &nbsp Seems a touch too sweet for my taste, at least on the nose. &nbsp Quite sweet on the tongue, honey, malty, but quite smooth to say the least. &nbsp Big body, honeycomb cereal dominates, with a rather smooth mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes rather sweet, malty, with loads of honey and even graham crackers. &nbsp Very slight chocolate malt profile throughout. &nbsp Good, very drinkable, but basically too sweet for my tastes.
A nice nutty twist to a tradional brown ale. Nice deep brown color with good nutty flavor. Another solid entry from Rogue.
Draft somewhere west of Portland on the way to the coast.  Sorry, dont care for hazelnut flavor in my coffee, and now I find that I dont want it in my beer.  Lindt hazelnut chocolate, anytime.

Pours a beautiful hazy deep amber brown color with a small amount of quickly dissapating tanish head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity, milky, and slighly hazelnut.  Flavor is a sweet hazelnut, not like in a coffee, but altogether different.  Slightly fruity undertone with a clean crisp finish.  Overall, I found this enjoyable but I think its too sweet and lactic for me to drink more than a bomber.

Draught. Hazy brown color with a thin head. Prominent hazelnut nose. Moderate carbonation. Definite hazelnut flavor with milk chocolate undertones. At one point I felt like I was tasting a chocolate milkshake. Very smooth finish. Not for everyone, but gives some flair to the normally pedestrian brown ale style.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 Hazy darker amber, moderate head, some lacing and retention. Aroma is big time hazelnut, caramel, chocolate, light hopping and other nutty notes. Medium bodied, dominated by the hazelnut flavor... almost vanilla like. Its always interesting to look back on flavored beers like this. At one point this was mindblowing, now its one dimensional and sloppy.

Always one of my favorites.  Dark brown colour, and thick tan head that slides down the glass till the finish if its not too cold.  Amazing maltiness that waltzes around the hazelnut and weaves a brown that cant be touched by anything even close to it.  How the hell can they hide that much hoppiness in a brown?

The first Rogue I ever had, and the beer that changed my High Life addiction.  Always near my heart, thanks guys.

This so called "brown ale" is much much more! After pouring it into a pint class there wasnt too much halzelnut aroma. I thought it was a hoax. But once it took a gulp..man alive! it was like drinking a hazlenut coffee coolatta! Daamit! Such a beer to savor. I bought 6 bottles to make sure everyone I knew could try it. This beer is one to introduce at a party...show uneducated Coors Light drinkers what kind of beer they can be trying.

Bottle: Beautiful dark brown pour with a thick and dense tan head.  Chocolaty aromas dominate.  The taste is pleasant with choco-nut creamy coffee flavors.  Sweet malts is the word on this one.  The carbonation was more than average and the body was thinner than expected - being that "nectar" was in the name!  I was thinking of a Kerns brown ale.  Imagine that!  Overall, a great brown ale.  I enjoyed it.

This pours a very dark amber-brown with a relatively weak and diminishing off white head.  The nose is very malty with strong hints of brown sugar and perhaps mahagony.  The flavors are relatively subtle: there is a definite brown sugar and woodiness upfront, a surprisingly German-tasting maltiness in the middle, and the bitterness is more of a tart sourness that lingers in the end.  Theres a strong dark chocolate presence in there also that makes it strongly resemble a porter.  This is a very good beer.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2006 strong and potent nutty malt aroma.  reddish orange in color.  hazelnut in aftertaste. maple syrup and malts.  complex.  the best brown ale ive tried.

Nice brown/dark amber color.  Smells sweet, malts, caramel.  Tastes obviously nutty, sweet hazelnut, a little biscuit/roast in the back.  Very smooth.  Excellent beer.  Bottles at Redlight Redlight in Winter Park, Fl.

(22 oz. bottle) Pours a deep coppery brown, nice biscuit head, some lacing. Notes of caramel and coffee. Mouthfeel mostly smooth, a little fizzy.  Flavor, smoothness and whole experience gets better as you drink it. I taste more coffee and chocolate than nuttiness though. Mmm yummy smooth.
Pours brown with a minimal head. Interesting aroma of hazelnut, brown sugar, and malts. Nutty flavor with slight roasted notes and some brown sugar sweetness. Long-lasting aftertaste. Very smooth.

One the best Ive had and a new favorite! Light brown head with good lacing. Deep brown color. Smells of caramel, brown sugar, and cinnamon. Nice malty flavors, moderate chocolate. Medium, creamy body. Nice to have around!

Very nice, creamy and dark with a nice smoky flavour.  There is a definite nuttiness to this one that is often lacking in other nut brown beers.  Its really very well done.  I actually had some packaged incorrectly in the wrong bottle.

Deep brown with a small tan head that vanishes quickly.  Aroma is mild nutty, roasted malts.  Flavors are what really make this one though; Hazelnut, roasted malt, toffee, caramel.  Heavy and creamy with just enough hoppy bitterness to keep the finish dry, crisp and smooth.  Outstanding!

Deep brown pour with a thin creamy head.  Hazelnut powered the aroma, followed by some vanilla, sweet malts, and toffee.  Hazelnut, brown sugar, and vanilla provided much of the flavor.  There was a hint of chocolate.  Very smooth mouthfeel and long hazelnut finish... almost like I had just finished a cold cappuccino (but in a good way).

22 oz bottle from Windy City El Cajon.  I am not a big brown ale fan.  But I may have found one I can stand.  Aromas were not much to speak of,  caramel and some toffee, but the flavors really kicked in.  I first tasted the head and the hazelnut actually surprised me.  Then in the beer, hazelnut and vanilla and cream.  Very creamy and very smooth.  But then that familiar Brown Ale taste to finish it off....  I liked it, but its still a Brown Ale.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2005 wow.  way impressed with this one.  had it on tap at summits in cumming.  this was so creamy and nutty.  i can still remember every hint of flavor in this one.  almond and honey roasted peanuts.  vanilla and heavy creams are makin this shit work for me yo.  perfectg brown with the creamiest tan head ever.  this was really frickin amazing.  two thumbs up.

pours a dark brown with slight toffee aroma. taste is of a mix of a maple chocolate merge with  lots of nut flavor throughout .  very malty from beginning to end on this one... another good one from rogue

Chocolate brown color with a medium head.  Sweet aroma of nuts.  Theres definitely a hazelnut blast in the taste.  Sweet maple syrup and brown sugar round it out.  Malty base; the hops never really show up.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2006 I too was expecting some cheap coffee flavoring of hazel nut. I should of given Rogue the benefit of the doubt, for this is the real deal.  Brownish red in appearance with tan head that dissipates quickly. Slight lace remains. Not much in the nose, but tons in the taste. Sweet nuttiness with a malty brown sugar evident through my entire gulp. Absolutely delicious. Imagine if you took all the subtle flavors of New Castle and exaggerated them. Best brown ale I ever have had. 

Rerate: Alchohol is almost impossible to detect. Although this does taste a little sour to me this time. lowering score accordingly. 

Yet another rerate: This beer keeps getting worse in my book. Artificial tootsie roll flavor..slightly sour....

Pours deep amber red with a cap of light tan head. Quite dark for a brown ale, but held up to the light it still has a nice sparkle. Aromas of toffee, fresh clean yeast with subtle fruitiness, some spicy notes, and maybe a hint of hazelnut. Or maybe a hint of the power of suggestion. Honestly, given the name, I was definately expecting a blast of hazelnut extract. But its not there, and I think I like it better that way. It doesnt seem like a "flavored" beer. And speaking of flavors. Rich toffee flavor with some good understated hop bitterness. Initially sweet, but with a dry, clean finish that keeps it from feeling sticky in the mouth. A very smooth, well-rounded beer.

Deep brown in color with a thin white head.  Subtle nutty smell with some malty and hoppy hints.  Sweet rich nutty taste without much else there in regards to taste.  Long lasting sweet nutty aftertaste.  By far the best brown ale Ive ever had.

draught at Flying Saucer


Nutty!! hehe.  Seriously this is a very good brew.  Tons of taste.  Lots of nutty flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2006 Probably the best brown ale ive ever had.  This beer erupts with flavors of, you guessed it, hazelnuts and nectar.  Slighty fruity aftertaste which is hard for me to like, but rogue pulled it off in this case.

Sesame aroma. Nice amber brown, with a tan head. SUPER toffee and hazlenuts. This is awesome! My new favorite brown ale, bar none. Amazing stuff. This will get an elaborate rerate sooner or later. Aftertaste and palate are smooth, buttery and overly nutty. Good stuff! Hops do a nice balancing act.
Better than average, but not spectacular. The aroma of nuts is very appearant,  feels a little watery, malt is reconizable. overall. I like this, but I had better

hmmm, complex.  Im not really sure how to describe the flavors here.  It fit the style and name as an excellent brown with a very subtle hazelnut flavor.  Probably more toffee and chocalate.  Very smooth and complex.  Must try again.

Ive never had a bad Rogue product, but this one may be the best.  If I count correctly it has 7 different malts; its easy to notice something new with each one.  When my wife sees the empty bomber bottles in the basement it makes her send me out for more.

Bottle. Medium brown aroma, light tan head, though not much remnant lacing. Aroma is nutty, good malt aroma, good balance to it. Flavor has a nice amount of maltiness, chocolatey and caramel notes hanging in the background, not too much hopiness. The hazelnut flavor is the main feature, it really ties everything together well. Medium body, carbonation might be a little high, but the nut flavor hung around and coated my mouth. A nice beer, and an excellent example of the style, an enjoyable beer.

Pours well, brown in colour! Small beige head. Aroma of rich toffee/caramel, nuts, chocolate and raisins. Flavour is sweet chocolate and caramel, balanced out with a mildly bitter finish. Some fruity notes evident. Not bad, but nothing special.

Pours a clear reddish brown color with a thin offwhite head. Mild aroma of malt and hazelnut. Mild flavor of malt and nuts, the finish leaves a chalky and dry feeling. Light to medium body, soft carbonation. This is a major let down, I used to love this beer but now either my tastes have changed or the quality of the beer has gone downhill.

Pours beautifullywith a deep reddish brown body and a beige head that tends to discipate rather quickly.  The scent is subtler than is to be expected considering the powerful flavour.  Strong hazelnut/chocolate/caramel flavour that goes down beautifully smooth and leaves a tart feeling on the sides of the tongue.  My one critique is that this beer was a bit too carbonated for my liking, that was not enough, however, to ruin the truly awesome taste of this beer.  THis beer tastes like it should be served as desert!
Pours a dark mahogany color, small off white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, and some nuttyness. Flavor is nutty, almonds, caramel, very sweet, but not over the edge. Very nice!

Smells if faintly alcoholic, faintly malty, but light overall. This is a quite refreshing beer, and really not that heavy. The hazelnut flavoring is light, but noticeable and the right amount. rogue is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries.

Pours a nice golden brown with a small tan head. Smell is overwhelmingly of hazelnut wth nutty malty overtones. Light sweetness in the nose, hints of vanilla or almond?

Taste is much like the smell. Roasted malt followed by overpowering taste of the hazelnut extract. Lightly sweet and lightly smoky. A surprising bitter hoppy finish with a lightly malty aftertaste on the tongue, then you are tasting the hazelnut again. Hints of nutty vanilla or almond too. For me, the strong hazelnut prevent it from being really drinkable but it is still very smooth. A complex and tasty brew. Definitely not my favorite from rogue but I would not hesitate to try it again.

Dark brown. Nice fluffy head. Moderate carbonation.
Robust chocolatey nutty aroma. Man this stuff really smells great.
I didnt know what a hazelnut tasted like until I took a drink of this. I like hazelnuts. The choclateyness really works well with the nuttyness. This medium bodied beer seems to stick around in you mouth for a while. Man this is good. Probably the best Rogue ale Ive tried so far.

Bouteille de 650 ml obtenue par importation privée via Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de café aux noisettes et de chocolat. Apparence: Couleur brune rougeâtre. Aucun col. Densité moyenne des bulles. Saveur: Goût facilement détectable de noisette. On y percois aussi un léger goût de sésame et de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Corps moyen avec une texture huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût de noix. (Rating #133)
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  Very sweet aroma with coffee and chocolate scents.  Very smooth. Malty tases with a surprising amount of hops at the finish. Very nice brew.
Dark amber color.  Sweet and smooth with a hint of honey.  It wasnt as nutty as I expected.  It had a very interesting tang to it.
tastes like coffee mixed with swiss mix hot chocolate. you can definatly taste the hazelnut. creamy mouthfeel and a coffee chocolate aroma. very good. no head  very dark brown body.

Pours transparent brown with ruby overtones.  Tan head clings to the side of the glass.  The aroma is hazelnut coffee and hops.  The first sip made me say wow now there is something different.  The flavor is amazing. The hazelnut flavor really comes through in the first sip.  I let the glass warm a little while reading some of the reviews here and I think that was wise.  This is bursting with goodness from a style that I usually find quite drab.  There is also malt and some roasted flavor and even some vanilla.  I think it is very balanced and while it isnt too thick it feels good in the mouth almost buttery.  This is my favorite nut brown ale now.  My first rating of a Rogue beer as well and I must say Im quite impressed with this one.

Bottle: Poured a dark brown color ale with a foamy dark head with average retention. Aroma is nutty from the hazelnut flavour and malty with some roastiness. Taste is quite enjoyable with the hazelnut easily identifiable and roasted malt balancing everything else. Overall, I would say that this is a very good session beer.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2005 This nectar pours a translucent brown with an enourmous tan head that slowly dissipates.  Lots of sweet, enticing nuttiness in the nose.  Great, smooth mouthfeel.  Caramel, chocolate and other candied flavors blend beautifully in the body.  A bit thin - but no real complaints.

Pours brown with ruby tones as well.  Thin beige head.  Malty, fruity aroma.  Not much of this carries through to the flavor.  Hazelnut, coffee, vanilla, and toffee in the flavor.  Kind of thin on the malt in the flavor for a Nut Brown.

650ml bottle from Utobeer. Pours dark brown with reddish hues. Aroma is suprisingly smoky with sweet malt and nuts. Flavour is sweet with unpleasent sourness and some stale malt character. There is some sort of nut evident but the beer is dominated by unpleasentness. Meh!

from the bottle. poured a mahagony with a nice tan head. witch some nice lacing. aromawhat else but hazelnut, honey, brown sugar, malts, a nice nuttyness, plums and raisins. flavor unfortunately they were weak, but did get some hazelnut, honey and just a touch of coffee.
pours dark brown with an off white head. strong hazelnut aroma and flavor, sweet smooth finish,
Probably the best of the micros.  Still not that  great.  This is pretty much a glorified Newcastle.

Bottle. Deep ruby brown with a thin beige head. Smells nutty and seriously malty with a hint of smokiness. Malty sweet flavors of hazelnut, toffee, chocolate, some coffee, and again more hazelnut coming up huge in the finish. Hop bitterness is there to attempt to balance this out, not an easy task, but done well enough to smooth this one out. Plenty of mouthfeel and ligering dessert like sweetness. Excellent after dinner beer-let it sit and warm up during dinner for maximum flavor at dessert time.

Yum! Pours like I want a brown ale to pour.  Smells malty in a powerful way.  Hazelnut (obviously), Spree candy, vanilla, and whole wheat were all invited to the party in my mouth.  Palate is perfectly balanced rich smoothness with just the right amount of carbonation and subtle, supportive hops.  Cinishes clean, sweet, and tasty.  I like it!

Off white head, nice retention.  Heavy red color with brown accents.  Nice malt aroma with a deep nuttiness.  Little to no hop presence in the aroma.  Full mouthfeel, almost like a latte.  Malty nose with nut notes, continues subtley until an immense burst of hazelnut in the finish.  Another very coffee-like sensation, having that hazelnut flavor linger with some malt backing.  This beer really tastes like a smooth beer hazelnut latte.  Surprisingly refreshing.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 Second time around with a head to head match up with New Glarus Nut Brown I was stunned that this beer had no body.  Good nut flavor but no substace.  I would not, not drink it if you offered it to me though!!

I sampled the 1 pt. 0.9 fl. oz. bottle, which pours a slightly cloudy, dark copper colored body with a small, quickly vanishing tan head; there was no appreciable lacing.  The aroma is rich with nuts and chocolate, while the palate entry is lightly sweet.  Mid-palate also reveals nuts and milk chocolate, but also vanilla and caramel.  The finish is malty with only light hops.  This is a medium-bodied ale that is best enjoyed at 50F-60F.

Malt and nut aroma ,distinct but not strongtaste is smooth creamy carmel vanilla and hazelnut. This is hard to score, because I really dont like hazelnut coffee, but I know this is a well made beer, and if I liked hazelnut, I would have rated this very high
She smell really sweet but when i tasted it have a strong bitter entry and finish with a taste of sweet hazelnut. Really good

Aroma:hazelnut,wood,chocolate....
Appearance:Brow with very small head...
Flavor:hazelnut,bit of chocolate and vanilla...

Pleasant but slight hazelnut aroma with a very minimal bit of chocolate flavor at the finish
Very tasty beer!

Tasted like Frangelico.  Not nearly as much aroma as you would expect though (very light and almost non-existent.  Not nearly as sweet or as heavy as I expected.  In fact, the mouth feel was a little watery.  I thought it tasted and smelled delicious.  Not what I think of though when I think of a brown ale.  

I would buy again and again but must be drunk in the right context.  I think it would be difficult to pair with foods other than desserts (although its not that sweet).  

I really enjoyed it.

Pours brown with a thick tan head that is moderately diminishing.  Nose is cream and hazelnut.  The flavor is the same, with a nice coffee balance and hops at the end.  Sweet and creamy, very good mouthfeel.  Not many bubbles.  Yum.

Blackish and ruddy dark brown that was clear until I poured in the brown yeast.  Head was light brown, but receded to absolutely nothing after not long.  Inviting aroma of toasted hazlenuts, bourbon, vanilla, and a little woodsmoke.  Packed with flavour: hazlenut, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, roasted and rauch-malt.  All said, it has not been lost that this is a sweet brown ale.  There is some faint hops flavour and a tiny bit of bitterness.  Medium to full body with low to mild carbonation.

Hazelnut extract nose that is extremely overpowering. Sweet almost cloying on the palate. Roasted malts clash with the extract, almost a pvc type flavor at the end. Vanilla and hazelnut finish overly sweet.

This has the most complex flavor of any brown Ive ever had. Pours a clear brown, smells like hazelnut, coffee, toffee. As the beer warms up, the flavors really come out. This is definitely a sipper. Delicious!
smooth with tons of malt.. roasted nut flavors with a good sweetness.  great mouthfeel.  blows newcastle brown out of the water IMO which was previously my favorite brown. buy this now
This is a wonderful brew.  Tastes of chocolate and coffee--almost like a frappucino with Baileys.  Dark, with a creamy mouthfeel.  This is good stuff.

bottle. opaque mahogany colour with a small white head. lots of sweet milk chocolate aroma, some roastiness and a hint of hazelnut. flavour is much better than the aroma displays. smooth, malty, nutty, roasty. medium body. the nutty finish is spectacular. great beer.
WOW! John Maier has out done himself with this brown ale! Seriously amazingly executed. Smooth from the first sip to the last. Questionably the best ROGUE!

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 Pours with little off-white head and looks like coffee.  Sweet nutty scent and strong coffee aftertaste.  Probably the best nutbrown ale Ive had.  You have to love the Rogue bottles, too.  RERATE.  every once and a while ill crave one of these, and it never disappoints.

First taste of this beer is all hazelnut and sugar. After a few sips you can appreciate this taste and recognize the smooth brown ale beneath it. Chocolate, honey, and maple syrup flavors. Smooth, light-to-medium mouthfeel. Sweetness overwhelms any hops or bitterness that might be hidden in the brew.

Nectar is right -- this beer is exceptionally sweet.  The malty flavor (because theres negligible hop to it, and only enough yeast to give it the characteristic Rogue-ness) is very sweet, and dominated by the nutty flavor that is its namesake, rather than the roastiness that helps out in the color.  Could have stood to be drier and roastier.

Cloudy, reddish brown. Tart, malty and grainy aroma with some vanilla and toffee. Somewhat thin in body but with a slight nutty finish that asks for more. Vanilla and hazelnut are prominent in the flavor, as is caramel and vanilla. First had on draught in 1995. Still a contender for the best American Brown.

Gorgeous, dark brown color, light brown head, with fine bubbles.  Aroma is slighly sweet and of toasted nuts.  And the initial flavor is a caramelly-chocolatey version of the same nutty aroma.  Lightly bitter finish.  My new favorite beer.
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2005 pours a dark brown.  the flavor is strong and especially nutty.  also stong on toasted malt flavor.  slight hint of chocolate as well. a very good beer.

On tap at Coles in Buffalo. I love browns, so I was waiting to have this for a while. Pours a dark amber brown color with a thick light tan head that thinned out quickly. Good roasted chocolate, slightly hopped, nutty aroma. Medium mouthfeel. Sweet, nutty, caramel flavor. Smooth. Slightly bitter. Nice bittery finish. Very good brown. I think I need to try this out of a bottle.

Pours brown with a small head. Aroma is of biscuit, toasty malt, a slight chocolate and hazelnut. Flavor is hazelnut with a thin grainy biscuit. A slight hoppy bitterness merges in during the finish. Light bodied and slightly thin in the malt backing but the hazelnut flavors are outstanding.

Nectar is a most apt name for this lovely winter concoction.  Nose is sweet, with incredible honey and caramel notes.  Pours a syrupy amber with thin, white head.  Flavors of caramel, milk chocolate, maple, honey, and (obviously) hazelnut.  Light to medium bodied.  Quick, oily finish with a touch of fizz and a last-minute caramel/hazelnut smoothness at the very end.  I thoroughly enjoyed this one - would definitely buy again.  (Bottled as Morimoto Signature Hazelnut Ale)
Smooth, nutty, chocolately (nutella?), with a dark chocolately body and shallow beige head.  Vague suggestion of caramel, lighter body than I expected but easy to drink in a pleasant way.

On draught at Barleys in Knoxville, Feb 2005.  Thick looking, transluscent brown body, but a very rapidly disappearing beige head.  Aroma of chocolate, nuts, pac-men and honey.  Flavor has a big dose of chocolate and hazelnut up front.  While I cant say the hazelnut is wonderfully authentic (Id rather it was fresh ground hazelnut then the syrupy sweet tasting extract) tasting, it is at least, not overdone.  Honey, maple and light caramel round out the flavor, with a finish of maple-cream butter and more chocolate malts.  Little hops apparency, just some earthiness.  Body, was sadly quite light and watery.  Perhaps the kegs having traveled so far hurt the beer, so I will have to try this one again.  It didnt taste old though, so Im not sure.  Low carbonation.
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2005 Sweet, nutty flavor that was far more smooth than I expected.  Brown in color with tan head.  Very excellent.  Would certainly try this one again.

Bottled.  Ive been looking forward to trying this beer for a while.  Pours a deep brick/brown, a small frothy head quickly fell to nothing, and carbonation is very light.  Aroma is very light, sweet maltyness, hazelnut extract (mmmm!!), really nothing else(?).  Flavor is smooth, with light malt and very nutty bitterness, quite nice.  Carbonation bites my tongue a little and the body is much lighter that I would have expected.  All in all highly drinkable brown ale, just wasnt as robust ("EL GRANDE NUTZ!!!!!!") as I thought it would be.

Hands down the BEST brown ale Ive had...and I LOVE the "nectar!" (dont ask)....Brown appearance (hence, brown ale), creamy, sweet, roasted malts, lots of nuts going on there, and smooooooooth, baby.  Wow, this push to 200s kicking my ass.

Dark brown ligke a cola with light brown head.. Malty aroma roasted chocolaty flavour ..Smooth palate.. soft background of hazelnuts that bounces off the roastedness and light bitter of hops.. great beer...
poured a brown color with little to no head.  Chocolate smell.. Very heavy on the hazelnut and chocolate flavors.  finishes with a little bitternes.  Very Nice brown ale..

Bottled: Reddish brown coloured. Clear. Light brown and dense head. Loads of chocolate, sweetness and some fruit in the aroma. Flavour is dominated by chocolate as well. Is rather sweet and light malty and fruity. Is smooth and light hoppy. Ends on a light bitter note. Is medium bodied.
Really enjoyed this brown (again, not my style) Roasted maltiness in aroma.  Mocha Hazelnut flavor and finish with a nice balance of hoppiness.  Id like another.
Deep color with little to no head.  Big toasted nose to it.  Great smooth flavors of toasted nuts mixed with a touch of molasses.  Nice light hop to it.  Very clean finish.

22oz bomber. Tasted @ 50°+. Brown with a khaki head. Malty, mild hops, hazelnut aroma. Malty, chocolate, mild roastiness, coffee?, hazelnut. Nice mouthfeel, aftertaste is moderatlely sweet with a mild hazelnut flavor. An enjoyable beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep mahogany with thin bubbly tan head.  Aroma is nutty, roasty and malty.  Taste is malty and a little on the thin side.  Roasty malts are present and a little stale tasting.  Finishes with a nutty taste.  This beer might not be too great but at least it stays true to its name.

Iron Chef Morimoto is hoisting his mug on the screen-printed label of this 22-ounce bomber. I poured it into a pint pub glass giving my wife the rest, which she guzzled quickly and burped loudly. This beer was dark brown almost too dark it had a thin ( 3/8) tan head that disappeared in 48 seconds. Hazelnut toffee aroma with subtle hops
The taste was very good not sweet but balanced malt, hazelnut and little hops. I thought it was a little thin in mouth feel, which might be from the hazelnut extract. A good beer that I will buy again

Nutty aroma, smooth taste. 
Not much of a head, though.
