Great aroma, wonderful light, frothy head.  Unfortunately as soon as I tasted it I was dissapointed.  It seemed like a great beer, just watered down.  I'm not sure if it was just this keg, but if it hadn't tasted watered down it would have been one of my favorites.

Frothy white head that leaves a nice lacing.  Hazelnut in the aroma, of course.  Slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Sweet flavor, with a good deal of hazelnut, as well as chocolate malt, perhaps some toffee.  Slight bitterness near the end which balances the beer out well.  A nice little brown ale.

A rich, brown brew with a quickly dissipating head.  Crisp and dry and nutty with a hint of caramel, sweet malts and coffee in the finish.  Nice and smooth and easy to drink, although nothing is particularly striking, except the coffee in the finish.

Brown nectar indeed.  Pours dark brown, with sweet malts and a distinct hazelnut flavor, as oh-so-subtely suggested on the bottle.  However, the flavor seemed to thin as the bottle was drained.  A good beer, but I've had better browns.
hazelnut color and cream head. Aroma has a hazel-chocolate and a gramcracker smell. Tastes a little like a gram cracker, with good hazelnut. Mild carbonation.
Wow.  Can you say hazelnut.  This is a very good beer but unless you like hazelnut flavoring, this may be a bit much.
Not much aroma or head. Nice brown color and not as sweet as I thought it would be. Toasted/Roasted flavor.
Bottle - Not an over-abundance of aroma.  Dark Brown color.  Roasted malt flavor.  Complex but not overwhelming.  Clear finish.
Given the accolades it has received here, I suppose I expected a bit more than this thinnish brown ale happened to offer.  It had its moments, but never approached anything resembling greatness.

Beautiful rich deep red-brown beer. The hazelnut tones are not overwhelming, but subtle and linger in the palate after the beer is down. Small lasting head, moderate carbonation. The palate is complex, a rich nutty flavor with a coffee base and a little sting in the back of the throat. Long lasting nutty palate with a lingering aroma of hazelnut.

A dark brown ale with a foamy off-white head.  Upon opening the bottle I noticed a strong, pleasing aroma of with a hint of hazelnut that begs 'drink me'.  This nectar starts out with nutty, slightly sweet  flavor that goes down smooth.  This is followed by roasted hop aftertaste.  This gets my vote as the best brown ale around.
A damned good brown ale! Not nearly as sweet as some of the reviews here would lead one to believe. There is a strong hop character to balance the malty profile of this winner from Rogue.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2004 Probably the best brown ale out there. Pours a dark brown with minimal head. Flavor is nutmeg, syrup, toffee, and caramel. A little bit of a thin body and a touch too much carbonation but this is still a very good beer!

Redish brown in color with a full leathery head.  Leaves a nice lace on the glass.  Chewy malt taste with a decent amount of brown sugar flavor.  Hops are only present to take any extra sweetness off of the malts.  One of my favorites from Rogue.

Dark mahogany with a rich mocha and hazelnut aroma. Medium bodied with roasted malts and balancing hops. Very delicious and drinkable. I usually don't think much of brown ales, but this one got my attention. Great stuff.

I dont like this artificial Hazelnut flavor in my coffee and I hate it in my beer. Gonna have to go against the grain on this one based on personal tastes only. Otherwise its a decent brown. Medium bodied with a slight nutty sweetness that isnt from the harsh extract/syrup.

Lovely dark garnet brown color. Decent head, mostly diminishing with some lace. Very mild aroma, nut much there but a slight hint of brown sugar and a whisper of hazelnut. Brown sugar sweetness carries this beer into a rich, nutty middle and pleasantly bitter finish.

Certainly an excellant example of brown ale without the usual hop bite of the west coast, I did not find any flavor overpowering but thought it had a pleasant balance(this good). I like other american browns better but would recomend thus one

Pour is dark brown, with a thick tan head that quickly settles to light lacing.  Aroma is strong on the hazelnut, backed up with lots of roasted and toasted malts.  Flavor is overpowered with the hazelnut, quite sweet (maple syrup?), with a hint of the roasty malts peeking through at the end.  Mouthfeel is full, a bit sticky.

- deep, dark brown with a very faint red hue, no head, a sweet hazelnut/buttery malt aroma, light roasted malt aroma, some chocolate, very lightly hopped, a touch of spiciness; a nutty/sweet malt/buttery blend, flavor starts with roasted malt mixed with a hint of chocolate, but the aftertaste is all hazelnut, slight hop bitterness, very smooth  rich texture, a different taste
This one's a winner.  Quintessencial American brown ale.  Not possessed with the typical Rogue hoppiness, this one is smooth and malty, with the nutty taste that the name implies.

Dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of malt, a molasses/chocolate mix.  Slight nut flavor, mainly a toasted malt taste.  Finish is not " smooth malty finish" as the bottle claims, it is bitter on the sides of the tongue, which becomes annoying at the ended of the beer.
Deep brown in color, with red tones when held to light.  Warm and nutty aroma.  The flavor is a subtle hoppy bitter that spikes quickly, and then slowly fades into a a rich nutty finish.
Yeah, it is that good. A typical mellow browna ale character, with a typical (for Rogue) hop backbone. This is not an attempt to make an English Brown, this is an American Brown Ale. Very impressive.

Clear dark amber, tan head recedes quickly, nose is roasted malt. Surprisingly for this brewer, more in the malt department than the hops. Roasty chocolatey flavor with nutty undertones. Typical Pacman house character comes through as well.  Really nice ale.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2007 A very nice nutty brown, with better all around flavor than most others of the variety. A superior beer, and possibly the best brown ale out there.

RERATE:  I have to say again, that having had a few other browns between tastings of this one, this IS the preeminent brown ale around today.  It has MUCH more depth of flavor, a VERY nice aroma, and is a very enjoyable, not too heavy on the palate brew.  Each and every brown I try, I compare to this, and none have stacked up to this one, and only Sammy Smith comes close.
Very big head. Dark and brimming with a nutty nose. Very smooth and malty. THE great American Brown Ale.
Semi-sweet, with notes of chocolate and a decent roastiness. Medium bitter finish. Becomes slightly cloying and perhaps metallic towards the end. And the bald guy freaks me out a bit.

I've always liked Newcastle Brown Ale, and still do. However this Rogue is really far better. It's simply delicious.  Creamy, creamy, creamy. Slightly sweet with a beautiful medium brown color. I enjoy most of Rogue's brews, and this one is at the top.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2003 Re-rate 10/17/03: Tried this labeled as Morimoto Hazelnut and thought I was getting a new beer.  It pisses me off that Rogue bottles the same beers under different names.  Morimoto had nothing to do with this beer whatsoever, unless he's been working at Rogue since they came out with the Hazelnut Brown Nectar.  Anyways, this is not as good as I remember.  Still has a good sweet hazelnut flavor, but their isn't much malty complexity.
Still a good, easy-drinking beer, so I'll let the mislabeling slide for this time.

Original Rating:
Robust sweet malty nose and medium to dark brown color.  Tastes like freshly cracked crystal malt stewing at mashing tempurature.  Mellow, inviting, full nuttiness caresses the palate and finishes a toasty almond.  The hazelnut extract adds a tremendous amount of character.  This is the best brown ale I have had.

Well it was brown. As far as the HazleNut and Nectar part go...I don't see it. Malty aroma but not really nutty. Smooth drinking. Thin palate. Not really a strong brown color. No real aftertaste. Pales in comparison to Papago's El Grande Nutz
nearly clear, root beer brown w/ a slight tan head. Slightly sweet, nutty (duh) taste on the palate. a very enjoyable brew, thx beerguy101

Well, I did my homework and this was the highest rated beer at Hopyard last nite. I did the cask IPA first (gotta do decent cask first, it's a religious thing) and then moved on to the big gun. I guess I'm not a hazelnut bear guy. This was the highest rating I could come up with and I hope it's at the end of a happy keg and tailing off or something because I was just NOT impressed. Yes, it's got good head and color and yes the feel is good, not great. But it tasted like someone had made a hazelnut beer by adding some commercial hazelnut extract like you do with coffee and it overbalanced the rest of the flavors in my (our) opinion. Had it been a bit more subtle and interacted in a more complex way with the malts, it would have been a different story but I couldn't pull the malts out in the mouth or the finish. I hope the rest of you enjoy it but I'll probably be drinking something else :-)

Rich, dark mahogany is very nice, but the head dies too quickly. Great mouthfeel, rich and purposeful, albeit easy to drink. Very aromatic beer, with molasses, coffee, wood, pine, nuts, and of course, a lot of hazelnut notes. The beer seems pretty well-balanced with a deep sweetness against a "roasty" bitterness. Its finish is great; really nice lasting flavors.

Pours a nice deep amber/light brown color with a sustaining white head. Aroma of roasted malts dominates. Flavor is a very complex and balanced blend of nuts, chocolate, a little hop bitterness and rich malts. A very good brown.

This is by far the best brown ale I have ever had.  The finish is long and complex.  Hazelnut is prominent, but there are many other flavors to go along with it.  Its very well balanced, and overall is a top quality beer.  I have to hand it to Rogue for pulling off this one!

Deep rich nutty brown color with a big, dense dusty brown head.  A big, full nose, lots of complexity for sure.  Sweet and malty with lots of chocolate, some grains and a light nutty character, of course.  Well roasted malts stand out in the mouth, caramely and chocolatey, full of body and character.  Exceptional balance.   A dry roastey, dark chocolatey finish.

(Re-rate ASAP)
OK, I usually avoid reviewing beers that I've not tasted for five years, so I'll keep it short.
According to the members of ratebeer.com, this is the best brown ale in the world.
This accolade is no fluke.  It's easy to make a cloyingly sweet brown ale.
Rogue has managed to perfectly balance malt sweetness with just enough hop bitterness.
They also managed to squeeze a mind-boggling amount of complexity into a notoriously delicate (read: easy to screw up) beer style.
To top it off, this brew stands alone as a great spice/fruit/vegetable beer, which
is not an easy task, for anyone who's tried it as a homebrewer or sampled the whole spectrum
of failures from American craft brewers.  Nectar it is!
Nice... almost tasted like a porter... a little sweet, but overall a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2003 Dark brown color with a tinge of red in the light. A dark brown head. The aroma was nutty, malty and a touch of caramel. The taste of nutty, chocolate, coffee goodness. Full flavor...great gravity and a creamy palate. I love this beer.
This truly lives up to its name.  A nectar of the gods right here folks.  Sweet all the way to the last drop.

Dark brown color. Medium head. Aroma is nutty and malty. A medium bodied brown ale. This is a very nice nut brown ale. Nutty and malty, smooth and sweet. Mellow and very drinkable. This is a beer that is complex enough for the experienced beer drinker, yet simple enough to wean someone off macro-swill. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is malty sweet. Etched/Painted beer bottle
Malty aroma, beautiful crystal brown color.  Nice malty sweet flavor, just not enough flavor.

WOW.  Far and away the best brown ale I've had ever.  Amazing subtle hazelnut flavor that melds seamlessly with the roasty brown ale flavor.  Great mouthfeel.  Smooth as hell.  A little bit too bitter for my idea of a brown ale, but very smooth, rich and tasty.  I'll probably get this regularly.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 Aroma of sweet chocolate and caramel, nice sweet first taste, right amount of carbonation.  Intense aftertaste is very nutty, with slight bitterness.  Drank this tonight with my roommate PrinceofNessus.  rerate: too sweet, oily AND watery and quite simple.
Nice taste though a bit bitter. The head is thin and quickly disappears.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2006 The best brown Ive had.  Very sweet aftertaste.  It puts other brown ales to shame.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2010 Bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, nuts, toasted bread), lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs), moderately yeasty (mold, cheese). Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, unclean. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. This sample had a strong and unpleasant moldy/cheesy note that all but ruined the aroma.  Rancid nuts maybe?  Rather dirty aftertaste too.
A beer with excellent flavor, everyone should try it

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2003 This is so good I'm having trouble rating it because I'm gulping it down so quickly! Pours out of the 22 oz bottle a very dark brown color with a great ruby red tinge. Head is a little small and dissipates quickly. Aroma has distinct brown sugar tones and a touch of hazelnut, and maybe a maple syrupy note in there too. Flavor is smooth all the way through. A bit of maltyness, no bitterness at all. Definitely sweet flavor, but just the right amount (not overly sweet or syrupy). Overall very delicious. I like brown ales, and this is the piece de resistance.
malty and heavy with a nice chocolate zing. not hoppy, really, but another great offering from rogue.
Malty, nutty, smooth and amazing... I dont like to many Browns, but this is one yummy brew.
Sweety nutty aroma.  Frothy tan head.  Good brown color.  Smooth easy drinking.  One of my favorite Rogues so far.  Well done.

Hazlenut, chocolate, toffe are all very evident.  A solid beer with a nice malt accent and it is the lowest hopped Rogue Ive had yet--that was good and at the same time a little disappointing.  Nut brown character seems rather artificial; it bothers me that there is extract added.
Sweet, nutty aroma.  dark brown opaque coloring.  Very smooth malty taste with a bit of nutty taste to it.  Body is medium heavy.  Very drinkable but nothing exceptional.

the aroma is like nut oils rather than fresh nuts. Like extract. Same with the taste. As i was admiring Scaramengas third nipple and sipping this, I discovered i couldnt get enough of it. Its rather malty and thick unlike most previous examples of this kind. The nut taste wasnt very predominate (my dream is to discover a beer that tastes like an almond joy) but it was a bigger kick to the balls than previous efforts.

Revamp:  Artifcial and thin.  Previous rating:  This is a great American brown.  Robust enough to enjoy after dinner or with a cigar.  Yet quaffable enough to make it a good session beer.  Well done Maier!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Outstanding nutty flavor.  However, the overwhelming sweetness made me think I was drinking soda and not beer.  Albeit a damn good soda.
I love good head; nice amber color; Smooth taste and dry finish.  Nutty, Honey like taste captures my heart.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 10, 2004 This is one of my favorite beers to date.  Beautifully sweet nose with traces of Hazelnut and one of the most intense palates I've ever tasted.  There's a lot of good stuff here - buttery sweet hazelnut taste right up front; one reviewer compared this experience to imagining a bowl of toffee ice cream right in front of him, and I tend to agree.  Taste reminds me of a toasted caramel and it doesn't disappoint as the temperature rises - although I didn't give it much of a chance to rise as I guzzled it down.  Looking forward to trying more of this brewery's offerings.  This is the beer that Newcastle aspires to be.

This wasnt nearly as complex and tasty as Samuel Smiths Nut Brown Ale. Im glad that it had all those varieties of hops and all, but I think they blended together just a bit too well. I think this ale would be dynamite on tap.

Good stuff, but not nearly as good as Samuel Smiths. I know it doesnt say it in the description, but I taste more coffee malts than chocolate. I bit on the sour side to be my favorite brown ale, and not really all that nutty. Strong alcoholic taste. Plus, as with all Rogue beers in big bottles, the label is cheesy and scares me a little.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2003 A great mahogany pour with a large off white head full of all sizes of bubbles.  It's got that great hazlenut nose, and complimenting that, a pleasing malt aromas. Here's where this beer excels. The flavor. Oh, this is what I think of when I hear brown ale. The hazlenut is just simply delectable. The malts back that up with a great barrage of flavors.  Creamy palate and full bodied make this one hell of a beer. Without a doubt, one of, if not the best brown ale out there

for such a highly rated beer this one just didnt do it for me. I found it kinda weak and watery and not all that flavorful. Maybe the bar did a bad job of taking care of the keg. Ill try it again, but for now it stays as mediocre.

Wow o wow, the creamy brown looking brew with a slim tan head is a good one.  Smelling of hazelnut, malts, nuts, with a roasted smoke smell. It taste exactly like it smells but better.  A Smooth nutty tasting malty sweet brew with hints of cream, hazelnut, toffee, and coffee. Man o man a goodie.

Creamy malt and hazel nut nose and a deep garnet color.  Head was loose and tan but left quickly.  Bock like malts with lost of cream, a little sweetness, hazelnut, bread dough, roasted nuts, and the slightest touch of a barleywine charactor.  Finishes long and bockish.  Increadably smooth and balanced.
Wonderful brown ale. Slightly heavy on the HazelNut extract, but I overcame that quickly ;-)
This brown ale is dank.  The hazelnut, coffee, and chocolate flavors were all very subtle. Which made this a nice and balanced brown ale. Not too overpowering.

Dark ruby color, kept a very nice head, very smooth, some nutty undertones to the flavor, lots of other interesting flavors in there, tasted almost like there was a few stalks of barley right in the glass, very interesting brew

Re-rate: Enjoyed another one of these on draft at my favorite tavern. This beer is wonderful and tastes better to me each time I try it.  Original rating 6/5/02:Dark ruby to brown in the glass. Pretty decent head retention. Wonderful aroma and flavors of caramel and nuts. Flavor gets better as the beer warms. Another outstanding beer from Rogue Ales.

Probably the worlds best brown ale, and certainly the best in the US. Strong hazel nut malt followed by a perfect balance of hops that I have come to expect from this great brewery. No bitterness in the aftertaste, smoother than New Castle, nearly perfection as brown ales go.
Hmm.  Kinda gross.  The hazelnut flavor is syrupy and overwhelms everything else.  I appreciate the attempt, tho.

I typically like a greater hopp character in a beer.  This one grew on me the more I drank it.  Dark brown color.  NIce malty flavor with the right balance of sweetness.  This one was dry but not bitter.  All in all a very nice brew.  Congrats
Outstanding.  Clean and simple, round and full.  Marvelous flavor.  Subtle, delicate head.  Gentle sweetness, with a finish like the best fresh oysters from PEI.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 8/8 & 9/16: darkness with holes of brown...lasting tanness on top...aroma kept quiet at first but started to whisper nutty secrets...the progression of flavors from start to finish is pinche loco cabrón..It starts with a punch of non-sweet silk on your tongue...then down the center of your tongue you feel a vibrant injection of hazelnut coffee..then as it travels through your veins to your head you get a sensation that you have a mouthful of ground coffee beans & hazelnuts and chocolate morsals ♫♫ Sing a song for this one, baby ♫♫ Oh yeah!! Great choice for # 300 However, do not drink more than 1 bottle in a session..gets kinda wierd after too much..

One of my favorite beers.  Not like other nut brown ales-definately in a higher class.  Smooth with nice body.  Dark, almost porter looking.  It has a distinctive hazelnut taste in it with subtle chocolateness. Would recommend to anyone with a half a brain.

Tap at the Rogue Pub/Public House in Newport, OR.  Dark brown to black with ruby touches.  Laced brown head.  Big hazelnut sweet flavor.  Smooth and malty.  Re-Rate 11/18/02 from a bottle.  A nice dark brown color with a yellow-brown head.  Sweet nut malty aroma.  The hazelnut comes through strong the middle of the beer.
poured a nice dark brown color with good sized tan head, aroma of roasted malt with a bit of nuttiness, smooth chocolate malt flavor with a hint of hazelnut, thin but still quite enjoyable

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2006 Delicious!  The strongest caramel flavors and aromas Ive ever had in a beer.  Tasty chocolate and subtle hazelnut (an added ingredient).  Mild hoppiness and fruitiness.  Negatives--lacks complexity and  looks and feels a bit thin.  Still this beer is very tasty.

Cloudy dark brown color.  The nose is sweet malt and chocolate.  Delicious fudgey(hazelnutty) notes make this beer, what ruins it is excessive spritzyness and iron notes.  Finished sweet malty.  Nice brown if it werent for the previously mentioned negatives.

On tap.  This beer is one of the richest beers I have ever had.  You know how if you eat regular chocolate then have some dark chocolate, you notice the profound difference in the richness of the two.  Well, thats how this beer compares to just about every other beer Ive had.  I was imagining a bowl of toffee ice cream in front of me when I had this, and it made me wonder why bars dont serve ice cream.  In this case it seems like it would be a perfect match.  The aroma and taste are reminiscent of hazelnuts but also toffee, caramel, and Kahlua.  The body was medium and just about where it should have been for all the sweetness.  Just a little bit of hops to finish it off and dry it up.  Can this brewery do no wrong?  Every product of theirs Ive tried has been wonderful.  This is no exception.
Some dark roasted chocolate flavors.  Distinct brown ale.  No head and very little carbonation.  Nutty flavors come through.  A good brown ale.
Very enjoyable because a lot of flavors come through. A bit watery in the middle, but a nutty, chocolatey taste lingers on after its gone.

An excellent brown ale.  The aroma is fantastic.  Pours out to a dark brown in the glass with a light brown head.  Taste is indeed nutty, with a perfect blend of hops and malt.  It got better as it warmed up. This brewery knows beer.

Attractive beer.  First hit is clearly the nuts, with bitterness which I took (mistook?) for a mocha-like hazlenut coffee coming in after a five-second delay.  Certainly nutty, although I wasnt sure it was hazlenut as I know it, but rather something else...a bit of pistachio almost?  A certain unsatisfying substructure, a bit thin yet a bit fizzy.  The guy sitting next to me at the bar was drinking Bud Light, but I gave him a taste of this and he said wow--perhaps a convert to good beer?  I had to leave part of my glass because I was driving...that was a shame.  (on tap, Flying Saucer, Addison, TX)

Aroma begs for the beer to be consumed--nutty
and sweet.  Brown and clear in appearance.  Nut 
flavor lingers into the aftertaste and changes for a 
sweet finish.  Wonderful bold maltiness.  May even 
be better than draught Moose Drool (forgive me Big 
Sky Brewing Co.).

Clear brown with hint of red, medium light tan head.  Aroma is sweet malty, with a hint of the promised hazelnut.  Flavor is full-bodied malt with distinct hazelnut.  Finshes nice and smooth, mostly sweet with only the slightest hint of bitterness.

This dark red-brown beer is topped with a thick head and has lots of lace.  it has a slightly sweet and appetizing malty aroma with nutty undertones.  the flavor is slightly sweet, nutty and malty with a hint of chocolate and well blanced with hops.  the finish is nutty and chocolaty.

My favorite style of beer, and to date, the best beer Ive ever had.  Everything about this beer is wonderful.  My only complaint is the lack of consistancy, as not every bottle Ive had tasted the same.  I also dont recommend drinking any more than one or two of these in a sitting, it could be a bit much.
Not a huge fan of Brown ales in general, but have to say this one was pretty darn good.

Upon first sipping, I declared this to be my favorite beer. After a few more times though I have come to realize that it is not as good as I first thought. It is a good beer, dont get me wrong. Flavor is great and aroma inviting. However it was a little over carbonated, overly malty and tasted a little silly going down my throat. Maybe I just drank too much or something else...

Great beer that screams Hazelnut.  More like a specialty coffee taste than beer actually.  Like the smoke ale, I could not drink too much.  The overwhelming flavor makes the beer taste artificial in a way, almost like they added espresso liquer to the boil for the extra flavor.  Another quality beer by Rogue though.  Experimental and highly tasty.
Being a good fan of Rogue, I thought this beer was exceptional.  A dark beer with real nutty hint of hazelnut. Excellent.

This is a great brown ale, probably the best I have had. Nutty flavor with a nice malty finish. Hazelnut flavor is not overpoweringly sweet.  This and the Shakespear Stout are my favorite Rogue ales so far.

great brown ale.
rogue took the Sam Smith nut brown name literally and brewed up this masterpiece.
sweet  malty taste with a distinct nutty  element.
dark brown, beige head that left a generous amount of lace.
malty chocolate aroma.
great balance of ther traditional  beer flavors of malt and hops with the novelty hazelnut element.
A classic experimental brew.

Dark brown, with a nice light brown head that diminishes, but sticks lightly around the edge of the glass.  Aroma could be carmelized bananas roasting over an open fire.  Sweet dark chocolate rolls over the tongue and the malty finish is extra smooth.  I wish my 750 could be even bigger.

The bottle doesnt lie, definitely a world champion brown ale.  I feel like a retro-beatnik just smelling it, belongs in a coffee shop.  the alcohol content is hidden like governments pro-tourist messages during the Michigan/Notre Dame game. Maybe its the alochol talking, but this beer makes me laugh in a Fox News kind of way

This beautiful beer pours up with a satisfyingly thick head over a body that is, surprise surprise, hazelnut brown.  The aroma wafting off this beer is absolutely heavenly, promising the smooth taste of a brown ale with the rich nutty maltiness of a mild porter.  It sits in the mouth well, stimulating the entire palate, although it could have been a bit smoother.  Overall, this is one of my favorite beers, and serves well as a stand-alone treat or as a complement to a large variety of meals.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2004 Malty, lightly toasted and caramelized, sweet nose, hazelnut is immediately evident.  Deep chestnut color with a light tan head.  Flavor profile is all about the sweet malt and hazelnut combo, and just look at all the malts this beer has in it.  It shows through quite readily.  Mouthfeel is very lush and fits perfectly.  Finish sees a little hop flavor enter the picture but Browns are about the malt through and through, this one is no exception.  I really enjoy this one a lot but part of me has to wonder what it would taste like without the added hazelnut flavoring.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2004 Drak mahagony brown hue.  Lacey beige head.  Earthy, chocolate, hint of hazelnut, toasted nose.  Sweetness first, moderately full bodied palate.  The finish is just incredible.  Chocolate and roasted hazelnut just crash through.  Then a long lingering spicy, bitter hop ending.  An absolutely wobderful brew.  The best brown ive ever had.

Toasted Roasted hazelNutty yummy.  Dark brown (really, I know that Ive had some "brown ales" that were very red - this was actually brown - bonus points!)  Tastes like coffee with cream, and is perfect to wash down the delicious brownies my wife made.
Excellent - my favorite Rogue to date.  Frothy, thick pour, excellent chocalate undertones.  Strong finish. Sweet, nutty aroma.  Winner all the way around.

In the words of Austin Powers, "Its a little nutty."  Ruby brown color with a small beige head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, and hazelnut.  Initially sweet flavor of malt and hazelnut, with a lasting bitter aftertaste.  Smooth, low carbonation.  Hazelnut tends to overpower, they should ease up a little on the hazelnut extract.
very rich and smooth nice choclate taste hazlenut flavour stays when drink is finnished
If you like the taste of Hazelnut, you cant beat this one!  There is no doubt about the underlying flavor.  Not something you might drink a lot of, but would go well with some deserts.

Had a 22Oz of this last night and i thought it was pretty good nuthin I could drink a sixer of, in a night, but one definately is a tastey treat. Its just a little sweet for my tastes to drink a lot of it. Other than that great brew.
Just had this last night -- its sweet and slightly nutty.  I enjoyed it and so did my brother!

Given my love of smokier, roastier (or caramelly + hoppy = Poppy Jasper) Brown Ales, and relative dislike of nutty Browns, I approached this with some trepidation. No worries...a fine beer  here, to be sure. Has a lot to recommend it; a fair palate, although pretty carbonated (too much?), a good hop finish. In the end, however, it is just far too hazelnutty for my tastes. Aroma, flavor finish, all over this thing you will find hazelnut. My wife would even like it in her morning coffee, Im sure.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: It doesnt get much better than this beer.  Rich Nutty Flavor, Sweet and smooth finish, pleasant aftertaste.

This is one amazing brown ale!  The first thing that grabbed me was the aroma of hazelnuts from the beer that is dark brown with a nice thick head.  Then came the taste that blew me away.  It was more hazlenuts mixed with chocolate and had a very smooth finish.  Today was the first time Ive tried this beer, and definately not the last.

As a un-fan of brown ales this is one of the tops in my history.  As good a looking beer as any.  A wonderfully clear rudy/amber color with a light tan, unassuming head.  Reminds me of Cracker Jacks - Toffee and nutty. Smooth with a mild malt finish.
In this case, Im assuming nectar is short for nectar of the gods.  One of the best nut brown ales ever.

Beautiful brown/dark red beer.  The aroma is comprised of nuts with a bit of surprizing sweetness.  Chocolate and nuts are most notable.  It is very creamy and smooth.  Easy to see why this one is called Nectar.
Nice dark brown beer, with nice malt flavor and a strong nut presence.  Sweet finish that took me by surprise, but still quite good.  Well worth drinking any time.

This beer mega-rocks.
The color is a beautiful, dark crimson (Roll Tide). Ok, the ale smells like an American macrobrew, but the flavor is malty, nutty, malty, nutty and not sweet. I thought aroma and flavor were interwoven in humans. How did Rogue pull this off? Why? Did I mention that this ale is really malty and nutty.  Dont let the NECTAR portion of the name fool you, it really isnt sweet at all... its hopped perfectly.  HAZELNUT HEAVEN. The best brown ale Ive had since LongShot Hazelnut Brown was brewed by the Boston Brewing Company back in 1995-1996. Anybody with me?

Rerated with clean palate... Excellent presentation, deep ruby brown, padded creamy head.  Nutty (obviously) slightly sulphurous aroma.  Very smooth hazelnut flavor.  Needs to be thickened up for a better palate.  I had to ding it on palate, and deduct 1 aroma point for sulphur, and one appearance point for the purple hippie.
Whoa!!!  The best thing to happen to brown ales since Sam Smith.  Wonderful chocolate hints and the sweetness is not overpowering.    Just a taste of hazelnut makes this a magnificent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2004 Terrific nut brown ale with a nutty, complex flavor that's rather addictive.  Sadly, it's hard to find in NYC!  After tasting the delicious Boyne and Casta brown ales, this one's even better than those great beers were.

I must admit, I was expecting a bit more from all of the hype surrounding this beer, but if I were to rate it purely by style this ranks quite high among brown ales Ive had. The hops are surprisingly apparent (considering the IBU is only 33) and the malt is nice and mellow. The really cool thing about this beer though is the hazelnut extract. At first I was wondering where it was, but as the beer neared room temp it became increasingly apparent. The hazelnut sits on the palate in a starchy bittery kind of cloying that really adds to the appeal of this brown ale. Very good indeed.

650 ml bottle.  I really dont know what to think about this one.  I know its a Rogue, but it seems pretty harsh for a brown, at least by my experiences.  Complex nose, yes, but theres a nasty lingering bitterness (not hoppy bitterness) reminiscent of bad coffee from a truck stop.  Im likely to resample though, due all of the other stellar reviews.
This is great stuff. Better than Newcastle, and thats saying something. Light nutty/coffee flavor, and a bit of hops. A winner.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2003 Ever had crème de hazelnut?...Interesting dry bitterness amongst the lactic, chocolate malt and huge, glittering hazelnut peels...Cherry wine surfaces once in a while as ashes cling to the nuts...These guys rarely compomise and do it very well...

Soft chocolate and caramel malt sweetness up front, followed by a dry, non-bitter finish, with nutty overtones.  Aroma is light with chocolate and hazelnuts.  Easy drinking, and not as sweet as you might expect from something called nectar - but the nut flavors make it something not to do too much of.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2004 Beautiful cloudy brown color with a decent tan head that leaves a nice lacing in the glass. Chocolate and hazelnut aromas, chocolate and nutty flavors as well with a nice nutty sweetness, medium bodied with a smooth and creamy mouthfeel, finishes with a lingering sweetness.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2003 This beer poured out a nice very dark amber color with a tan head, that did subside with some lace. Nice faint malt smell to it. Slight hazelnut smell to it, some coffee aroma to it. The flavor is what hits you. Because of the hazelnut, you would have to put this not only as a brown ale, but a spice beer. The hazelnut taste was very good and quite pronounced. It was so heavy with that taste, you wonder if that adds to the body to it as well as the mouthfeel. Good flavor, but the strong hazelnut and carmel aspects to this might throw some. Worth checking out.

Perfection on draft. I would not make this my everyday brown ale -- thats Newcastle -- because I want the act of drinking it to retain a special aura. They are not kidding when they call Rogue Hazelnut a nectar (of the gods, as the rest of the phrase goes). 6/7/2002 update: Slightly less of a knock-out bottled (although still very impressive). Im taking the Overall Impression down a couple of notches because of that. But what beer isnt better on draft?

bottle brown with garnet highlights,  dense tan head that would be at home atop any stout.  typical of a rogue, the aroma is almost visibly radiating with its masterful melange of malts. just to hazard an offbeat impression, id suggest it has a resemblance in bouquet to hot fudge on coffee ice cream.  once on the tongue that flavoring additive asserts itself, and while it does harmonize with the malt choir, it might be a shade too loud for people like me in the front row. as ive remarked about other skillfully orchestrated flavored beers, id love to taste this identical product without an ingredient which is probably more of a marketing device than a brewing refinement. that said, it works, its sweet and full bodied amid a creamy maple, desert beverage flavor. i concur that it warms charmingly, and the big bottle allows us that leisure. plenty of hop in the finish.  could be the perfect beer to accompany a fine cigar. maestro maier makes my life better.

Comment added yet again, 5/31: All that said, Ive got to downgrade it back to 4.2.  Love it, but isnt exactly quite as rich as Id really love it to be.

Comment added 5/16/02: This stuff has grown on me.  Love the stuff, and can hardly stop drinking it.  It kicks butt.  Makes me look forward with great anticipation putting it up against Boyne River Brown in a taste test.  Only question: will I possibly be sober by the end?

Orignal 1/25/02 comments, giving the beer a 4.2 rating:

I havent been a big fan of brown ales, but I bought this on the strength of Rogues reputation (with me, most importantly) for making quality brews, and as usual, Rogue doesnt disappoint.  I do like this one better than Newcastle and Sam Smiths.  Pretty mild taste- and aroma-wise, and tastes just how I think a brown ale should taste.  More richness comes out in the taste and aroma when it warms up, so for maximum effect and enjoyment, you should let this warm up from refrigerator temperature before you drink it.  (Myself, I enjoyed it more and more as it got warmer, so its a good lesson for next time I have one.)  Just a pleasant drink that goes down nice and smooth.  And quite nice was the fact that Rogue put this in a brown bottle rather than the clear ones.  No skunking much less any suspicious traces of it.  Newcastle and Sam Smith should take a hint.

rerate 5/28/02: had to knock this a few points after experiencing the subtlety of Boyne River Brown. Oh. My. Deity. This beer just took Shakespeare off the top of my list. Nice hazelnut capuccino flavor. Definitely verges on being a porter. This is an excellent beer.
Dark brown color, nutty aroma. Flavor of nuts and vanilla. Pretty smooth and drinkable
to be fair i should mention i dont care for hazelnuts. not a beer for me.

Well I love Brown Ales, but the Hazlenut flavor seems to cheapen the overall taste of ths beer.  Its kind of the same as flavored cigars and flavored coffee.  But I did find that the beer is quite refreshing and pairs really well with spicy mexican food!
Very good. A nice, sweet taste sure to please the ladies.

My new favourite Rogue.  Reminds me of a wonderful hazelnut-pecan pie.  Incredibly well done.  Brown ales are not usually my thing, but this is one exception I would like to keep stocked in my beer closet.

another ingenius brew from Rogue.  Pours a deep ruby to brown shade.  Aroma is malty, vanilla and a nice hazelnut touch.  Full flavored, rich, creamy, roasted malt, nuts, honey, and a hazelnut flavors.  Wonderful soft palate, low carbonation, outstanding!
deep brown, tan foam. initial light molasses and woody notes. delicious... honey, vanilla, hazelnut, toffee with grainy tannic astringency.

This brew pours a deep ruby brown.  The large tan head is creamy, frothy and very dense.  The head is mostly lasting and has good lacing.  The bold aroma is stellar.  When Im long dead and burning in hell, they are going to have me chained to the wall with one of these under my nose for me to whiff on for all eternity -with no hope of actually drinking it.  Hazelnuts dominate in addition to caramel, mild coffee, flowers, cheese, prunes, toffee, butterscotch, honey, and spices galore.  The flavor is also stellar.  It is warm, rich, complex, and very balanced.  Again hazelnuts dominate with coffee & toffee, spices, honey and some chocolate.  The long balanced finish is very clean.  The creamy body is medium to full with a very crisp fizzy carbonation that supplies plenty of bite.  This brew is almost porter speed.  Rogue Ales is quickly becoming my favorite Micro-Brewery.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2003 RE-RATE: Couldn't find this stuff again until I went to the Flying Saucer in Houston last weekend.  Loved it again, especially the smoky taste, and had to up it a little bit.  I also believe that this beer can bring you good luck.  ORIG RATING 4/22/02: 9-5-8-5-16: Incredible!!  How can a taste have such prominent hazelnut and honey without ruining it being beer?  By far the best nut brown I've ever had, I'm having another next time I'm out.  Toffe/caramel is also in the taste.  A complex blend of sweetness.  Nectar is a good word to describe it, too.  Okay, away from the incredible taste, it's also got a handsome brown color, and the nose is as good as how it is on your tongue.  Classic.
Holy smokes!  This ones a true champion.  Nutty, nutty.  Its got it all, folks.  Best nut brown.
Quite impressive.  The hazelnut flavoring is present.  Sweet and malty.  As I recall, not to much hop presence.  My brother would enjoy this beer.
UPDATED: AUG 26, 2003 Pours a dark brown color with a bit of orange.  Hazelnut aroma backed by sweet malts.  Firm bodied and ends sweet.  Hmmm...nutty and buttery.

A very complex brew.  I got a lot out of this beer the more I drank it.  I tasted the nuttiness right off the bat, but the more I drank it, the more I got fruits and sweetness out of it.  The malts brought out a brown sugar taste...which balanced the hops nicely.  Very good beer to end the night with if you are on the town.

Fantastic beer.  Brillant aroma accompanied by beautiful color and wonderful taste.  Really appreciated how well the sweet yet measured hoppiness produced a wonderful flavor.  Neither overly sweet nor overly hoppy. Have been very impressed with Rouge beers so far.

Not the typically Rogue-ish hop fest you might expect. Incredibly decadent dark roasted chocolate, dry hazelnut, sweet toffeeish caramel. Even gained a slight port like character with food. May have lacked a little bitterness in the finish but did a great job without it. I have to say I loved this one.
Not really a brown ale.  Belongs in the herb and spice catagory.  It is hard to drink more than just one.
Nice and smooth, but not too smooth.
Rogue Brown Nectar is truly a beer worth trying if you like an excellent Brown ale with a unique flavor.  This beer makes my top ten list.

Best Brown I have tried so far.  Much more flavorful than Newcastle.  A little more hoppy than I expected, but I guess thats Rogue for you.  I agree with one poster that said it was a little thin on the palate (even though it poured thick), but it had enough going on that I still felt it deserved a 4 for palate.  Nice:)

Well, Rogue left out the hops and bumped up the malt character on this one.  It makes for an incredibly rich, nutty and sweet brown.  Pleasant deep brown color with an eggshell head that didnt stick around.  Plenty of vanilla, toffee, sweet chocolate and subdued nuttiness in both aroma and flavor.  You could smell this one a mile away.  Starts very sweet and finishes a bit more subdued and refined.  Theres alot going on in this one.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2003 The beer disembogues a transpicuous deep ruby color with a Bunyanesque sized head that is spumescent in texture and a beauteous tan color, as it ever so slowly transmogrifies the lace forms a thick and glutinous sheet to meld with the glass. A sweet nutlike malted aroma dominates hints of vanilla, quite fresh and clean, start quite sweet with the top a bit thin for my liking. Finish is moderate in carbonation with the hop personable in their spicy bite, quite dry with a lingering bittersweet flavor, drinkable as all Rogue beers are, but certainly not their best Whatever the name.
This is a very good specialty thats great for dessert.
beautiful creamy dark head, perfect carbonation, smooth taste, with a extra hoppy after taste to balance off the hazelnut/chocolate flavor.a really good brew!

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2003 Deep red/brown.Pretty nice head and lace. Nice dessert-like aroma of chocolate and sweet hazelnut . Palate is full of sweet and roasted nuts mingling with a smooth malt profile. Body is a little thin but the finish is  rich,smooth hazelnut with a quick shot of hops at the end creating a little bit of dryness. Nice beer. Didnt think it was too sweet either. Kicks Newcastle's(had it earlier at dinner) ass like Rocky beating on Clubber.
A great beer.  Very nutty tasting.  The hazelnuts stand out.
Well balanced and flavorful brown ale.  The hazelnut flavor provides just enough kick to make this beer stand well by itself.

sigh! alas....

my expectations were too high!

i was so excited to find a big bottle of this to try. but as has been the case with the other 2 rogues that ive tried, the hoopla was bigger than the actual beer.

i didnt get any sense of robust at all. it was sort of flat and thin, actually. 

very sweet, and it seems like there should have been something else to balance this sweetness out that just wasnt there.

i love hazelnut coffee, and i liked the aroma of this beer, but dang, i was disappointed with a rogue choice again! and i even let it warm up a bit as another reviewer suggested.

i actually liked the other two styles better than this one (mocha porter and shakespeare stout) even though they were so very hoppy.

my husband tasted this and his exact words were this beer rots.

i wouldnt go that far, but it certainly wasnt all that and a bag of chips as i was hoping it was going to be.
pretty good, heavy on the hazelnut, but it does grow on you; not too hoppy, nice aftertaste

Nice color, toasty aroma, and decent body, but if I had to drink a full bottle of this I would probably puke up hazelnut for the rest of the night.  Without the flavoring, this would probably be damn good beer.
I am sorry but the hazlenut doesnt work. I realize that this beers has its fans, but, BLAH!

This was my most anticipated purchase since I joined the site, what with all the raves, and maybe the expectation hurt some, but guys, come on!  Its like over sweetened hazelnut coffee.  Its really hard to tell that this is a beer at all.  Im going to make bread with the rest of the bottle, and it should be all right for that.
Very delicious ale.  The hint of chocolate compliments the hazelnut flavor.  Well balanced with no aftertaste.
Perhaps my favorite beer. Nice balance between the malt and hops. The last sip is as good as the first(perhaps better as it warms a bit).Do yourself a favor and give it a try.
Wow. Firesides, friends, and memories. A wonderfully warm and rich sweetness, without being cloying. Fabulous.

This beer is phenomenal The colour is perfect, darker than Newcastle, but not as dark as some American brown ales. Awseome flavour with overtones of hazelnut and a hint of chocolate.  I am convinced that Rogue is one of the best breweries in the U.S.
Excellent aroma great nutty flavor great aftertaste.
No idea how to describe this.  The hazelnut is surprisingly strong.  Also quite a bit of sweetness to this one.  A very intriguing, unique ale.

Best thing about this:  the head, beautiful in color and dissipates very slowly for the style.  Indicates higher-than-usual carb, which turns out to be right.  For me, the above-average carbonation & hoppiness detract a bit, but the flavor is exceptionally complex, and I have to say the nose is one of the best, malty as all get out.
Wow. What a brown. Great hazelnut/chocolate/coffee flavors. Just wonderful. John Maier has outdone himself with this one.
nutty, with a hint of chocolate in the aroma, very dark. really late, as your about to take another sip this slight coffee taste appears.  This is the best brown ale ever
Wow, amazing.  Looks, smells and tastes awesome!  Loved the slight coffee aftertaste.

Update: Im taking this one down a couple of notches.  Had it on tap and the sweet, nutty flavor was a little overbearing.  As my friend said it tastes like maple syrup.  I agreed.

One of the better Rogue beers.  Its medium bodied, but packed with flavor.  Its one of the few Rogue beers that I can finish the big bottle and be ready for another (and not be full).
A very nice beer. Very flavorful. Well-bodied, not too heavy. Great aroma.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ - quite clear ruby brown beer under a persistent beige foam; earthy and hazelnutty aroma; lighty toasted, some hoppy notes show up; medium-bodied, gently sweet, low bitterness; the finish is moderately long, lgihtly toasted with lingering hazelnutty notes

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2007 Re-rate:  I absolutely adored this beer when I first had it at the Blind Tiger in 1997 ($2/pint happy hour at that!).  Since then, Ive had little tastes and sips and none of them came close to what I remembered.  But finally, a shade over 10 years later, I get around to a re-rate.  Yeah, I suck.  Chestnut brown, bright, thin head.  Aroma is mainly a toasty-roasty dark malt.  The flavour shows this as well, but brings in a sickly sweet artificial hazelnut element.  The body is thin for a Rogue as is the hopping...yeah I know its a brown but something has to balance off that syrupy hazelnut.  What the hell was I thinking...this is poor.
I was very pleased by this beer - outstanding appearance, great flavor and aroma.  Isnt Rogue wonderful?
